   <h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">
    Amiens
   </h1>
   <div class="mw-body-content" id="bodyContent">
    <div class="noprint" id="siteSub">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div>
    <div id="contentSub">
    </div>
    <div class="mw-jump" id="jump-to-nav">
     Jump to:
     <a href="#mw-head">
      navigation
     </a>
     ,
     <a href="#p-search">
      search
     </a>
    </div>
    <div class="mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       This article is about the city in France. For the battles which occurred nearby, see
       <a class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Battle_of_Amiens_(disambiguation)" title="Battle of Amiens (disambiguation)">
        Battle of Amiens (disambiguation)
       </a>
       . For the locality in Australia, see
       <a href="/wiki/Amiens,_Queensland" title="Amiens, Queensland">
        Amiens, Queensland
       </a>
       .
      </div>

         </a>

         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UTC%2B1" title="UTC+1">
          UTC+1
         </a>
         )
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr class="mergedrow">
        <th scope="row">
         <span style="white-space:nowrap">
          • Summer (
          <a href="/wiki/Daylight_saving_time" title="Daylight saving time">
           DST
          </a>
          )
         </span>
        </th>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/Central_European_Summer_Time" title="Central European Summer Time">
          CEST
         </a>
         (
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UTC%2B2" title="UTC+2">
          UTC+2
         </a>
         )
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr class="mergedtoprow">
        <th scope="row">
         <a href="/wiki/INSEE_code" title="INSEE code">
          INSEE
         </a>
         /Postal code
        </th>
        <td class="adr">
         <span class="postal-code">
          <a class="external text" href="https://www.insee.fr/fr/statistiques/1405599?geo=COM-80021" rel="nofollow">
           80021
          </a>
          /80000
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr class="mergedtoprow">
        <th scope="row">
         Elevation
        </th>
        <td>
         14–106 m (46–348 ft)
         <br/>
         (avg. 33 m or 108 ft)
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;text-align:left; font-size:smaller">
         <p>
          <sup>
           <b>
            1
           </b>
          </sup>
          French Land Register data, which excludes lakes, ponds, glaciers &gt; 1 km² (0.386 sq mi or 247 acres) and river estuaries.
         </p>
         <sup>
          <b>
           2
          </b>
         </sup>
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Population_without_double_counting" title="Population without double counting">
           Population without double counting
          </a>
         </i>
         : residents of multiple communes (e.g., students and military personnel) only counted once.
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       <b>
        Amiens
       </b>
       (
       <small>
        French pronunciation: ​
       </small>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/French" title="Help:IPA/French">
         [amjɛ̃]
        </a>
       </span>
       ) is a city and
       <a href="/wiki/Communes_of_France" title="Communes of France">
        commune
       </a>
       in northern France, 120 km (75 mi) north of Paris and 100 km (62 mi) south-west of
       <a href="/wiki/Lille" title="Lille">
        Lille
       </a>
       . It is the capital of the
       <a href="/wiki/Somme_(department)" title="Somme (department)">
        Somme
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Departments_of_France" title="Departments of France">
        department
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Hauts-de-France" title="Hauts-de-France">
        Hauts-de-France
       </a>
       . The city had a population of 136,105 according to the 2006 census.
      </p>
      <p>
       It has one of the biggest university hospitals in France with a capacity of 1,200 beds.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Amiens_Cathedral" title="Amiens Cathedral">
        Amiens Cathedral
       </a>
       , the tallest of the large, classic,
       <a href="/wiki/Gothic_architecture" title="Gothic architecture">
        Gothic
       </a>
       churches of the 13th century and the largest in France of its kind, is a
       <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">
        World Heritage Site
       </a>
       . The author
       <a href="/wiki/Jules_Verne" title="Jules Verne">
        Jules Verne
       </a>
       lived in Amiens from 1871 until his death in 1905, and served on the city council for 15 years. During December, the town hosts the largest
       <a href="/wiki/Christmas_market" title="Christmas market">
        Christmas market
       </a>
       in northern France. Amiens is known for a few local foods, including "
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Macarons_d%27Amiens" title="Macarons d'Amiens">
        macarons d'Amiens
       </a>
       ", almond paste biscuits; "tuiles amienoises", chocolate and orange curved biscuits; "pâté de canard d'Amiens", duck pâté in pastry; "la ficelle Picarde", an oven-baked cheese-topped
       <a href="/wiki/Cr%C3%AApe" title="Crêpe">
        crêpe
       </a>
       ; and "
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flamiche_aux_poireaux" title="Flamiche aux poireaux">
        flamiche aux poireaux
       </a>
       ", a puff pastry tart made with leeks and cream.
      </p>

             <li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-69">

               <span class="tocnumber">
                8.1.7
               </span>
               <span class="toctext">

               </span>
              </a>
              <ul>
               <li class="toclevel-4 tocsection-70">

                 </span>
                </a>
               </li>
               <li class="toclevel-4 tocsection-72">

           </li>

      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
        History
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: History">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Amiens" title="History of Amiens">
        History of Amiens
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Amiens" title="Timeline of Amiens">
        Timeline of Amiens
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The first known settlement at this location was
       <b>
        Samarobriva
       </b>
       ("Somme bridge"), the central settlement of the
       <a href="/wiki/Ambiani" title="Ambiani">
        Ambiani
       </a>
       , one of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_peoples_of_Gaul" title="List of peoples of Gaul">
        principal tribes of Gaul
       </a>
       . The town was given the name Ambianum by the Romans, meaning settlement of the Ambiani people. Amiens was part of
       <a href="/wiki/Francia" title="Francia">
        Francia
       </a>
       from the 5th century.
       <a href="/wiki/Normans" title="Normans">
        Normans
       </a>
       sacked the city in 859 and again in 882. In 1113, the city was recognized by King
       <a href="/wiki/Louis_VI_of_France" title="Louis VI of France">
        Louis VI
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_France" title="Kingdom of France">
        France
       </a>
       and joined to the Crown of France in 1185. In 1597, Spanish soldiers held the city during the six-month
       <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Amiens_(1597)" title="Siege of Amiens (1597)">
        Siege of Amiens
       </a>
       , before
       <a href="/wiki/Henry_IV_of_France" title="Henry IV of France">
        Henry IV
       </a>
       regained control. During the 18th and 19th century, the textile tradition of Amiens became famous for its
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Velours" title="Velours">
        velours
       </a>
       . In 1789, the provinces of France were dismantled and the territory was organised into
       <a href="/wiki/Departments_of_France" title="Departments of France">
        departments
       </a>
       . Much of
       <a href="/wiki/Picardy" title="Picardy">
        Picardy
       </a>
       became the newly created department of
       <a href="/wiki/Somme_(department)" title="Somme (department)">
        Somme
       </a>
       with Amiens as the departmental capital. During the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Industrial_revolution" title="Industrial revolution">
        industrial revolution
       </a>
       , the city walls were demolished, opening up space for large boulevards around the town centre. The
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Henriville,_Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Henriville, Amiens (page does not exist)">
        Henriville
       </a>
       neighbourhood in the south of the city was developed around this time. In 1848, the first railway arrived in Amiens, linking the city to
       <a href="/wiki/Boulogne-sur-Mer" title="Boulogne-sur-Mer">
        Boulogne-sur-Mer
       </a>
       . During the 1870
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Amiens_(1870)" title="Battle of Amiens (1870)">
        Battle of Amiens
       </a>
       when the Somme was invaded by Prussian forces, Amiens was occupied.
      </p>
      <p>
       The town was fought over during both the First and Second World Wars, suffering much damage and being occupied several times by both sides. The 1918
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Amiens_(1918)" title="Battle of Amiens (1918)">
        Battle of Amiens
       </a>
       was the opening phase of the
       <a href="/wiki/Hundred_Days_Offensive" title="Hundred Days Offensive">
        Hundred Days Offensive
       </a>
       which led directly to the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Armistice_with_Germany" title="Armistice with Germany">
        Armistice with Germany
       </a>
       that ended the war. It was heavily bombed by the Royal Air Force during the Second World War. The city was rebuilt according to
       <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Dufau" title="Pierre Dufau">
        Pierre Dufau
       </a>
       's plans with a focus on widening the streets to ease traffic congestion. These newer structures were primarily built of brick, concrete and white stone with slate roofs. The architect
       <a href="/wiki/Auguste_Perret" title="Auguste Perret">
        Auguste Perret
       </a>
       designed the
       <a href="/wiki/Gare_d%27Amiens" title="Gare d'Amiens">
        Gare d'Amiens
       </a>
       train station and nearby
       <a href="/wiki/Tour_Perret_(Amiens)" title="Tour Perret (Amiens)">
        Tour Perret
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">
        Geography
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Geography">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Location">
        Location
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Location">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_commune_FR_insee_code_80021.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="605" data-file-width="756" height="176" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Map_commune_FR_insee_code_80021.png/220px-Map_commune_FR_insee_code_80021.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Map_commune_FR_insee_code_80021.png/330px-Map_commune_FR_insee_code_80021.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Map_commune_FR_insee_code_80021.png/440px-Map_commune_FR_insee_code_80021.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map_commune_FR_insee_code_80021.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Map of the Amiens and its surrounding communes
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Amiens, the regional prefecture of
       <a href="/wiki/Picardy" title="Picardy">
        Picardy
       </a>
       , is also the prefecture of the
       <a href="/wiki/Somme_(department)" title="Somme (department)">
        Somme
       </a>
       , one of the three departments (with
       <a href="/wiki/Oise" title="Oise">
        Oise
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Aisne" title="Aisne">
        Aisne
       </a>
       ) in the region. Located in the
       <a href="/wiki/Paris_Basin" title="Paris Basin">
        Paris Basin
       </a>
       , across the country the city benefits from a privileged geographical position (proximity to
       <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">
        Paris
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lille" title="Lille">
        Lille
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Rouen" title="Rouen">
        Rouen
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">
        London
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Brussels" title="Brussels">
        Brussels
       </a>
       ). At the crossroads of major European routes of movement (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/A1_autoroute_(France)" title="A1 autoroute (France)">
        A1
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/A16_autoroute" title="A16 autoroute">
        A16
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/A29_autoroute" title="A29 autoroute">
        A29
       </a>
       ), the city is also at the heart of a major rail star.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/As_the_crow_flies" title="As the crow flies">
        As the crow flies
       </a>
       , the city is 115 kilometres (71 mi) from Paris, 97 kilometres (60 mi) from Lille, 100 kilometres (62 mi) from Rouen, 162 kilometres (101 mi) from
       <a href="/wiki/Le_Havre" title="Le Havre">
        Le Havre
       </a>
       and 144 kilometres (89 mi) from
       <a href="/wiki/Reims" title="Reims">
        Reims
       </a>
       . At the regional level, Amiens is located 53 kilometres (33 mi) north of
       <a href="/wiki/Beauvais" title="Beauvais">
        Beauvais
       </a>
       , 71 kilometres (44 mi) west of
       <a href="/wiki/Saint-Quentin,_Aisne" title="Saint-Quentin, Aisne">
        Saint-Quentin
       </a>
       , 66 kilometres (41 mi) from
       <a href="/wiki/Compi%C3%A8gne" title="Compiègne">
        Compiègne
       </a>
       and 102 kilometres (63 mi) from
       <a href="/wiki/Laon" title="Laon">
        Laon
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       In area, it is the third in the Somme, after
       <a href="/wiki/Cr%C3%A9cy-en-Ponthieu" title="Crécy-en-Ponthieu">
        Crécy-en-Ponthieu
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Hornoy-le-Bourg" title="Hornoy-le-Bourg">
        Hornoy-le-Bourg
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Geology_and_relief">
        Geology and relief
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Geology and relief">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The area of the commune is 4,946 hectares (12,220 acres); the altitude varies between 14 and 106 metres (46 and 348 ft).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-1">
         [1]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span id="Hydrography:_Somme_and_canal.2C_Avre_and_Selle">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Hydrography:_Somme_and_canal,_Avre_and_Selle">
        Hydrography: Somme and canal, Avre and Selle
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Hydrography: Somme and canal, Avre and Selle">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LL_69_-_AMIENS_-_Vue_prise_dans_la_vieille_ville.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1600" data-file-width="1025" height="234" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/LL_69_-_AMIENS_-_Vue_prise_dans_la_vieille_ville.JPG/150px-LL_69_-_AMIENS_-_Vue_prise_dans_la_vieille_ville.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/LL_69_-_AMIENS_-_Vue_prise_dans_la_vieille_ville.JPG/225px-LL_69_-_AMIENS_-_Vue_prise_dans_la_vieille_ville.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/LL_69_-_AMIENS_-_Vue_prise_dans_la_vieille_ville.JPG/300px-LL_69_-_AMIENS_-_Vue_prise_dans_la_vieille_ville.JPG 2x" width="150"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:LL_69_-_AMIENS_-_Vue_prise_dans_la_vieille_ville.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The Somme in the old town at the beginning of the 20th century
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:INCONNU_-_Vieil_Amiens_-_Pont_Becquet.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1031" data-file-width="1625" height="140" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/INCONNU_-_Vieil_Amiens_-_Pont_Becquet.JPG/220px-INCONNU_-_Vieil_Amiens_-_Pont_Becquet.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/INCONNU_-_Vieil_Amiens_-_Pont_Becquet.JPG/330px-INCONNU_-_Vieil_Amiens_-_Pont_Becquet.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/INCONNU_-_Vieil_Amiens_-_Pont_Becquet.JPG/440px-INCONNU_-_Vieil_Amiens_-_Pont_Becquet.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:INCONNU_-_Vieil_Amiens_-_Pont_Becquet.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The Becquet Bridge, at the start of the 20th century
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Amiens is crossed by the
       <a href="/wiki/Main_stem" title="Main stem">
        main stem
       </a>
       of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/River_Somme" title="River Somme">
        River Somme
       </a>
       and is generally quiet, except during exceptional floods, several weeks long (such as spring 2001). It is also, on its southeastern outskirts, close to
       <a href="/wiki/Camon,_Somme" title="Camon, Somme">
        Camon
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Longueau" title="Longueau">
        Longueau
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Confluence" title="Confluence">
        confluence
       </a>
       with its main
       <a href="/wiki/Tributary" title="Tributary">
        tributary
       </a>
       on the left bank (to the south), the
       <a href="/wiki/Avre_(Somme)" title="Avre (Somme)">
        Avre
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Selle" title="Selle">
        Selle
       </a>
       enters from the northwest of Amiens, with two arms (including the Haute Selle) passing behind the Unicorn Stadium, the exhibition park, the megacity and horse racing track, then passing the end of the
       <i>
        Promenade de la Hotoie
       </i>
       and the zoo of Amiens, and to the right of the water treatment plant, in front of the island Sainte-Aragone, opposite the cemetery of La Madeleine in Amiens.
      </p>
      <p>
       The city developed in a natural narrowing of the river at the level of the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Hortillonnages_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Hortillonnages d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
        hortillonnages
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hortillonnages_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Hortillonnages d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , due to the advance of the rim of the Picard plateau in Saint-Pierre (
       <a href="/wiki/Ford_(crossing)" title="Ford (crossing)">
        ford crossing
       </a>
       ). The Amiens citadel is built on this limestone butte and
       <i>
        Rue Saint-Pierre
       </i>
       is a slightly inclined path to leave the city from the north. At this narrowing, a network of narrow canals led to the construction of bridges and buildings including
       <a href="/wiki/Textile_manufacturing" title="Textile manufacturing">
        textile mills
       </a>
       in the
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">
        Middle Ages
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The hydrographic network has always been an important asset operated by the city. The river helped shape the identity of the landscape, urban and economic territory. It is around the quarters of Saint-Leu, Saint-Maurice bordering the River Somme and most of the administrative and civil area of the current city centre which the city has developed since
       <a href="/wiki/Ancient_history" title="Ancient history">
        antiquity
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Canal_de_la_Somme" title="Canal de la Somme">
        Canal de la Somme
       </a>
       dates from the beginning of the 19th century and the bridge at the foot of the citadel was built after
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
        World War II
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">
        Climate
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Climate">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Amiens has a typical
       <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">
        oceanic climate
       </a>
       in the north of France, with relatively mild winters, cool summers, and rainfall well distributed throughout the year.
      </p>
      <div class="center">
       <div class="floatnone">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ombrothermic_diagram_of_Amiens.png">
         <img alt="Ombrothermic diagram of Amiens.png" data-file-height="852" data-file-width="1786" height="382" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Ombrothermic_diagram_of_Amiens.png/800px-Ombrothermic_diagram_of_Amiens.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Ombrothermic_diagram_of_Amiens.png/1200px-Ombrothermic_diagram_of_Amiens.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Ombrothermic_diagram_of_Amiens.png/1600px-Ombrothermic_diagram_of_Amiens.png 2x" width="800"/>
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">
        Transport
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Transport">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Amiens is a
       <a href="/wiki/Transport_hub" title="Transport hub">
        hub
       </a>
       between the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele-de-France_(region)" title="Île-de-France (region)">
        Île de France
       </a>
       and the rest of the north of France;
       <a href="/wiki/Normandy" title="Normandy">
        Normandy
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Benelux" title="Benelux">
        Benelux
       </a>
       ; and France and Great Britain. Amiens is not directly on principal European road and rail arteries, such as the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/A1_autoroute_(France)" title="A1 autoroute (France)">
        A1 motorway
       </a>
       and the Paris-Lille
       <a href="/wiki/TGV" title="TGV">
        TGV
       </a>
       train line, at present.
      </p>
      <p>
       However, at halfway between the urban areas of Lille and Paris, Amiens has good conditions of service and accessibility, including motorways (at the junction of the
       <a href="/wiki/A16_autoroute" title="A16 autoroute">
        A16
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/A29_autoroute" title="A29 autoroute">
        A29
       </a>
       ).
      </p>
      <p>
       A regular bus link with the
       <a href="/wiki/Gare_TGV_Haute-Picardie" title="Gare TGV Haute-Picardie">
        TGV Haute-Picardie station
       </a>
       also provides access to the
       <a href="/wiki/A%C3%A9roport_Charles_de_Gaulle_2_TGV" title="Aéroport Charles de Gaulle 2 TGV">
        Charles-de-Gaulle Airport station
       </a>
       . On the horizon of 2022,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-2">
         [2]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the
       <a href="/wiki/Roissy%E2%80%93Picardie_Link" title="Roissy–Picardie Link">
        Roissy–Picardie Link
       </a>
       will put Amiens 55 minutes from Paris Charles-de-Gaulle Airport and its TGV station.
      </p>
      <p>
       By train, Amiens is located at:
      </p>
      <center>
       <table style="vertical-align:top; width:100%;">
        <tr>
         <td style="vertical-align:top; width:50%;">
          <ul>
           <li>
            1 hour 5 minutes from Paris (16 round-trip trains per day)
           </li>
           <li>
            1 hour 15 minutes from Lille
           </li>
           <li>
            1 hour 15 minutes from Rouen
           </li>
          </ul>
         </td>
         <td style="vertical-align:top; width:50%;">
          <ul>
           <li>
            2 hours 30 minutes from Brussels
           </li>
           <li>
            3 hours 30 minutes from Lyon
           </li>
           <li>
            3 hours from London
           </li>
          </ul>
         </td>
        </tr>
       </table>
      </center>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Roads">
        Roads
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Roads">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also: [[:
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Rocade_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Rocade d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
        Rocade d'Amiens
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rocade_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Rocade d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ]]
      </div>
      <p>
       Since antiquity, Amiens has been a crossroads of important routes. The contemporary city is served by the
       <a href="/wiki/A16_autoroute" title="A16 autoroute">
        A16
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/A29_autoroute" title="A29 autoroute">
        A29
       </a>
       autoroutes. The
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Viaduc_Jules-Verne&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Viaduc Jules-Verne (page does not exist)">
        Jules Verne Viaduct
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viaduc_Jules-Verne" title="fr:Viaduc Jules-Verne">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , 943 metres (3,094 ft) long, crosses the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/River_Somme" title="River Somme">
        River Somme
       </a>
       to the east of the city and allows circumvention of the city by motorway-type roads. The A16 and A29 autoroutes, the RN1 and the RN25 form a bypass-type motorway around the city that the population has called the
       <i>
        Rocade d'Amiens
       </i>
       [ring road of Amiens]. Initially constituting national roads which are downgraded today, mostly as departmental roads, the greater urban area of Amiens is served by:
      </p>
      <center>
       <table style="vertical-align:top; width:100%;">
        <tr>
         <td style="vertical-align:top; width:50%;">
          <ul>
           <li>
            <a href="/wiki/Route_nationale_1" title="Route nationale 1">
             RN 1
            </a>
            to
            <a href="/wiki/Beauvais" title="Beauvais">
             Beauvais
            </a>
            and
            <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">
             Paris
            </a>
            , to the South, and towards
            <a href="/wiki/Abbeville" title="Abbeville">
             Abbeville
            </a>
            ,
            <a href="/wiki/Calais" title="Calais">
             Calais
            </a>
            ,
            <a href="/wiki/Dunkirk" title="Dunkirk">
             Dunkirk
            </a>
            and the Belgian border, northwest.
           </li>
           <li>
            <a href="/wiki/Route_nationale_25" title="Route nationale 25">
             RN 25
            </a>
            towards
            <a href="/wiki/Doullens" title="Doullens">
             Doullens
            </a>
            ,
            <a href="/wiki/Saint-Pol-sur-Ternoise" title="Saint-Pol-sur-Ternoise">
             Saint-Pol-sur-Ternoise
            </a>
            and
            <a href="/wiki/Arras" title="Arras">
             Arras
            </a>
           </li>
           <li>
            <a href="/wiki/Route_nationale_29" title="Route nationale 29">
             RD 1029
            </a>
            towards
            <a href="/wiki/Yvetot" title="Yvetot">
             Yvetot
            </a>
            and
            <a href="/wiki/Neufch%C3%A2tel-en-Bray" title="Neufchâtel-en-Bray">
             Neufchâtel-en-Bray
            </a>
            to the west,
            <a href="/wiki/Saint-Quentin,_Aisne" title="Saint-Quentin, Aisne">
             Saint-Quentin
            </a>
            and
            <a href="/wiki/La_Capelle" title="La Capelle">
             La Capelle
            </a>
            in the east.
           </li>
          </ul>
         </td>
         <td style="vertical-align:top; width:50%;">
          <ul>
           <li>
            <a href="/wiki/Route_nationale_29" title="Route nationale 29">
             RD 929
            </a>
            to
            <a href="/wiki/Albert,_Somme" title="Albert, Somme">
             Albert
            </a>
            and
            <a href="/wiki/Bapaume" title="Bapaume">
             Bapaume
            </a>
            and
            <a href="/wiki/Cambrai" title="Cambrai">
             Cambrai
            </a>
            .
           </li>
           <li>
            <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Route_nationale_35&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Route nationale 35 (page does not exist)">
             RD 935
            </a>
            <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
             (
             <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Route_nationale_35_(France)" title="fr:Route nationale 35 (France)">
              fr
             </a>
             )
            </span>
            towards
            <a href="/wiki/Compi%C3%A8gne" title="Compiègne">
             Compiègne
            </a>
            .
           </li>
           <li>
            <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Route_nationale_319&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Route nationale 319 (page does not exist)">
             RD 919
            </a>
            <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
             (
             <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Route_nationale_319" title="fr:Route nationale 319">
              fr
             </a>
             )
            </span>
            to
            <a href="/wiki/Mailly-Maillet" title="Mailly-Maillet">
             Mailly-Maillet
            </a>
            and
            <a href="/wiki/Arras" title="Arras">
             Arras
            </a>
            .
           </li>
           <li>
            <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Route_nationale_333&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Route nationale 333 (page does not exist)">
             RD 933
            </a>
            <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
             (
             <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Route_nationale_333" title="fr:Route nationale 333">
              fr
             </a>
             )
            </span>
            to
            <a href="/wiki/Bernaville" title="Bernaville">
             Bernaville
            </a>
            and
            <a href="/wiki/Auxi-le-Ch%C3%A2teau" title="Auxi-le-Château">
             Auxi-le-Château
            </a>
            .
           </li>
           <li>
            <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Route_nationale_334&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Route nationale 334 (page does not exist)">
             RD 934
            </a>
            <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
             (
             <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Route_nationale_334" title="fr:Route nationale 334">
              fr
             </a>
             )
            </span>
            to
            <a href="/wiki/Roye,_Somme" title="Roye, Somme">
             Roye
            </a>
            and
            <a href="/wiki/Noyon" title="Noyon">
             Noyon
            </a>
            .
           </li>
          </ul>
         </td>
        </tr>
       </table>
      </center>
      <p>
       Amiens is served by several motorways:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/A16_autoroute" title="A16 autoroute">
         A16
        </a>
        to
        <a href="/wiki/Calais" title="Calais">
         Calais
        </a>
        via
        <a href="/wiki/Abbeville" title="Abbeville">
         Abbeville
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Boulogne-sur-Mer" title="Boulogne-sur-Mer">
         Boulogne-sur-Mer
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        A16 to Paris via
        <a href="/wiki/Beauvais" title="Beauvais">
         Beauvais
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/A29_autoroute" title="A29 autoroute">
         A29
        </a>
        to
        <a href="/wiki/Rouen" title="Rouen">
         Rouen
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Le_Havre" title="Le Havre">
         Le Havre
        </a>
        via
        <a href="/wiki/Neufch%C3%A2tel-en-Bray" title="Neufchâtel-en-Bray">
         Neufchâtel-en-Bray
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        A29 to
        <a href="/wiki/Reims" title="Reims">
         Reims
        </a>
        via
        <a href="/wiki/Saint-Quentin,_Aisne" title="Saint-Quentin, Aisne">
         Saint-Quentin
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Laon" title="Laon">
         Laon
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        The proposed A24 autoroute from Amiens to
        <a href="/wiki/Lille" title="Lille">
         Lille
        </a>
        via
        <a href="/wiki/Doullens" title="Doullens">
         Doullens
        </a>
        was cancelled in 2006.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Parking">
        Parking
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Parking">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Parking-amiens.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="417" data-file-width="596" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Parking-amiens.png/220px-Parking-amiens.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Parking-amiens.png/330px-Parking-amiens.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Parking-amiens.png/440px-Parking-amiens.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Parking-amiens.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Map of parking in the city centre of Amiens in 2009.
         <div style="-moz-column-count:2; column-count:2;">
          <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
           <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #0000fd; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
           </span>
           Town Hall
          </div>
          <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
           <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #40fc00; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
           </span>
           Halles
          </div>
          <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
           <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #ffdb2d; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
           </span>
           Jacobins
          </div>
          <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
           <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #2de9ff; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
           </span>
           Trois Cailloux
          </div>
          <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
           <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #f80521; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
           </span>
           Saint-Leu
          </div>
          <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
           <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #f8b934; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
           </span>
           Amiens 2
          </div>
          <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
           <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #effd00; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
           </span>
           Perret
          </div>
          <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
           <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #444444; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
           </span>
           Free outdoor parking
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       According to the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Plan_de_d%C3%A9placements_urbains&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Plan de déplacements urbains (page does not exist)">
        urban transport plan
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plan_de_d%C3%A9placements_urbains" title="fr:Plan de déplacements urbains">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       (PDU) approved 19 December 2013 for the period 2013-2023 parking supply is considered abundant in Amiens.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PDU_3-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-PDU-3">
         [3]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Although important, demand for parking is less than what is available (capacity reserves are still 20% minimum: If the road is sometimes saturated, the occupancy rate of the underground parking remains globally less than 100%).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PDU_3-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-PDU-3">
         [3]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2013, the city counted approximately 70,000 public parking spaces, including 8,400 in the city centre and in its immediate vicinity, where 70% of places are paid.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PDU_3-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-PDU-3">
         [3]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        4,400 spaces on highways (1,950 in the inner city, including 1,600 paid)
       </li>
       <li>
        4,000 spaces in underground parking (620 other new places are programmed in a project for the Gare La Vallée development zone).
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       The underground car parks in the city centre are organised thus:
      </p>
      <table class="wikitable" style="border:0; text-align:center;">
       <tr>
        <th>
         Name
        </th>
        <th>
         Accessible by
        </th>
        <th>
         Close to
        </th>
        <th>
         Number of spaces
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         Halles
        </td>
        <td>
         Rue du Général-Leclerc
        </td>
        <td>
         Commercial Centre of Halles, belfry
        </td>
        <td>
         468
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         Centrum
        </td>
        <td>
         Rue Frédéric Petit
        </td>
        <td>
         Coliseum
        </td>
        <td>
         190
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         Hôtel de ville
        </td>
        <td>
         Rue de Beauvais
        </td>
        <td>
         Espace piétonnier, town hall
        </td>
        <td>
         80
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         Jacobins
        </td>
        <td>
         Rue des Jacobins
        </td>
        <td>
         Espace piétonnier, prefecture
        </td>
        <td>
         587
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         Saint-Leu
        </td>
        <td>
         Rue des Huchers
        </td>
        <td>
         Faculties of law, political science and economy management; cathedral
        </td>
        <td>
         585
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         Trois Cailloux
        </td>
        <td>
         Rue Robert de Luzarches
        </td>
        <td>
         Espace piétonnier, courthouse, cathedral
        </td>
        <td>
         486
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         Amiens 2
        </td>
        <td>
         Boulevard d'Alsace-Lorraine, rue de la Vallée
        </td>
        <td>
