        </td>
        <td>
         724
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         Perret
        </td>
        <td>
         Boulevard de Belfort, rue Vulfran-Warmé
        </td>
        <td>
         Cinema, SNCF railway station
        </td>
        <td>
         490
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         Gare La Vallée
        </td>
        <td>
         Rue de la Vallée
        </td>
        <td>
         SNCF railway station, Gare La Vallée development zone
        </td>
        <td>
         840
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       As of 2007
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , a residential parking system is deployed in Saint-Anne ward to cope with congestion in the streets by cars of users from the
       <a href="/wiki/Gare_d%27Amiens" title="Gare d'Amiens">
        SNCF railway station
       </a>
       . During the campaign for the
       <a href="/wiki/French_municipal_elections,_2008" title="French municipal elections, 2008">
        municipal election of 2008
       </a>
       , parking was one of the important topics of debate.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-4">
         [4]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A year after the change of majority, the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Gilles_Demailly&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Gilles Demailly (page does not exist)">
        Gilles Demailly
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gilles_Demailly" title="fr:Gilles Demailly">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       team launched a consultation with the population.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5">
        <a href="#cite_note-5">
         [5]
        </a>
       </sup>
       From 2011, the residential parking was extended to the quarters of Gare-La-Vallée and Riolan, then in 2012 the Noyon and the area east of the Riolan sector. In 2014, 2,600 parking spaces
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6">
        <a href="#cite_note-6">
         [6]
        </a>
       </sup>
       were affected by this system which is designed to allow city residents more parking near their homes, to promote a better rotation of vehicles in the streets and reduce permanent occupation of public space by the cars cluttering the highway.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Public_transport">
        Public transport
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Public transport">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles: [[:
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Former_tramway_of_Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Former tramway of Amiens (page does not exist)">
        Former tramway of Amiens
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancien_tramway_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Ancien tramway d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ]], [[:
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Tramway_of_Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Tramway of Amiens (page does not exist)">
        Tramway of Amiens
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tramway_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Tramway d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ]], and [[:
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Public_transport_in_Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Public transport in Amiens (page does not exist)">
        Public transport in Amiens
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transports_en_commun_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Transports en commun d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ]]
      </div>
      <p>
       Two
       <a href="/wiki/Tram" title="Tram">
        tram
       </a>
       lines over 10.7 kilometres (6.6 mi) were opened in 1887. The two intersect at
       <i>
        Place Gambetta
       </i>
       , one linking
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Cimeti%C3%A8re_de_La_Madeleine_(Amiens)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Cimetière de La Madeleine (Amiens) (page does not exist)">
        La Madeleine Cemetery
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cimeti%C3%A8re_de_La_Madeleine_(Amiens)" title="fr:Cimetière de La Madeleine (Amiens)">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abbaye_de_Saint-Acheul" title="Abbaye de Saint-Acheul">
        Church of Saint-Acheul
       </a>
       , Cagnard bridge,
       <i>
        Rue de Noyon
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        Rue Jules-Barni
       </i>
       ; the other from the Church of Saint-Pierre at the racecourse, by the streets of Saint-Leu, Frédéric-Petit and Colbert.
      </p>
      <p>
       Electrified in 1899, the network grew to seven lines totalling 19 kilometres (12 mi) in 1906. From 1932,
       <a href="/wiki/Longueau" title="Longueau">
        Longueau
       </a>
       was linked to Amiens by a bus service. The terrible German bombing in 1940 which destroyed most of the city centre also hit the Jules-Ferry Road tram
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Former_tramway_of_Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Former tramway of Amiens (page does not exist)">
        depot
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancien_tramway_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Ancien tramway d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       and totally destroyed the tram fleet. Only the Longueau bus survived. Amiens remained without transport. A few old Parisian buses were then used for an extremely reduced service. These buses as well as the survivor bus were then converted to city gas and equipped with tanks on the roof covered by a huge white dome. This service continued with this extraordinary material until approximately 1946. There were only two urban lines: An east-west line (Saint-Acheul - Montieres) and a northeast-southwest line (Beauville - road to Rouen). It was decided after war to serve the city by
       <a href="/wiki/Trolleybus" title="Trolleybus">
        trolleybus
       </a>
       with one bus route to Longueau. This programme was only in part realised (serving Saint-Acheul), road to Rouen, La Madeleine and Saint-Pierre. In 1964, trolleybuses were abandoned and the bus became ubiquitous in Amiens transportation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7">
        <a href="#cite_note-7">
         [7]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The bus network is today managed by the Ametis
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Soci%C3%A9t%C3%A9_d%27%C3%A9conomie_mixte&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Société d'économie mixte (page does not exist)">
        mixed economy company
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soci%C3%A9t%C3%A9_d%27%C3%A9conomie_mixte" title="fr:Société d'économie mixte">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , whose network covers
       <a href="/wiki/Communaut%C3%A9_d%27agglom%C3%A9ration_Amiens_M%C3%A9tropole" title="Communauté d'agglomération Amiens Métropole">
        Amiens Métropole
       </a>
       , the agglomeration of Amiens. The establishment of dedicated
       <a href="/wiki/Bus_lane" title="Bus lane">
        bus lanes
       </a>
       began in 2006. Former Mayor
       <a href="/wiki/Gilles_de_Robien" title="Gilles de Robien">
        Gilles de Robien
       </a>
       had envisioned the creation of a
       <a href="/wiki/Tram" title="Tram">
        tram
       </a>
       , but the choice of dedicated
       <a href="/wiki/Bus_lane" title="Bus lane">
        bus lanes
       </a>
       had been preferred for reasons of cost and attendance. His successor, Mayor
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Gilles_Demailly&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Gilles Demailly (page does not exist)">
        Gilles Demailly
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gilles_Demailly" title="fr:Gilles Demailly">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , had been considering the development of a
       <span style="border-bottom:1px dotted" title="Transport en commun en site propre (public transport in a dedicated site)">
        TSCP
       </span>
       in the metropolitan area. As a result of numerous studies and conferences, elected representatives voted for the creation of a tram at the municipal Council of 15 November 2012. The project had been endorsed by the
       <a href="/wiki/Communaut%C3%A9_d%27agglom%C3%A9ration_Amiens_M%C3%A9tropole" title="Communauté d'agglomération Amiens Métropole">
        Communauté d'agglomération Amiens Métropole
       </a>
       on 18 December 2012 and the commissioning of a first north-south
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Tramway_of_Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Tramway of Amiens (page does not exist)">
        tram route
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tramway_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Tramway d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       was scheduled for 2018/2019.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8">
        <a href="#cite_note-8">
         [8]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Following the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=2014_municipal_election_in_Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="2014 municipal election in Amiens (page does not exist)">
        elections of 2014
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89lection_municipale_de_2014_%C3%A0_Amiens" title="fr:Élection municipale de 2014 à Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , which were a defeat for most municipal and community carriers of the project, the new mayor of Amiens
       <a href="/wiki/Brigitte_Four%C3%A9" title="Brigitte Fouré">
        Brigitte Fouré
       </a>
       and by extension the new president of Amiens Métropole
       <a href="/wiki/Alain_Gest" title="Alain Gest">
        Alain Gest
       </a>
       decided to suspend the project at least during the time of their respective mandates, thus applying a campaign promise (the tram was at the heart of debate)
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9">
        <a href="#cite_note-9">
         [9]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and despite a project announcement of
       <a href="/wiki/Guided_bus" title="Guided bus">
        trams on tyres
       </a>
       (of
       <a href="/wiki/Bombardier_Guided_Light_Transit" title="Bombardier Guided Light Transit">
        TVR
       </a>
       type).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10">
        <a href="#cite_note-10">
         [10]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11">
        <a href="#cite_note-11">
         [11]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Improvement of public transit would then be only by that of the bus network. Indeed, in December of the same year, the Community Council approved funding for a study (the sixth in 20 years)
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12">
        <a href="#cite_note-12">
         [12]
        </a>
       </sup>
       relating to the establishment of a
       <a href="/wiki/Bus_rapid_transit" title="Bus rapid transit">
        rapid transit
       </a>
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Public_transport_in_Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Public transport in Amiens (page does not exist)">
        bus network
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transports_en_commun_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Transports en commun d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       (BHNS), which should enter into service in March 2019, and whose vehicles could be electric.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13">
        <a href="#cite_note-13">
         [13]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 194.66666666667px">
        <div style="width: 194.66666666667px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 192.66666666667px;">
          <div style="margin:0px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LL_35_-_AMIENS_-_La_Place_Gambetta_(couleur,_2_trams_dt_le_30).jpg">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="1017" data-file-width="1633" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/LL_35_-_AMIENS_-_La_Place_Gambetta_%28couleur%2C_2_trams_dt_le_30%29.jpg/289px-LL_35_-_AMIENS_-_La_Place_Gambetta_%28couleur%2C_2_trams_dt_le_30%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/LL_35_-_AMIENS_-_La_Place_Gambetta_%28couleur%2C_2_trams_dt_le_30%29.jpg/434px-LL_35_-_AMIENS_-_La_Place_Gambetta_%28couleur%2C_2_trams_dt_le_30%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/LL_35_-_AMIENS_-_La_Place_Gambetta_%28couleur%2C_2_trams_dt_le_30%29.jpg/578px-LL_35_-_AMIENS_-_La_Place_Gambetta_%28couleur%2C_2_trams_dt_le_30%29.jpg 2x" width="193"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           The
           <i>
            Place Gambetta
           </i>
           : An important hub of the former tram network of Amiens at the beginning of the 20th century.
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 184.66666666667px">
        <div style="width: 184.66666666667px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 182.66666666667px;">
          <div style="margin:0px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LL_65_-_AMIENS_-_Le_lyc%C3%A9e_de_Jeunes_Filles.JPG">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="1062" data-file-width="1614" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/LL_65_-_AMIENS_-_Le_lyc%C3%A9e_de_Jeunes_Filles.JPG/274px-LL_65_-_AMIENS_-_Le_lyc%C3%A9e_de_Jeunes_Filles.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/LL_65_-_AMIENS_-_Le_lyc%C3%A9e_de_Jeunes_Filles.JPG/411px-LL_65_-_AMIENS_-_Le_lyc%C3%A9e_de_Jeunes_Filles.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/LL_65_-_AMIENS_-_Le_lyc%C3%A9e_de_Jeunes_Filles.JPG/547px-LL_65_-_AMIENS_-_Le_lyc%C3%A9e_de_Jeunes_Filles.JPG 2x" width="183"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           The lycée de jeunes filles and tramway,
           <i>
            Rue des Otages
           </i>
           , now Lycée Madeleine-Michelis.
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px">
        <div style="width: 162px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;">
          <div style="margin:0px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mercedes_Citaro_O530GII_n%C2%B0331_AMETIS_Gare_du_Nord.jpg">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Mercedes_Citaro_O530GII_n%C2%B0331_AMETIS_Gare_du_Nord.jpg/240px-Mercedes_Citaro_O530GII_n%C2%B0331_AMETIS_Gare_du_Nord.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Mercedes_Citaro_O530GII_n%C2%B0331_AMETIS_Gare_du_Nord.jpg/360px-Mercedes_Citaro_O530GII_n%C2%B0331_AMETIS_Gare_du_Nord.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Mercedes_Citaro_O530GII_n%C2%B0331_AMETIS_Gare_du_Nord.jpg/480px-Mercedes_Citaro_O530GII_n%C2%B0331_AMETIS_Gare_du_Nord.jpg 2x" width="160"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           A bus of the network of
           <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Public_transport_in_Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Public transport in Amiens (page does not exist)">
            public transport in Amiens
           </a>
           <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
            (
            <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/transports_en_commun_d%27Amiens" title="fr:transports en commun d'Amiens">
             fr
            </a>
            )
           </span>
           .
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cycle_networks">
        Cycle networks
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Cycle networks">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:V%C3%A9lam_Amiens.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2056" data-file-width="3173" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/V%C3%A9lam_Amiens.jpg/220px-V%C3%A9lam_Amiens.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/V%C3%A9lam_Amiens.jpg/330px-V%C3%A9lam_Amiens.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/V%C3%A9lam_Amiens.jpg/440px-V%C3%A9lam_Amiens.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:V%C3%A9lam_Amiens.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Vélam public
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bicycle_sharing_system" title="Bicycle sharing system">
          bicycle sharing system
         </a>
         in Amiens.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Amiens has developed two bike services:
       <i>
        Buscyclette
       </i>
       and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=V%C3%A9lam&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Vélam (page does not exist)">
        <i>
         Velam
        </i>
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/V%C3%A9lam" title="fr:Vélam">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       .
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <i>
         Buscyclette
        </i>
        is a service of rental bikes on demand, created in May 1999. In 2014, nearly 2,400 "green bikes" are available for rent, essentially city bikes but also
        <a href="/wiki/Electric_bicycle" title="Electric bicycle">
         electric bikes
        </a>
        (VAE),
        <a href="/wiki/Folding_bicycle" title="Folding bicycle">
         folding bicycles
        </a>
        and specific bikes (kids bikes, child trailers,
        <a href="/wiki/Mountain_bike" title="Mountain bike">
         mountain bikes
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Freight_bicycle" title="Freight bicycle">
         freight bikes
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Tandem_bicycle" title="Tandem bicycle">
         tandems
        </a>
        , etc.). The rental period varies from half a day to one year.
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=V%C3%A9lam&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Vélam (page does not exist)">
         <i>
          Velam
         </i>
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/V%C3%A9lam" title="fr:Vélam">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        is a
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bicycle_sharing_system" title="Bicycle sharing system">
         bike sharing system
        </a>
        (VLS) created on 16 February 2008, an adaptation of the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cyclocity" title="Cyclocity">
         Cyclocity
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyclocity" title="fr:Cyclocity">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        system managed by
        <a href="/wiki/JCDecaux" title="JCDecaux">
         JCDecaux
        </a>
        , similar to
        <a href="/wiki/V%C3%A9lo%27v" title="Vélo'v">
         Vélo'v
        </a>
        in Lyon and
        <a href="/wiki/V%C3%A9lib%27" title="Vélib'">
         Vélib'
        </a>
        in Paris.
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=V%C3%A9lam&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Vélam (page does not exist)">
         Vélam
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/V%C3%A9lam" title="fr:Vélam">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        offers 313 bikes distributed every 300 to 400 metres in the centre of Amiens and 26 stations.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       In 2012,
       <a href="/wiki/Communaut%C3%A9_d%27agglom%C3%A9ration_Amiens_M%C3%A9tropole" title="Communauté d'agglomération Amiens Métropole">
        Amiens Métropole
       </a>
       had 100 kilometres (62 mi) of routes for cyclists.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PDU_3-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-PDU-3">
         [3]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Despite the development of a bicycle plan in 1997 which was planning the development of 500 kilometres (310 mi) of equipped cycleways, the network of the territory in terms of paths is still incomplete.
      </p>
      <p>
       The blueprint of the bicycle facilities of the agglomeration (SDAC) provides, over a period of 10 years (2014-2024),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PDU_3-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-PDU-3">
         [3]
        </a>
       </sup>
       for 188 kilometres (117 mi) of cycle routes and equips 490 sites for the parking of bikes. This plan also includes the deployment of parking facilities over the entire territory of the city, close to the facilities frequented by bikers, as well as
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Tourne-%C3%A0-droite_cycliste&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Tourne-à-droite cycliste (page does not exist)">
        cyclist right-turns
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tourne-%C3%A0-droite_cycliste" title="fr:Tourne-à-droite cycliste">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       at traffic lights or even the maintenance of existing facilities.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Railways">
        Railways
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Railways">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Verr%C3%A8re_place_Alphonse_Fiquet,_Gare_d%27Amiens.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2936" data-file-width="3909" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Verr%C3%A8re_place_Alphonse_Fiquet%2C_Gare_d%27Amiens.jpg/220px-Verr%C3%A8re_place_Alphonse_Fiquet%2C_Gare_d%27Amiens.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Verr%C3%A8re_place_Alphonse_Fiquet%2C_Gare_d%27Amiens.jpg/330px-Verr%C3%A8re_place_Alphonse_Fiquet%2C_Gare_d%27Amiens.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Verr%C3%A8re_place_Alphonse_Fiquet%2C_Gare_d%27Amiens.jpg/440px-Verr%C3%A8re_place_Alphonse_Fiquet%2C_Gare_d%27Amiens.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Verr%C3%A8re_place_Alphonse_Fiquet,_Gare_d%27Amiens.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Gare du Nord and its canopy in August 2012
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       There are three railway stations:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        Two stations on the
        <a href="/wiki/Longueau%E2%80%93Boulogne_railway" title="Longueau–Boulogne railway">
         Paris-Boulogne
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Amiens%E2%80%93Rouen_railway" title="Amiens–Rouen railway">
         Amiens - Rouen
        </a>
        lines:
       </li>
      </ul>
      <dl>
       <dd>
        <ul>
         <li>
          The
          <a href="/wiki/Gare_d%27Amiens" title="Gare d'Amiens">
           Amiens station
          </a>
          , main station, known as
          <i>
           Gare du Nord
          </i>
          , in memory of the
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/French_Northern_Railway" title="French Northern Railway">
           Compagnie du Nord
          </a>
          who created it. Every day, 15,000 travellers use its seven lines.
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bedel_14-0">
           <a href="#cite_note-bedel-14">
            [14]
           </a>
          </sup>
         </li>
        </ul>
       </dd>
      </dl>
      <dl>
       <dd>
        <ul>
         <li>
          The
          <a href="/wiki/Gare_de_Saint-Roch_(Somme)" title="Gare de Saint-Roch (Somme)">
           station of Saint-Roch
          </a>
         </li>
        </ul>
       </dd>
      </dl>
      <p>
       Connections from these two stations include to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gare_de_Lille-Flandres" title="Gare de Lille-Flandres">
        Lille
       </a>
       via
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arras,_France" title="Arras, France">
        Arras
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Douai" title="Douai">
        Douai
       </a>
       , to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Boulogne" title="Boulogne">
        Boulogne
       </a>
       via
       <a href="/wiki/Abbeville" title="Abbeville">
        Abbeville
       </a>
       , to Paris-Nord via
       <a href="/wiki/Creil" title="Creil">
        Creil
       </a>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/Compi%C3%A8gne" title="Compiègne">
        Compiègne
       </a>
       , to
       <a href="/wiki/Reims" title="Reims">
        Reims
       </a>
       via
       <a href="/wiki/Tergnier" title="Tergnier">
        Tergnier
       </a>
       , and to
       <a href="/wiki/Rouen" title="Rouen">
        Rouen
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        A station located on the
        <a href="/wiki/Paris%E2%80%93Lille_railway" title="Paris–Lille railway">
         Paris - Lille line
        </a>
        in
        <a href="/wiki/Longueau" title="Longueau">
         Longueau
        </a>
        serving south of Amiens and the communes of Longueau,
        <a href="/wiki/Cagny,_Somme" title="Cagny, Somme">
         Cagny
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Boves,_Somme" title="Boves, Somme">
         Boves
        </a>
        , etc.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <dl>
       <dd>
        <ul>
         <li>
          <a href="/wiki/Gare_de_Longueau" title="Gare de Longueau">
           Longueau station
          </a>
          , a passenger station of the historic railway hub in
          <a href="/wiki/Longueau" title="Longueau">
           Longueau
          </a>
          . Every day, 2,500 travellers use its two lines.
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bedel_14-1">
           <a href="#cite_note-bedel-14">
            [14]
           </a>
          </sup>
         </li>
        </ul>
       </dd>
      </dl>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Gare_de_Monti%C3%A8res&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Gare de Montières (page does not exist)">
         Montieres station
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gare_de_Monti%C3%A8res" title="fr:Gare de Montières">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        , station assigned to the freight traffic, it serves only the industrial zone of Amiens. This station is located on the former railway line of
        <a href="/wiki/Doullens" title="Doullens">
         Doullens
        </a>
        .
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       Many regional and extra regional links (Haute-Normandie, Nord-Pas-de-Calais, Champagne-Ardenne and île-de-France) pass through Amiens, especially by
       <a href="/wiki/TER_Picardie" title="TER Picardie">
        TER Picardie
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       A station located 45 kilometres (28 mi) from Amiens, the
       <a href="/wiki/Gare_TGV_Haute-Picardie" title="Gare TGV Haute-Picardie">
        Haute-Picardie TGV station
       </a>
       , allows access to the
       <a href="/wiki/TGV" title="TGV">
        TGV
       </a>
       network. It is served by buses from Amiens. Its isolated character earned it the name of
       <i>
        gare des betteraves
       </i>
       , or
       <i>
        gare betteraves
       </i>
       , at the time of its construction.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">
        <a href="#cite_note-15">
         [15]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 189.33333333333px">
        <div style="width: 189.33333333333px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 187.33333333333px;">
          <div style="margin:0px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CARON_328_-_AMIENS_-_La_Gare_du_Nord.jpg">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="1051" data-file-width="1639" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/CARON_328_-_AMIENS_-_La_Gare_du_Nord.jpg/281px-CARON_328_-_AMIENS_-_La_Gare_du_Nord.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/CARON_328_-_AMIENS_-_La_Gare_du_Nord.jpg/421px-CARON_328_-_AMIENS_-_La_Gare_du_Nord.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/CARON_328_-_AMIENS_-_La_Gare_du_Nord.jpg/562px-CARON_328_-_AMIENS_-_La_Gare_du_Nord.jpg 2x" width="188"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           Gare du Nord (old postcard published by Caron No. 328, postmarked in 1909).
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 188.66666666667px">
        <div style="width: 188.66666666667px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 186.66666666667px;">
          <div style="margin:0px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:INCONNU_-_AMIENS_-_Int%C3%A9rieur_de_la_Gare_Saint-Roch.jpg">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="1048" data-file-width="1629" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/INCONNU_-_AMIENS_-_Int%C3%A9rieur_de_la_Gare_Saint-Roch.jpg/280px-INCONNU_-_AMIENS_-_Int%C3%A9rieur_de_la_Gare_Saint-Roch.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/INCONNU_-_AMIENS_-_Int%C3%A9rieur_de_la_Gare_Saint-Roch.jpg/420px-INCONNU_-_AMIENS_-_Int%C3%A9rieur_de_la_Gare_Saint-Roch.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/INCONNU_-_AMIENS_-_Int%C3%A9rieur_de_la_Gare_Saint-Roch.jpg/560px-INCONNU_-_AMIENS_-_Int%C3%A9rieur_de_la_Gare_Saint-Roch.jpg 2x" width="187"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           Inside Saint-Roch railway station (postcard postmarked in 1905).
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px">
        <div style="width: 162px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;">
          <div style="margin:0px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Amiens_St_Roch_(ext%C3%A9rieur).jpg">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Amiens_St_Roch_%28ext%C3%A9rieur%29.jpg/240px-Amiens_St_Roch_%28ext%C3%A9rieur%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Amiens_St_Roch_%28ext%C3%A9rieur%29.jpg/360px-Amiens_St_Roch_%28ext%C3%A9rieur%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Amiens_St_Roch_%28ext%C3%A9rieur%29.jpg/480px-Amiens_St_Roch_%28ext%C3%A9rieur%29.jpg 2x" width="160"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           Gare Saint-Roch.
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px">
        <div style="width: 162px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;">
          <div style="margin:0px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gare_de_Longueau_-_La_Halle.JPG">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Gare_de_Longueau_-_La_Halle.JPG/240px-Gare_de_Longueau_-_La_Halle.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Gare_de_Longueau_-_La_Halle.JPG/360px-Gare_de_Longueau_-_La_Halle.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Gare_de_Longueau_-_La_Halle.JPG/480px-Gare_de_Longueau_-_La_Halle.JPG 2x" width="160"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           Gare de Longueau.
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Air_transport">
        Air transport
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Air transport">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       In addition to
       <a href="/wiki/Amiens_%E2%80%93_Glisy_Aerodrome" title="Amiens – Glisy Aerodrome">
        Amiens – Glisy Aerodrome
       </a>
       , bordering the town's eastern edge 5 kilometres (3.1 mi) from the centre, there are several airports nearby.
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Albert_%E2%80%93_Picardie_Airport" title="Albert – Picardie Airport">
         Albert – Picardie Airport
        </a>
        is located 20 minutes northeast of the city.
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beauvais-Till%C3%A9_Airport" title="Beauvais-Tillé Airport">
         Beauvais-Tillé Airport
        </a>
        , the ninth largest French airport by usage, located 45 minutes by car south of the city, and served by a bus service from Amiens.
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Lille_Airport" title="Lille Airport">
         Lille Airport
        </a>
        , reachable by train or by road using the A29 and A1.
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paris-Charles_de_Gaulle_Airport" title="Paris-Charles de Gaulle Airport">
         Paris-Charles de Gaulle Airport
        </a>
        , reachable by train or by road using the A29 and A1, or A16 and N104. The creation of a railway between
        <a href="/wiki/Creil" title="Creil">
         Creil
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/A%C3%A9roport_Charles_de_Gaulle_2_TGV" title="Aéroport Charles de Gaulle 2 TGV">
         Roissy
        </a>
        will put Amiens 55 minutes from Paris Charles de Gaulle airport by 2020.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16">
         <a href="#cite_note-16">
          [16]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Waterways">
        Waterways
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Waterways">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       The Somme
       <a href="/wiki/Canal" title="Canal">
        canal
       </a>
       runs through the town to the
       <a href="/wiki/English_Channel" title="English Channel">
        English Channel
       </a>
       . This canal is linked to the
       <a href="/wiki/Canal_du_Nord" title="Canal du Nord">
        Canal du Nord
       </a>
       (Paris to Lille metropolitan area)
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanism">
        Urbanism
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Urbanism">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Urban_morphology">
        Urban morphology
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Urban morphology">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Amiens comprises a number of neighbourhoods ("quartiers" in French) with their own characteristics, including
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Saint-Leu,_Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Saint-Leu, Amiens (page does not exist)">
        Saint-Leu
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=St-Maurice,_Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="St-Maurice, Amiens (page does not exist)">
        St-Maurice
       </a>
       , Henriville, and
       <a href="/wiki/Saint-Acheul" title="Saint-Acheul">
        Saint-Acheul
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Saint-Leu_quarter">
        Saint-Leu quarter
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Saint-Leu quarter">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       St-Leu is a part of Amiens north of the city centre. It has many older wooden and brick houses and several canals. At the foot of the cathedral, traversed by canals, this picturesque area was largely rehabilitated during the 1990s. It extends to the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/River_Somme" title="River Somme">
        Somme
       </a>
       canal, located more to the north, at the foot of the Coteau Saint-Pierre on which the fortress of
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Jean_Errard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Jean Errard (page does not exist)">
        Jean Errard
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean_Errard" title="fr:Jean Errard">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , called
       <i>
        Citadelle
       </i>
       , was built. Historically, it was the poor quarter of the city, where butchers, tanners and dyers gathered.
      </p>
      <p>
       Amiens University's Faculty of Sciences, present since the 1960s, has been renovated and expanded on occasion. The Faculty of Law and Economics has also been transferred since the mid-1990s from the campus (offset to the south of the city) to its new location at the foot of the cathedral.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17">
        <a href="#cite_note-17">
         [note 1]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The open-air parking it replaces was a "gap" in the landscape dating from
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
        World War II
       </a>
       . Nonetheless, it allowed an unobstructed view of the cathedral. Most of the buildings have been renovated and transformed into housing much of which is for students, many of whom are in the quarter.
      </p>
      <p>
       The area became the heart of the Amiens people's evenings, with many establishments (bars, restaurants, etc.) on
       <i>
        Place du Don
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        Quai Bélu
       </i>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       At
       <i>
        Rue Saint-Leu
       </i>
       is found the church, located just between the Faculty of Science and Law-Economy (UPJV).
      </p>
      <p>
       Two theatres were established in the quarter, that of the
       <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A9s_Cabotans" title="Chés Cabotans">
        Chés Cabotans
       </a>
       (puppet shows in the
       <a href="/wiki/Picard_language" title="Picard language">
        Picard language
       </a>
       ) and the
       <i>
        Maison du Théâtre
       </i>
       at the foot of the Saint-Leu Church. There is also
       <i>
        La Lune des Pirates
       </i>
       , a concert hall.
      </p>
      <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182px">
        <div style="width: 182px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 180px;">
          <div style="margin:0px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:0_Amiens_-_Place_du_Don_-_Cath%C3%A9drale_(1).JPG">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3456" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/0_Amiens_-_Place_du_Don_-_Cath%C3%A9drale_%281%29.JPG/270px-0_Amiens_-_Place_du_Don_-_Cath%C3%A9drale_%281%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/0_Amiens_-_Place_du_Don_-_Cath%C3%A9drale_%281%29.JPG/405px-0_Amiens_-_Place_du_Don_-_Cath%C3%A9drale_%281%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/0_Amiens_-_Place_du_Don_-_Cath%C3%A9drale_%281%29.JPG/540px-0_Amiens_-_Place_du_Don_-_Cath%C3%A9drale_%281%29.JPG 2x" width="180"/>
           </a>
          </div>

           </i>

          </p>

           </a>

           <i>

          </p>

           <i>

           </i>
          </p>

       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 210.66666666667px">

           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           Canal in the Saint-Leu quarter
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px">
        <div style="width: 162px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;">
          <div style="margin:0px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Quai_belu_amiens.JPG">

           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           Quai Bélu on the banks of the Somme, near the old market on the waterside
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 172px">
        <div style="width: 172px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;">

          <p>

          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Saint-Maurice_quarter">
        Saint-Maurice quarter
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Saint-Maurice quarter">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Located to the west of the
       <a href="/wiki/Citadel" title="Citadel">
        Citadelle
       </a>
       , and east of the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Cimeti%C3%A8re_de_La_Madeleine_(Amiens)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Cimetière de La Madeleine (Amiens) (page does not exist)">
        La Madeleine Cemetery
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cimeti%C3%A8re_de_La_Madeleine_(Amiens)" title="fr:Cimetière de La Madeleine (Amiens)">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , this very old working-class quarter of Amiens, and industrial centre of the 18th century, is undergoing rehabilitation with the construction, rearrangement and renovation of much housing.
      </p>
      <p>
       Bordered by the
       <a href="/wiki/Canal_de_la_Somme" title="Canal de la Somme">
        Canal de la Somme
       </a>
       , it offers a stopover for leisure boats, which must go through a lock.
      </p>
      <p>
       The walls of the city's former
       <a href="/wiki/Dye" title="Dye">
        dye
       </a>
       factory are now those of the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%89cole_sup%C3%A9rieure_d%27art_et_de_design_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="École supérieure d'art et de design d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
        École supérieure d'art et de design d'Amiens
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89cole_sup%C3%A9rieure_d%27art_et_de_design_d%27Amiens" title="fr:École supérieure d'art et de design d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       (ESAD) as well as those of the Faculty of Arts. The
       <a href="/wiki/ESIEE_Amiens" title="ESIEE Amiens">
        École supérieure d'ingénieurs en électronique et électrotechnique
       </a>
       (ESIEE) is in the same quarter. As the Citadelle, it will be renovated by the architect
       <a href="/wiki/Renzo_Piano" title="Renzo Piano">
        Renzo Piano
       </a>
       to accommodate the university departments (UFR) of letters, of history and geography, of languages, the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%89cole_sup%C3%A9rieure_du_professorat_et_de_l%27%C3%A9ducation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="École supérieure du professorat et de l'éducation (page does not exist)">
        École supérieure du professorat et de l'éducation
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89cole_sup%C3%A9rieure_du_professorat_et_de_l%27%C3%A9ducation" title="fr:École supérieure du professorat et de l'éducation">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       (ESPE), the House of Languages, the House of Research and the University Library in 2015.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Jardin_des_plantes_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Jardin des plantes d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
        Jardin des plantes
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jardin_des_plantes_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Jardin des plantes d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , known as the
       <i>
        Jardin du Roy
       </i>
       within the city, is also located in this quarter.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ami1b.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1704" data-file-width="2272" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Ami1b.JPG/220px-Ami1b.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Ami1b.JPG/330px-Ami1b.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Ami1b.JPG/440px-Ami1b.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ami1b.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/River_Somme" title="River Somme">
          River Somme
         </a>
         from the Boulevard de Beauvillé
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Henriville_quarter">
        Henriville quarter
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Henriville quarter">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       The Henriville neighbourhood was mostly built during the 19th century after the demolition of the city wall. It lies at the south of the town centre. It has numerous
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bourgeois" title="Bourgeois">
        bourgeois
       </a>
       houses and
       <a href="/wiki/Townhouse" title="Townhouse">
        townhouses
       </a>
       , predominantly in brick, blending architectural styles of the period, including
       <a href="/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture" title="Neoclassical architecture">
        neoclassical
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Troubadour_style#Architecture" title="Troubadour style">
        troubadour
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Gothic_Revival_architecture" title="Gothic Revival architecture">
        neo-Gothic
       </a>
       . There are also private mansions, such as the Acloque mansion and the house of
       <a href="/wiki/Jules_Verne" title="Jules Verne">
        Jules Verne
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Saint-Acheul_quarter">
        Saint-Acheul quarter
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Saint-Acheul quarter">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       The Saint-Acheul quarter (
       <small>
        IPA:
       </small>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/French" title="Help:IPA/French">
         [aʃoel]
        </a>
       </span>
       ) existed before Amiens, as people have lived there since prehistoric times. This is where archaeological excavations in the nineteenth century discovered prehistoric tool sets typical of the "
       <a href="/wiki/Acheulean" title="Acheulean">
        Acheulean
       </a>
       " prehistorical era, named after this neighbourhood (also spelled Acheulian, pronounced
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/French" title="Help:IPA/French">
         [əˈʃuːliən]
        </a>
       </span>
       ). An archaeological garden can be freely visited there.
      </p>
      <p>
       Not to be confused with the
       <a href="/wiki/Commune" title="Commune">
        commune
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Saint-Acheul" title="Saint-Acheul">
        Saint-Acheul
       </a>
       situated 37 km (23 mi) to the north, the quarter of Saint-Acheul is the site of a military cemetery from the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_World_War" title="First World War">
        First World War
       </a>
       (1914–1918).
      </p>
      <p>
       It also contains the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abbaye_de_Saint-Acheul" title="Abbaye de Saint-Acheul">
        Church of Saint-Acheul
       </a>
       , and the former
       <a href="/wiki/Normal_school" title="Normal school">
        normal school
       </a>
       of teachers which became the Lycée Robert-de-Luzarches. A number of famous people are buried in the former Saint-Acheul cemetery such as J.-P. Pinchon (creator of
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/B%C3%A9cassine" title="Bécassine">
         Bécassine
        </a>
       </i>
       ) and many resistance fighters. Part of the quarter includes a so-called "English neighbourhood," with typical English style houses. At the feet of this area lie the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Hortillonnages&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Hortillonnages (page does not exist)">
        hortillonnages
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hortillonnages_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Hortillonnages d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , a marshy area criss-crossed by canals.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Other_neighbourhoods">
        Other neighbourhoods
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Other neighbourhoods">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Amiens, like other big cities, has its large
       <a href="/wiki/HLM" title="HLM">
        HLM
       </a>
       high-rise tower blocks:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        North of the city the quarters
        <i>
         du
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Pigeonnier&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Pigeonnier (page does not exist)">
          Pigeonnier
         </a>
        </i>
        , which is famous for its weekend market,
        <i>
         Messenger
        </i>
        ,
        <i>
         Mozart
        </i>
        ,
        <i>
         Fafet-Brossolette-la Cité
        </i>
        ,
        <i>
         Balzac
        </i>
        ,
        <i>
         Léo Lagrange-Schweitzer
        </i>
        , etc.;
       </li>
       <li>
        Southeast of the city:
        <i>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Victorine-Autier&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Victorine-Autier (page does not exist)">
          Victorine-Autier
         </a>
        </i>
        ,
        <i>
         Philéas Lebesgue
        </i>
        ,
        <i>
         Condorcet
        </i>
        ,
        <i>
         Pierre-Rollin
        </i>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        West:
        <i>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Etouvie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Etouvie (page does not exist)">
          Etouvie
         </a>
        </i>
        and
        <i>
         Montieres
        </i>
        (an
        <a href="/wiki/Ecodistrict" title="Ecodistrict">
         ecodistrict
        </a>
        is provided in this industrial space, where there are buildings of the 19th century, in brick).
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18">
         <a href="#cite_note-18">
          [17]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        East:
        <i>
         Saint-Acheul-la-Cité
        </i>
        and the
        <i>
         Clos de l'Avre
        </i>
        .
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       These areas experience a lot of social troubles and have regularly been the place for riots. The northern quarters were the scene of violent events in 1994, 1999 and 2000 (clashes between several districts of the city and between the neighbourhoods of Amiens and the districts of
       <a href="/wiki/Creil" title="Creil">
        Creil
       </a>
       ), in 2006 and 2008 (in the wake of incidents in the Paris suburbs)
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       and more recently in August 2012 following a conflict between youth and the police. The cost of the latest vandalism to occur in the north of Amiens would amount, according to
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Gilles_Demailly&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Gilles Demailly (page does not exist)">
        Gilles Demailly
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gilles_Demailly" title="fr:Gilles Demailly">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , to between four and six million euros. These extremely violent riots caused sixteen police officers to be injured.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19">
        <a href="#cite_note-19">
         [18]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       An extensive programme of redevelopment of these neighborhoods began recently, demolished HLM tower blocks and new infrastructure have been built, especially for schools. In 2009, the public transport network of the Amiens agglomeration was significantly modified.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Housing">
        Housing
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Housing">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Amiens_rue_du_Don.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3168" data-file-width="4866" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Amiens_rue_du_Don.jpg/220px-Amiens_rue_du_Don.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Amiens_rue_du_Don.jpg/330px-Amiens_rue_du_Don.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Amiens_rue_du_Don.jpg/440px-Amiens_rue_du_Don.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Amiens_rue_du_Don.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Houses in the Saint-Leu quarter.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 2009, the total number of dwellings in the municipality was 68,145, while it was 63,201 in 1999.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
        <a href="#cite_note-20">
         [Insee 1]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Among this housing, 91.7% were primary residences, 1.0% of secondary residences and 7.4% vacant housing. These dwellings were 38.7% of detached houses and 60.2% of apartments.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LOG_T2_21-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-LOG_T2-21">
         [Insee 2]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The proportion of principal residences, which were the properties of occupants, was 34.0%, down from 1999 (35.3%). The share of empty rented
       <a href="/wiki/HLM" title="HLM">
        HLM
       </a>
       homes (social housing) was also down: 29.0% against 32.5% in 1999, their number decreased from 18,692 to 18,103. However, this percentage remains much greater than the rate of 20% required by the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Loi_relative_%C3%A0_la_solidarit%C3%A9_et_au_renouvellement_urbains&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Loi relative à la solidarité et au renouvellement urbains (page does not exist)">
        law on solidarity and urban renewal
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loi_relative_%C3%A0_la_solidarit%C3%A9_et_au_renouvellement_urbains" title="fr:Loi relative à la solidarité et au renouvellement urbains">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       (SRU) for cities and agglomerations of more than 50,000 inhabitants.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
        <a href="#cite_note-22">
         [Insee 3]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The identity of the city is strongly marked by the specificity of its housing stock consisting in a large proportion of detached houses, semi-detached, single or bourgeois: the
       <i>
        amiénoises
       </i>
       . These traditional houses in the suburbs, in brick and floor(s), were intrinsically linked to the expansion of the city during and after the
       <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">
        Industrial Revolution
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <i>
        amiénoise simple
       </i>
       includes a window on the ground floor and floors for attic and basement. It is built on a plot of a few metres wide but is very deep, and includes a garden, forming hearts with green islets and sparse areas. The
       <i>
        amiénoise double
       </i>
       has two windows at each level. The
       <i>
        grandes amiénoises
       </i>
       and townhouses rise to at least two floors with large rooms. They can have a gate opening onto a paved courtyard.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23">
        <a href="#cite_note-23">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The official buildings or mansions regularly use
       <a href="/wiki/Brick" title="Brick">
        brick
       </a>
       façades on a sandstone base, decorated by stone window and door frames.
      </p>
      <p>
       The Chanoines quarter has stone façades exclusively.
      </p>
      <p>
       In historic areas such as the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Saint-Leu_(Amiens)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Saint-Leu (Amiens) (page does not exist)">
        Saint-Leu
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saint-Leu_(Amiens)" title="fr:Saint-Leu (Amiens)">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       quarter, façades widely use wood,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Half-timbered" title="Half-timbered">
        half-timbered
       </a>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/Siding" title="Siding">
        siding
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Wattle_and_daub" title="Wattle and daub">
        wattle and daub
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Development_projects">
        Development projects
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Development projects">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <ul>
       <li>
        Amiens 2030: Amiens, in the context of the
        <a href="/wiki/Communaut%C3%A9_d%27agglom%C3%A9ration_Amiens_M%C3%A9tropole" title="Communauté d'agglomération Amiens Métropole">
         Communauté d'agglomération Amiens Métropole
        </a>
        , is developing a master plan of development called Amiens 2030.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
         <a href="#cite_note-24">
          [20]
         </a>
        </sup>
        This strategic outreach project shapes around priority issues of economic, social and cultural development of the agglomeration. The whole process of reflection will determine the development of the metropolis by the 2030.
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Citadelle_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Citadelle d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
         La Citadelle
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citadelle_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Citadelle d'Amiens">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        : This flagship project for the agglomeration involves the amalgamation of units of training and research from the
        <a href="/wiki/University_of_Picardie_Jules_Verne" title="University of Picardie Jules Verne">
         University of Picardie
        </a>
        in letters, languages, history, geography, philosophy, sociology, psychology and the
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%89cole_sup%C3%A9rieure_du_professorat_et_de_l%27%C3%A9ducation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="École supérieure du professorat et de l'éducation (page does not exist)">
         College teaching and education
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89cole_sup%C3%A9rieure_du_professorat_et_de_l%27%C3%A9ducation" title="fr:École supérieure du professorat et de l'éducation">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        (ESPE) on the site of La Citadelle; set of 18 acres (7.3 ha) on the outskirts of downtown. This university construction programme should strengthen regional competitiveness and the development of higher education and research. The project, entrusted to the Italian architect
        <a href="/wiki/Renzo_Piano" title="Renzo Piano">
         Renzo Piano
        </a>
        , provides an opening of the campus on the city and will be accessible to all its inhabitants.
       </li>
       <li>
        ZAC Gare-la-Vallée: The project must strengthen Amiens in his role as regional capital and allow the creation of a genuine business district in the heart of the city. With a budget of €157 million, the project combines tertiary activities, shops and habitat walk from the
        <a href="/wiki/Gare_d%27Amiens" title="Gare d'Amiens">
         station
        </a>
        and the inner city. The first buildings were inaugurated in 2008. A second phase of development extends from 2012 to 2017. Under the control of the Chief Architect,
        <a href="/wiki/Paul_Chemetov" title="Paul Chemetov">
         Paul Chemetov
        </a>
        , the quarter must especially accommodate 2,000 homes, 200,000 square metres (2,200,000 sq ft) of offices and two urban parks creating a visible link between downtown, the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/River_Somme" title="River Somme">
         Somme
        </a>
        and the
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Hortillonnages_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Hortillonnages d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
         Hortillonnages
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hortillonnages_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Hortillonnages d'Amiens">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
         <a href="#cite_note-25">
          [21]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        ZAC Intercampus: This new housing and services quarter in the south of the city is to host 1,900 housing by 2030.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">
         <a href="#cite_note-26">
          [22]
         </a>
        </sup>
        A first tranche of 850 dwellings must be delivered in 2015. Located in the immediate vicinity of the campus and the CHU d'Amiens, it will be served by a future
        <a href="/wiki/Bus_lane" title="Bus lane">
         TCSP
        </a>
        . The
        <a href="/wiki/Ecodistrict" title="Ecodistrict">
         ecodistrict
        </a>
        of 80 hectares (200 acres) must provide beautiful green spaces and gardens (60% of its total area will be not be built). It will include 12 hectares (30 acres) of gardens.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27">
         <a href="#cite_note-27">
          [23]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        ZAC Paul Claudel: This new housing and services quarter of 40 hectares (99 acres) is located at the southern entrance to the city. Intended as a small neighbourhood, it must accommodate 1,400 units and 1,800 square metres (19,000 sq ft) of commercial space. Designed in 4 slices, together with its inhabitants, it entered the final phase of development in 2013.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
         <a href="#cite_note-28">
          [24]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        ZAC Renancourt: This new quarter must ensure the development of the city to the west. Located between the Grâce Valley, the Selle Valley, the Renancourt quarter and its suburb, this planning area is a natural viewpoint over the city. It is also adjacent to emblematic facilities of the city: The
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Z%C3%A9nith_d%27Amiens" title="Zénith d'Amiens">
         Zenith of Amiens
        </a>
        , the
        <a href="/wiki/Stade_de_la_Licorne" title="Stade de la Licorne">
         Stade de la Licorne
        </a>
        and the
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=M%C3%A9gacit%C3%A9_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Mégacité d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
         megacity
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/M%C3%A9gacit%C3%A9_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Mégacité d'Amiens">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        . By 2018, this residential area must accommodate 1,400 houses but also a hotel, facilities and shops.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29">
         <a href="#cite_note-29">
          [25]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Bus_rapid_transit" title="Bus rapid transit">
         Bus rapid transit
        </a>
        (BRT): A project of three BRT lines is under consideration for commissioning in 2019, at the end of two years of work. Estimated at €85 million excluding taxes for 44 kilometres (27 mi), the project would include the construction of a new bus depot and four
        <a href="/wiki/Park_and_ride" title="Park and ride">
         park and ride
        </a>
        stops.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30">
         <a href="#cite_note-30">
          [26]
         </a>
        </sup>
        This project follows the cancellation of a tram project, which was endorsed by the municipal team in place between 2008 and 2014.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Toponymy">
        Toponymy
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Toponymy">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Toponym" title="Toponym">
        toponym
       </a>
       is derived from the name of the local Gallic people, the
       <a href="/wiki/Ambiani" title="Ambiani">
        Ambiani
       </a>
       , which was replaced in the 4th century to the old name of the town
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samarobriva" title="Samarobriva">
        Samarobriva
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samarobriva" title="fr:Samarobriva">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       (the bridge on the Samara - Somme). Amiens then became the
       <a href="/wiki/Bishop" title="Bishop">
        episcopal
       </a>
       headquarters.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nompic_31-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-nompic-31">
         [27]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In
       <a href="/wiki/Picard_language" title="Picard language">
        Picard
       </a>
       , Amiens is called
       <i>
        Anmyen
       </i>
       .
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Politics_and_administration">
        Politics and administration
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Politics and administration">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Political_trends_and_results">
        Political trends and results
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Political trends and results">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article: [[:
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Municipal_elections_in_Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Municipal elections in Amiens (page does not exist)">
        Municipal elections in Amiens
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89lections_municipales_%C3%A0_Amiens" title="fr:Élections municipales à Amiens">

        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ]]
      </div>

      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Municipal_administration">
        Municipal administration
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Municipal administration">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The number of inhabitants at the last census being between 100,000 and 149,999, the
       <a href="/wiki/Municipal_elections_in_France#Number_and_Election_of_Municipal_Councilors" title="Municipal elections in France">
        number of members of the municipal council
       </a>
       is 55.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32">
        <a href="#cite_note-32">
         [28]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       As a result of the
       <a href="/wiki/French_municipal_elections,_2014" title="French municipal elections, 2014">
        French municipal elections of 2014
       </a>
       , the distribution of seats is as follows:
      </p>
      <table class="toccolours" style="margin:auto; text-align:center;">
       <caption>
        <b>
         Municipal council of Amiens
        </b>
        (2014-2020)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
         <a href="#cite_note-33">
          [29]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </caption>
       <tr>
        <th>
         List
        </th>
        <th>
         Party
        </th>

         Status
        </th>
       </tr>

      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="The_cantons">
        The cantons
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: The cantons">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Cantons_of_the_Somme_department" title="Cantons of the Somme department">
        Cantons of the Somme department
       </a>
       and [[:
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=2015_departmental_elections_in_Somme&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="2015 departmental elections in Somme (page does not exist)">
        2015 departmental elections in Somme
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89lections_d%C3%A9partementales_de_2015_dans_la_Somme" title="fr:Élections départementales de 2015 dans la Somme">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ]]
      </div>
      <p>
       Amiens is divided into seven
       <a href="/wiki/Cantons_of_the_Somme_department" title="Cantons of the Somme department">
        cantons
       </a>
       :
      </p>
      <table cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" rules="all" style="margin:auto; border:1px solid #999;">
