      <h5>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Digital_terrestrial_radio_stations">
        Digital terrestrial radio stations
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=48" title="Edit section: Digital terrestrial radio stations">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h5>
      <p>
       As of 1 March 2015, the
       <a href="/wiki/Conseil_sup%C3%A9rieur_de_l%27audiovisuel" title="Conseil supérieur de l'audiovisuel">
        CSA
       </a>
       has not selected Amiens for broadcast or experimentation of this broadcasting standard.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Telecommunications">
        Telecommunications
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=49" title="Edit section: Telecommunications">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       The city of Amiens is covered with:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Coaxial_cable" title="Coaxial cable">
         Cable
        </a>
        by
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=CityPlay&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="CityPlay (page does not exist)">
         Wibox/Cityplay
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/CityPlay" title="fr:CityPlay">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        since 2002.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67">
         <a href="#cite_note-67">
          [60]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Optical_fiber" title="Optical fiber">
         Fibre optic
        </a>
        by
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=CityPlay&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="CityPlay (page does not exist)">
         Wibox/Cityplay
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/CityPlay" title="fr:CityPlay">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        since 2007
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68">
         <a href="#cite_note-68">
          [61]
         </a>
        </sup>
        and by
        <a href="/wiki/Orange_S.A." title="Orange S.A.">
         Orange
        </a>
        since 2013.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69">
         <a href="#cite_note-69">
          [62]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Asymmetric_digital_subscriber_line" title="Asymmetric digital subscriber line">
         ADSL
        </a>
        , with five telephone exchanges, the majority of which are unbundled, by
        <a href="/wiki/SFR" title="SFR">
         SFR
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Free_(ISP)" title="Free (ISP)">
         Free
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Bouygues_Telecom" title="Bouygues Telecom">
         Bouygues Telecom
        </a>
        and
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Completel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Completel (page does not exist)">
         Completel
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Completel" title="fr:Completel">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70">
         <a href="#cite_note-70">
          [63]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Worship">
        Worship
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=50" title="Edit section: Worship">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Buddhist_worship">
        Buddhist worship
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=51" title="Edit section: Buddhist worship">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       The Zen
       <a href="/wiki/S%C5%8Dt%C5%8D" title="Sōtō">
        Sōtō
       </a>
       Zen centre affiliated with the international Zen Association, on
       <i>
        Rue Vulfran Warmé
       </i>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Catholic_worship">
        Catholic worship
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=52" title="Edit section: Catholic worship">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Amiens_Cathedral" title="Amiens Cathedral">
         Notre-Dame Cathedral
        </a>
        ,
        <i>
         Place Notre-Dame
        </i>
       </li>
       <li>
        Chapelle du Bon Pasteur (first of the name): Situated on
        <i>
         Rue Daire
        </i>
        , it belonged to the
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Conseil_d%C3%A9partemental_de_la_Somme&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Conseil départemental de la Somme (page does not exist)">
         Conseil général de la Somme
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conseil_d%C3%A9partemental_de_la_Somme" title="fr:Conseil départemental de la Somme">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        . Leased to the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Society_of_St._Pius_X" title="Society of St. Pius X">
         Society of St. Pius X
        </a>
        from 1983 to 2007, it was sold, with the property complex to which it belonged, to Picardy in May 2007.
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Chapelle_Saint-Vincent-de-Paul_(Amiens)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Chapelle Saint-Vincent-de-Paul (Amiens) (page does not exist)">
         Chapelle
         <i>
          Saint-Vincent-de-Paul
         </i>
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chapelle_Saint-Vincent-de-Paul_(Amiens)" title="fr:Chapelle Saint-Vincent-de-Paul (Amiens)">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        , situated on
        <i>
         Rue Jules Barni
        </i>
        , the offices are run by the Society of St. Pius X according to the
        <a href="/wiki/Tridentine_Mass" title="Tridentine Mass">
         Tridentine Mass
        </a>
        (an
        <i>
         extraordinary form the Roman rite
        </i>
        ).
       </li>
       <li>
        The church of Saint Honoré known as the
        <i>
         église de Beauvais
        </i>
        ,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71">
         <a href="#cite_note-71">
          [64]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <i>
         Rue Dom Bouquet
        </i>
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abbaye_de_Saint-Acheul" title="Abbaye de Saint-Acheul">
         church of Saint-Acheul
        </a>
        ,
        <i>
         Chaussée Jules Ferry
        </i>
       </li>
       <li>
        The church of Saint-Firmin-le-Martyr, 137
        <i>
         Rue du Faubourg du Hem
        </i>
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%89glise_Saint-Germain-l%27%C3%89cossais_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Église Saint-Germain-l'Écossais d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
         church of Saint-Germain-l'Écossais
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89glise_Saint-Germain-l%27%C3%89cossais_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Église Saint-Germain-l'Écossais d'Amiens">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        ,
        <i>
         Rue Pingre
        </i>
       </li>
       <li>
        The church of Sacré-Cœur,
        <i>
         Rue de Mareuil
        </i>
       </li>
       <li>
        The church of Saint-Jacques, 'Rue Saint-Jacques
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%89glise_Saint-Leu_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Église Saint-Leu d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
         church of Saint-Leu
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89glise_Saint-Leu_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Église Saint-Leu d'Amiens">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        ,
        <i>
         Rue Saint-Leu
        </i>
       </li>
       <li>
        The church of Saint-Martin,
        <i>
         Rue Morgan
        </i>
       </li>
       <li>
        The church of Saint-Maurice,
        <i>
         Rue Turgot
        </i>
       </li>
       <li>
        The church of Saint-Pierre,
        <i>
         Rue St Pierre
        </i>
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%89glise_Saint-R%C3%A9mi_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Église Saint-Rémi d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
         church of Saint-Rémi
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89glise_Saint-R%C3%A9mi_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Église Saint-Rémi d'Amiens">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        ,
        <i>
         Rue des Cordeliers
        </i>
       </li>
       <li>
        The church of Saint-Roch,
        <i>
         Rue de l'Abbaye
        </i>
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%89glise_Sainte-Anne_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Église Sainte-Anne d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
         church of Sainte-Anne
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89glise_Sainte-Anne_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Église Sainte-Anne d'Amiens">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        ,
        <i>
         Rue Vulfran Warmé
        </i>

        The church of Sainte-Jeanne-d'Arc,
        <i>

        </i>

        <i>

        </i>

        The church of Sainte-Marie-Madeleine in the Renancourt quarter

        <i>
         Rue de Cagny
        </i>

      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Jewish_worship">
        Jewish worship
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=53" title="Edit section: Jewish worship">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       The synagogue is located at 12
       <i>
        Rue du Port d'Amont
       </i>
       , near Pont-Beauville.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Mormon_worship">
        Mormon worship
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=54" title="Edit section: Mormon worship">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints" title="The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints">
        The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
       </a>
       has a place of worship on the Doullens road.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Muslim_worship">
        Muslim worship
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=55" title="Edit section: Muslim worship">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       The city of Amiens concentrates the largest Muslim community of
       <a href="/wiki/Picardy" title="Picardy">
        Picardy
       </a>
       and one of the largest in the north of the France. Places of worship are evolving, several mosques are in phase of expansion or relocation. Thus the city has fifteen Muslim places of worship: Eight independent prayer rooms and seven mosques:
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72">
        <a href="#cite_note-72">
         [65]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The An-Nour mosque where sits the Institute of the Arab-Muslim world of Picardy in
        <i>
         Rue de la Hotoie
        </i>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        The Al-Fath mosque (currently moving premises), also the Association of Worship and Culture of Muslims in Picardy located at 375
        <i>
         Boulevard Beauvillé
        </i>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        The Al Badr mosque, also the Association of workers and Moroccan traders of Amiens, located at 33
        <i>
         Rue Winston-Churchill
        </i>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        The Masjid Al Muhsinin mosque located on the
        <i>
         Rue de l'île-de-France
        </i>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        The Sounnahs mosque located
        <i>
         Rue Victorine-Autier
        </i>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        The Chekkar mosque, also Association of the Committee of the Briqueterie located at 40
        <i>
         Rue Ronsard
        </i>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        The Mosque of the "19" is located at 19
        <i>
         Avenue de l'Europe
        </i>
        and is home to the Association of Muslims in Picardy.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       Several independent prayer rooms are present in the urban community. On the other hand, Muslim committees and associations exist in the image of the Islamic Cultural Centre of Amiens in the
       <i>
        Rue de Savoie
       </i>
       , the Muslim Cultural Freedom Association - Institute of Enlightenment and also the Association of residents of the home at 21
       <i>
        Route d'Allonville
       </i>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Protestant_worship">
        Protestant worship
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=56" title="Edit section: Protestant worship">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       The temple is adjacent to the Church of
       <i>
        Saint-Jacques
       </i>
       .
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">
        Economy
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=57" title="Edit section: Economy">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>
       Both industrial hub and services centre, Amiens enjoys a large pool of workers, a labour pool of over 350,000 inhabitants and many professional training courses.
      </p>
      <p>
       Proof of dynamism, the magazine
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=L%27Entreprise_(magazine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="L'Entreprise (magazine) (page does not exist)">
        <i>
         L'Entreprise
        </i>
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/L%27Entreprise_(magazine)" title="fr:L'Entreprise (magazine)">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       elected Amiens "Most attractive city of France" for businesses (category less than 200,000 inhabitants) in 2009 and 2007. The city finished second in 2010, 2008 and 2006. The strengths of the city include a developed real estate business and taxation around the average for French cities. In addition, its geographical position square in the centre of the triangle "Paris - London - Brussels", that is at the heart of the richest Europe.
      </p>
      <p>
       The magazine
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Challenges_(magazine)" title="Challenges (magazine)">
         Challenges
        </a>
       </i>
       has also designated Amiens as "Best managed city of France" (category large cities with more than 100,000 inhabitants) in 2011, 2010 and 2008.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Income_of_the_population_and_taxation">
        Income of the population and taxation
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=58" title="Edit section: Income of the population and taxation">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       In 2010, the median taxable household income was €22,539, which placed Amiens at 177th place among the 31,525 communes with more than 39 households in metropolitan France.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
        <a href="#cite_note-73">
         [66]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2009, the proportion of taxable households was 48.1%.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
        <a href="#cite_note-74">
         [Insee 5]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Employment">
        Employment
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=59" title="Edit section: Employment">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       In 2009, the population aged 15 to 64 years amounted to 93,256 persons, among which there were 66.5% of assets including 54.9% having a job and 11.6 per cent of unemployed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
        <a href="#cite_note-75">
         [Insee 6]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       There were 81,405 jobs in the employment area, against 72,058 in 1999. The number of assets employed residing in the area of employment being 51,539, the concentration of job indicator
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">
        <a href="#cite_note-76">
         [note 4]
        </a>
       </sup>
       is 158.0%, which means that the employment area offers three jobs for every two active inhabitants.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
        <a href="#cite_note-77">
         [Insee 7]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <center>
       <p>
        <b>
         Distribution of employment
        </b>
        <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
         [
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers">
           <span title="The time period mentioned near this tag is ambiguous. (June 2015)">
            when?
           </span>
          </a>
         </i>
         ]
        </sup>
       </p>
       <table class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%; width:90%; border:0; text-align:center; line-height:120%;">
        <tr>
         <th style="background:#f5f5f5; color:#000; width:100px;">
         </th>
         <th style="background:#f5f5f5; color:#000;">
          <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Tertiary sector of the economy">
           Tertiary sector
          </a>
         </th>
         <th style="background:#f5f5f5; color:#000;">
          <a href="/wiki/Industry" title="Industry">
           Industry
          </a>
         </th>
         <th style="background:#f5f5f5; color:#000;">
          <a href="/wiki/Construction" title="Construction">
           Construction
          </a>
         </th>
         <th style="background:#f5f5f5; color:#000;">
          <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">
           Agriculture
          </a>
         </th>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th style="background:#f5f5f5; color:#000;">
          Amiens
         </th>
         <td style="background:#d1e8ff; color:#000;">
          79.3%
         </td>
         <td style="background:#d1e8ff; color:#000;">
          17.4%
         </td>
         <td style="background:#d1e8ff; color:#000;">
          3.0%
         </td>
         <td style="background:#d1e8ff; color:#000;">
          0.2%
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th style="background:#f5f5f5; color:#000;">
          National average
         </th>
         <td style="background: #F5F5F5; color: black;">
          71.5%
         </td>
         <td style="background: #F5F5F5; color: black;">
          18.3%
         </td>
         <td style="background: #F5F5F5; color: black;">
          6.1%
         </td>
         <td style="background: #F5F5F5; color: black;">
          4.1%
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td colspan="5" style="text-align:center;font-size:90%;">
          Source: Insee
          <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
           [
           <i>
            <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
             <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2015)">
              citation needed
             </span>
            </a>
           </i>
           ]
          </sup>
         </td>
        </tr>
       </table>
      </center>
      <p>
       Agriculture has very little representation among Amiens jobs with only 0.2%, just as the construction sector which represents 3.0% of jobs. Unlike these two sectors whose share is below the national average, the tertiary sector represents a significant part of the Amiens workforce, 19.8%, and is more important than at the national level. Industry includes 17.4% of jobs.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Goodyear_Tire_and_Rubber_Company" title="Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company">
        Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company
       </a>
       announced more than 400
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Unemployment_in_France&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Unemployment in France (page does not exist)">
        job cuts
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ch%C3%B4mage_en_France" title="fr:Chômage en France">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       in May 2008 at the Amiens plant, which has had 1,450 employees; in March 2009, the management announced new
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Plan_of_safeguarding_of_employment&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Plan of safeguarding of employment (page does not exist)">
        collective redundancies
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plan_de_sauvegarde_de_l%27emploi" title="fr:Plan de sauvegarde de l'emploi">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       of a thousand jobs.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
        <a href="#cite_note-78">
         [67]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Businesses_and_shops">
        Businesses and shops
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=60" title="Edit section: Businesses and shops">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chambre_R%C3%A9gionale_de_Commerce_et_d%27Industrie_de_Picardie,_Amiens,_2012._Chartier-Corbasson_architectes..jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="549" data-file-width="591" height="204" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Chambre_R%C3%A9gionale_de_Commerce_et_d%27Industrie_de_Picardie%2C_Amiens%2C_2012._Chartier-Corbasson_architectes..jpg/220px-Chambre_R%C3%A9gionale_de_Commerce_et_d%27Industrie_de_Picardie%2C_Amiens%2C_2012._Chartier-Corbasson_architectes..jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Chambre_R%C3%A9gionale_de_Commerce_et_d%27Industrie_de_Picardie%2C_Amiens%2C_2012._Chartier-Corbasson_architectes..jpg/330px-Chambre_R%C3%A9gionale_de_Commerce_et_d%27Industrie_de_Picardie%2C_Amiens%2C_2012._Chartier-Corbasson_architectes..jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Chambre_R%C3%A9gionale_de_Commerce_et_d%27Industrie_de_Picardie%2C_Amiens%2C_2012._Chartier-Corbasson_architectes..jpg/440px-Chambre_R%C3%A9gionale_de_Commerce_et_d%27Industrie_de_Picardie%2C_Amiens%2C_2012._Chartier-Corbasson_architectes..jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Chambre_R%C3%A9gionale_de_Commerce_et_d%27Industrie_de_Picardie,_Amiens,_2012._Chartier-Corbasson_architectes..jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Chamber_of_commerce_and_industry_of_Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Chamber of commerce and industry of Amiens (page does not exist)">
          Chamber of commerce and industry of Amiens
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chambre_de_commerce_et_d%27industrie_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Chambre de commerce et d'industrie d'Amiens">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         and
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Chartier-Corbasson_architectes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Chartier-Corbasson architectes (page does not exist)">
          Chartier-Corbasson architectes
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chartier-Corbasson_architectes" title="fr:Chartier-Corbasson architectes">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         , in 2012
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       On 31 December 2010, at Amiens, there were 9,166 businesses: 69 in agriculture, forestry and fisheries, 402 in industry, 533 in construction, 6,111 in trade, transportation and various services and 2,051 were related to the administrative sector.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CEN_T1_79-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CEN_T1-79">
         [Insee 8]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2011, 743 companies were established at Amiens,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
        <a href="#cite_note-80">
         [Insee 9]
        </a>
       </sup>
       including 417 by of
       <a href="/wiki/Sole_proprietorship" title="Sole proprietorship">
        sole proprietors
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">
        <a href="#cite_note-81">
         [Insee 10]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Philately" title="Philately">
        Philatelic
       </a>
       publishers
       <a href="/wiki/Yvert_et_Tellier" title="Yvert et Tellier">
        Yvert et Tellier
       </a>
       (catalogues of quotes) and
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/L%27%C3%89cho_de_la_timbrologie" title="L'Écho de la timbrologie">
         l'Écho de la timbrologie
        </a>
       </i>
       (magazine) have their management in Amiens, even if they have more of their services in the Paris region. The
       <a href="/wiki/Gueudet" title="Gueudet">
        Gueudet
       </a>
       Group, one of the largest car dealers in France, was established at Amiens in 1918. The old textile tradition of the city remains with the factory of
       <a href="/wiki/Lee_Cooper" title="Lee Cooper">
        Lee Cooper
       </a>
       France (122 employees).
      </p>
      <p>
       Since the end of
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
        World War II
       </a>
       , much of the city's economy was related to automotive equipment with companies such as
       <a href="/wiki/Valeo" title="Valeo">
        Valeo
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Goodyear_Tire_and_Rubber_Company" title="Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company">
        Goodyear
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Sumitomo_Group" title="Sumitomo Group">
        Sumitomo
       </a>
       -
       <a href="/wiki/Dunlop_Tyres" title="Dunlop Tyres">
        Dunlop
       </a>
       tyres. In 2003, Dunlop was bought by the American Goodyear company, these two companies through late 2007 and early 2008 had a deep crisis, the headquarters in the United States having "offered" to workers a change of their working hours and the number of posts, which was refused by the staff at a high percentage.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Procter_%26_Gamble" title="Procter &amp; Gamble">
        Procter &amp; Gamble
       </a>
       , settled at Amiens in 1964 to produce soap and inaugurated its new detergents unit in 1966. Established over more than 45 hectares (110 acres), it is one of the largest factories in the world for laundry cleaning products (
       <a href="/wiki/Ariel_(detergent)" title="Ariel (detergent)">
        Ariel
       </a>
       , Dash, Bonux, Gama) and for around the house (
       <a href="/wiki/Mr._Clean" title="Mr. Clean">
        Mr. Clean
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Febreze" title="Febreze">
        Febreze
       </a>
       ). More than 85% of its production is intended for export. The Amiens plant employs approximately 930 people.
      </p>
      <p>
       Since the mid-1990s, the city has tried to convert to the economy of the internet and telephony. Many
       <a href="/wiki/Call_centre" title="Call centre">
        call centres
       </a>
       (Intracall center, Coriolis France,
       <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A9diam%C3%A9trie" title="Médiamétrie">
        Médiamétrie
       </a>
       )
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
        <a href="#cite_note-82">
         [68]
        </a>
       </sup>
       have opened mainly within the city, region or state. The Unilog (now
       <a href="/wiki/Logica" title="Logica">
        Logica
       </a>
       ) computer service company has installed a service centre in Amiens (the CSA).
      </p>
      <p>
       Amiens is the seat of the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Regional_Chamber_of_commerce_and_industry_of_Picardy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Regional Chamber of commerce and industry of Picardy (page does not exist)">
        Regional Chamber of commerce and industry of Picardy
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chambre_r%C3%A9gionale_de_commerce_et_d%27industrie_de_Picardie" title="fr:Chambre régionale de commerce et d'industrie de Picardie">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       . It is also the seat of the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Chamber_of_commerce_and_industry_of_Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Chamber of commerce and industry of Amiens (page does not exist)">
        Chamber of commerce and industry of Amiens
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chambre_de_commerce_et_d%27industrie_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Chambre de commerce et d'industrie d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       . It manages the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amiens_-_Glisy_Aerodrome" title="Amiens - Glisy Aerodrome">
        Amiens - Glisy Aerodrome
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span id="Culture.2C_tourism_and_heritage">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Culture,_tourism_and_heritage">
        Culture, tourism and heritage
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=61" title="Edit section: Culture, tourism and heritage">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article: [[:
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_historic_monuments_of_Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="List of historic monuments of Amiens (page does not exist)">
        List of historic monuments of Amiens
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liste_des_monuments_historiques_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Liste des monuments historiques d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ]]
      </div>
      <p>
       The strategic position of Amiens makes it an attractive destination for a weekend or a few days, from
       <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">
        Paris
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lille" title="Lille">
        Lille
       </a>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/Brussels" title="Brussels">
        Brussels
       </a>
       . Amiens also benefits from the proximity of the
       <a href="/wiki/Baie_de_Somme" title="Baie de Somme">
        Baie de Somme
       </a>
       , a tourist hotspot registered at the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Club_des_plus_belles_baies_du_monde&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Club des plus belles baies du monde (page does not exist)">
        Club des plus belles baies du monde
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Club_des_plus_belles_baies_du_monde" title="fr:Club des plus belles baies du monde">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       and labelled
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Label_Grand_Site_de_France&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Label Grand Site de France (page does not exist)">
        Great Site of France
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Label_Grand_Site_de_France" title="fr:Label Grand Site de France">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Amiens has the label of
       <a href="/wiki/French_Towns_and_Lands_of_Art_and_History" title="French Towns and Lands of Art and History">
        Towns and Lands of Art and History
       </a>
       since 1992. Within this framework, the host of the heritage organises guided tours to themes intended for an audience of adults and children with educational workshops. A signposted circuit allows an independent tour of the town, with information panels offering comment on places and notable buildings.
      </p>
      <p>
       Amiens has an important historical and cultural heritage, an accessible and varied natural heritage, on which tourism is based. The main attractions are the cathedral, which is included in the world heritage of
       <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">
        UNESCO
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Hortillonnages_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Hortillonnages d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
        hortillonnages
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hortillonnages_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Hortillonnages d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Maison_de_Jules_Verne&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Maison de Jules Verne (page does not exist)">
        Jules Verne House
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maison_de_Jules_Verne" title="fr:Maison de Jules Verne">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Tour_Perret_(Amiens)" title="Tour Perret (Amiens)">
        Tour Perret
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_de_Picardie" title="Musée de Picardie">
        Musée de Picardie
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Zoo_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Zoo d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
        zoo
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zoo_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Zoo d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , and the quarters of Saint-Leu and Saint-Maurice.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Places_and_monuments">
        Places and monuments
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=62" title="Edit section: Places and monuments">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The commune has an exceptional heritage: 53 monuments listed in the
       <a href="/wiki/Monument_historique" title="Monument historique">
        inventory of monuments historiques
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">
        <a href="#cite_note-83">
         [69]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and 126 places and monuments listed in the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Inventaire_g%C3%A9n%C3%A9ral_du_patrimoine_culturel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Inventaire général du patrimoine culturel (page does not exist)">
        general inventory of cultural heritage
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inventaire_g%C3%A9n%C3%A9ral_du_patrimoine_culturel" title="fr:Inventaire général du patrimoine culturel">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ;
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
        <a href="#cite_note-84">
         [70]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and on the other hand, 263 objects listed in the inventory of monuments historiques
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
        <a href="#cite_note-85">
         [71]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and 122 objects listed in the general inventory of cultural heritage.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
        <a href="#cite_note-86">
         [72]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The information given below is relative only to a brief selection.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span id="Notre-Dame_d.27Amiens">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Notre-Dame_d'Amiens">
        Notre-Dame d'Amiens
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=63" title="Edit section: Notre-Dame d'Amiens">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Amiens_Cathedral" title="Amiens Cathedral">
        Amiens Cathedral
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cath%C3%A9drale_Notre-Dame_d%27Amiens-3420.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3420" data-file-width="3022" height="249" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Cath%C3%A9drale_Notre-Dame_d%27Amiens-3420.jpg/220px-Cath%C3%A9drale_Notre-Dame_d%27Amiens-3420.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Cath%C3%A9drale_Notre-Dame_d%27Amiens-3420.jpg/330px-Cath%C3%A9drale_Notre-Dame_d%27Amiens-3420.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Cath%C3%A9drale_Notre-Dame_d%27Amiens-3420.jpg/440px-Cath%C3%A9drale_Notre-Dame_d%27Amiens-3420.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cath%C3%A9drale_Notre-Dame_d%27Amiens-3420.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Façade of Notre-Dame Cathedral
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <table class="cquote pullquote" role="presentation" style="margin:auto; border-collapse: collapse; border: none; background-color: transparent; width: auto;">
       <tr>
        <td style="width: 20px; vertical-align: top; border: none; color: #B2B7F2; font-size: 40px; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: bold; line-height: .6em; text-align: left; padding: 10px 10px;">
         “
        </td>
        <td style="vertical-align: top; border: none; padding: 4px 10px;">
         It's a lovely woman, this Cathedral is a Virgin. ... Point of vain confusion, here, point of exaggeration or swelling. It is absolutely empirical of supreme elegance.
        </td>
        <td style="width: 20px; vertical-align: bottom; border: none; color: #B2B7F2; font-size: 40px; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: bold; line-height: .6em; text-align: right; padding: 10px 10px;">
         ”
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td class="cquotecite" colspan="3" style="border: none; padding-right: 4%; font-size: smaller; text-align: right;">
         <cite>
          —
          <a href="/wiki/Auguste_Rodin" title="Auguste Rodin">
           Auguste Rodin
          </a>
         </cite>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <table class="cquote pullquote" role="presentation" style="margin:auto; border-collapse: collapse; border: none; background-color: transparent; width: auto;">
       <tr>
        <td style="width: 20px; vertical-align: top; border: none; color: #B2B7F2; font-size: 40px; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: bold; line-height: .6em; text-align: left; padding: 10px 10px;">
         “
        </td>
        <td style="vertical-align: top; border: none; padding: 4px 10px;">
         Amiens Cathedral deserves the name given by
         <a href="/wiki/Eug%C3%A8ne_Viollet-le-Duc" title="Eugène Viollet-le-Duc">
          M. Viollet-le-Duc
         </a>
         , 'the
         <a href="/wiki/Parthenon" title="Parthenon">
          Parthenon
         </a>
         of Gothic architecture'.
        </td>
        <td style="width: 20px; vertical-align: bottom; border: none; color: #B2B7F2; font-size: 40px; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: bold; line-height: .6em; text-align: right; padding: 10px 10px;">
         ”
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td class="cquotecite" colspan="3" style="border: none; padding-right: 4%; font-size: smaller; text-align: right;">
         <cite>
          —
          <a href="/wiki/John_Ruskin" title="John Ruskin">
           John Ruskin
          </a>
          , The Bible of Amiens
         </cite>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       The city is famous for its Notre-Dame Cathedral, masterpiece of
       <a href="/wiki/Gothic_art" title="Gothic art">
        Gothic art
       </a>
       and the largest cathedral in the world by its interior volume (200,000 cubic metres (7,100,000 cu ft)).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87">
        <a href="#cite_note-87">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The largest religious and medieval building of France, its interior could twice hold
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Notre_Dame_de_Paris" title="Notre Dame de Paris">
        Notre Dame de Paris
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
        <a href="#cite_note-88">
         [74]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The cathedral measures 145 metres (476 ft) long and its spire rises 112 metres (367 ft) high. The vaults of the central
       <a href="/wiki/Nave" title="Nave">
        nave
       </a>
       , finished in 1247, are 42.3 metres (139 ft) (close to the maximum limit for this architecture).
      </p>
      <p>
       Dating back to the 13th century, its construction is due to the wealth of the city in the Middle Ages and the fire of the
       <a href="/wiki/Romanesque_art" title="Romanesque art">
        Romanesque
       </a>
       cathedral which stood previously. Three architects, including
       <a href="/wiki/Robert_of_Luzarches" title="Robert of Luzarches">
        Robert of Luzarches
       </a>
       succeeded to complete the construction.
      </p>
      <p>
       Amiens Cathedral is notable for the coherence of its plan, the beauty of its three-tier interior elevation, the particularly fine display of sculptures on the principal façade and in the south transept, and other inlays of its floor. It is also described by
       <a href="/wiki/John_Ruskin" title="John Ruskin">
        John Ruskin
       </a>
       as "Gothic, clear of Roman tradition and of Arabian taint, Gothic pure, authoritative, unsurpassable, and unaccusable."
      </p>
      <p>
       Regarded as the archetype of the classic
       <a href="/wiki/Gothic_architecture" title="Gothic architecture">
        Gothic
       </a>
       style, the cathedral also presents some elements of the radiant Gothic style and flamboyant Gothic. The speed of construction, barely 70 years for the shell (1220 to 1269), explains this remarkable homogeneity of style. Its façade is decorated with more 3,000 statues, gargoyles and chimeras.
      </p>
      <p>
       Registered since 1981 as a
       <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">
        World Heritage Site
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">
        UNESCO
       </a>
       as a "masterpiece of world heritage", it is a second time in 1998 as a monumental step on the
       <a href="/wiki/Camino_de_Santiago_(route_descriptions)" title="Camino de Santiago (route descriptions)">
        Camino de Santiago
       </a>
       . Despite the two World Wars of the 20th century, which severely affected the city, it managed to stay intact.
      </p>
      <p>
       A show of the reproduction of the original polychromy
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
        <a href="#cite_note-89">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
       of façades, discovered as a result of recent
       <a href="/wiki/Laser" title="Laser">
        laser
       </a>
       cleaning, is given annually for free in December and during the summer period. The show is a projection on the façade of slides in color.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Zodiaque_de_la_cath%C3%A9drale_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Zodiaque de la cathédrale d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
        zodiac
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zodiaque_de_la_cath%C3%A9drale_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Zodiaque de la cathédrale d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       is a set of reliefs on the foundations of the western façade formed series of quatrefoil medallions, carved in a representative agrarian calendar and the signs of the zodiac.
      </p>
      <p>
       The statue of the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=L%27Ange_pleureur&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="L'Ange pleureur (page does not exist)">
        weeping Angel
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/L%27Ange_pleureur" title="fr:L'Ange pleureur">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       (on a tomb carved by
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Nicolas_Blasset&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Nicolas Blasset (page does not exist)">
        Nicolas Blasset
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicolas_Blasset" title="fr:Nicolas Blasset">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ) and the reliefs evoking Saint-Firmin and St. John the Baptist are some of the well-known works of the Cathedral.
      </p>
      <p>
       At ground level lies the intact
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Labyrinthe_de_la_cath%C3%A9drale_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Labyrinthe de la cathédrale d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
        labyrinth
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labyrinthe_de_la_cath%C3%A9drale_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Labyrinthe de la cathédrale d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       of 234 metres (768 ft) long.
      </p>
      <p>
       On the north side of the cathedral is the former
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Palais_de_l%27%C3%A9v%C3%AAch%C3%A9_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Palais de l'évêché d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
        Palace of the Bishop of Amiens
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palais_de_l%27%C3%A9v%C3%AAch%C3%A9_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Palais de l'évêché d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , occupied by the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%89cole_sup%C3%A9rieure_de_commerce_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="École supérieure de commerce d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
        École supérieure de commerce
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89cole_sup%C3%A9rieure_de_commerce_d%27Amiens" title="fr:École supérieure de commerce d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       in Amiens.
      </p>
      <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 92px">

          </p>

           </a>
          </div>

          </p>
         </div>

          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 106px">
