           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           Tomb of Canon Lucas
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="The_belfry">
        The belfry
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=64" title="Edit section: The belfry">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Le_Beffroi_Amiens_FRA_001.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="2304" height="330" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Le_Beffroi_Amiens_FRA_001.jpg/220px-Le_Beffroi_Amiens_FRA_001.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Le_Beffroi_Amiens_FRA_001.jpg/330px-Le_Beffroi_Amiens_FRA_001.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Le_Beffroi_Amiens_FRA_001.jpg/440px-Le_Beffroi_Amiens_FRA_001.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Le_Beffroi_Amiens_FRA_001.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The belfry of Amiens
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article: [[:
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Belfry_of_Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Belfry of Amiens (page does not exist)">
        Belfry of Amiens
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beffroi_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Beffroi d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ]]
      </div>
      <p>
       Its origin dates back to the establishment of the commune of Amiens by
       <a href="/wiki/Louis_VI_of_France" title="Louis VI of France">
        Louis VI
       </a>
       . It is mentioned for the first time in an arbitral award issued by the chapter of Amiens in 1244.
      </p>
      <p>
       Symbolising the independence of the commune, it was formerly used for meetings of the notables of the city and then as archive rooms, weapons store and prison. A spotter nearby monitored arrivals and warned the population of the external dangers. During the Middle Ages, the building was repeatedly engulfed by fire.
      </p>
      <p>
       The belfry is composed of a base in white cut stone, built in the 15th century between 1406 and 1410, a stone superstructure bell tower built from 1749 with Baroque
       <a href="/wiki/Volute" title="Volute">
        volutes
       </a>
       at its base, and a dome covered with slate and then an arrow and a weather vane with a
       <a href="/wiki/Pheme" title="Pheme">
        renown
       </a>
       . At the time, a huge 11-ton bell was installed inside, it was later destroyed along with the dome (as a result of the melting of the copper component) in the bombardment and fire of the city on 19 May 1940. Abandoned and devoid of a roof since
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
        World War II
       </a>
       , the monument was fully restored between February 1989 and July 1990.
      </p>
      <p>
       Located on the
       <i>
        Place au Fil
       </i>
       , the old central square of the city before the arrival of the railway and the rise of the
       <i>
        Rue des Trois Calloux
       </i>
       , the belfry is adjacent to
       <i>
        Les Halles
       </i>
       and the back of the city hall.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
        <a href="#cite_note-90">
         [76]
        </a>
       </sup>
       At a height of 52 metres (171 ft), it rings every hour of the day.
      </p>
      <p>
       Since July 2005, the belfry of Amiens (recorded in the inventory of Historic Monuments) is, as
       <a href="/wiki/Amiens_Cathedral" title="Amiens Cathedral">
        Notre Dame Cathedral
       </a>
       , classed among the world heritage of
       <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">
        UNESCO
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cirque_Jules-Verne">
        Cirque Jules-Verne
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=65" title="Edit section: Cirque Jules-Verne">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article: [[:
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Cirque_Jules-Verne&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Cirque Jules-Verne (page does not exist)">
        Cirque Jules-Verne
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cirque_Jules-Verne" title="fr:Cirque Jules-Verne">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ]]
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cirque_Amiens_foule_d%C3%A9but_XXe.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="364" data-file-width="597" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Cirque_Amiens_foule_d%C3%A9but_XXe.jpg/220px-Cirque_Amiens_foule_d%C3%A9but_XXe.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Cirque_Amiens_foule_d%C3%A9but_XXe.jpg/330px-Cirque_Amiens_foule_d%C3%A9but_XXe.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Cirque_Amiens_foule_d%C3%A9but_XXe.jpg/440px-Cirque_Amiens_foule_d%C3%A9but_XXe.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cirque_Amiens_foule_d%C3%A9but_XXe.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The municipal circus of Amiens in 1912, on the festival of Saint Jean.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cirque_municipale_amiens.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Cirque_municipale_amiens.jpg/220px-Cirque_municipale_amiens.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Cirque_municipale_amiens.jpg/330px-Cirque_municipale_amiens.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Cirque_municipale_amiens.jpg/440px-Cirque_municipale_amiens.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cirque_municipale_amiens.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The municipal circus of Amiens in 2006.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 1845, the traditional fair of Saint-Jean, formerly held at
       <i>
        Place René Goblet
       </i>
       , was transferred to
       <i>
        Place Longueville
       </i>
       , a wide esplanade taking the place of the Longueville bastion since the demolition of the walls of the city in the early 19th century. Each year, a temporary circus was established on this occasion.
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1865, a circus company emerged to claim a permanent circus, which would be built in wood by the Schytte contractor in 1874. However, expensive maintenance prompted the municipality to consider the construction of a new building. The decision was taken in 1886 under the leadership of Mayor
       <a href="/wiki/Fr%C3%A9d%C3%A9ric_Petit_(19th-century_politician)" title="Frédéric Petit (19th-century politician)">
        Frédéric Petit
       </a>
       and the work began.
      </p>
      <p>
       The Chief Architect of the Somme,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%89mile_Ricquier&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Émile Ricquier (page does not exist)">
        Émile Ricquier
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89mile_Ricquier" title="fr:Émile Ricquier">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , a disciple of
       <a href="/wiki/Gustave_Eiffel" title="Gustave Eiffel">
        Gustave Eiffel
       </a>
       , was responsible for its construction. It was inspired by the
       <a href="/wiki/Cirque_d%27hiver" title="Cirque d'hiver">
        Cirque d'hiver
       </a>
       of Paris but chose a cast metal frame, supplemented by brick from the local countryside. The architect of civil buildings,
       <a href="/wiki/Charles_Garnier_(architect)" title="Charles Garnier (architect)">
        Charles Garnier
       </a>
       , claimed that the frames should be hidden with a plaster imitating stone. The "moderninst" design of Ricquier, who chose to display the structure, and to favour local material such as brick, is visible at the rear of the monument.
      </p>
      <p>
       With its 16-sided polygonal shape, with a diameter of 44 metres (144 ft), it includes lodges and
       <a href="/wiki/Choir_(architecture)#Seating" title="Choir (architecture)">
        stalls
       </a>
       in its enclosure. Modern, it hosts two steam engines dedicated fully electric lights and central heating. Since its construction, it has also been the first circus which included a buffet and a refreshment bar. The cost of the construction of the building finally reached double the forecast.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91">
        <a href="#cite_note-91">
         [77]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1888, the new city councillor responsible for festivals and celebrations, Jules Verne, was responsible for monitoring the work, and it was he who opened it on Sunday 23 June 1889, for the opening of the fair and the centenary of the French Revolution:
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92">
        <a href="#cite_note-92">
         [78]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <table class="cquote pullquote" role="presentation" style="margin:auto; border-collapse: collapse; border: none; background-color: transparent; width: auto;">
       <tr>
        <td style="width: 20px; vertical-align: top; border: none; color: #B2B7F2; font-size: 40px; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: bold; line-height: .6em; text-align: left; padding: 10px 10px;">
         “
        </td>
        <td style="vertical-align: top; border: none; padding: 4px 10px;">
         The new circus is a work of art that your municipal administration wanted to build with all of the enhancements of the modern industry. It is the most best, undoubtedly, it is also the most comprehensive with its facilities and equipment which have been built in France and abroad.
        </td>
        <td style="width: 20px; vertical-align: bottom; border: none; color: #B2B7F2; font-size: 40px; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: bold; line-height: .6em; text-align: right; padding: 10px 10px;">
         ”
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td class="cquotecite" colspan="3" style="border: none; padding-right: 4%; font-size: smaller; text-align: right;">
         <cite>
          —
          <a href="/wiki/Jules_Verne" title="Jules Verne">
           Jules Verne
          </a>
         </cite>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       The roof was damaged by a shell in 1916. The circus was the setting for
       <a href="/wiki/Federico_Fellini" title="Federico Fellini">
        Federico Fellini
       </a>
       's
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Clowns_(film)" title="The Clowns (film)">
         The Clowns
        </a>
       </i>
       (1971), and the film by
       <a href="/wiki/Jean-Jacques_Beineix" title="Jean-Jacques Beineix">
        Jean-Jacques Beineix
       </a>
       ,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Roselyne_et_les_lions" title="Roselyne et les lions">
         Roselyne et les lions
        </a>
       </i>
       (1989), with
       <a href="/wiki/Isabelle_Pasco" title="Isabelle Pasco">
        Isabelle Pasco
       </a>
       as lead actress. The largest of the circuses of the province with its 3,000-seats, the building has acquired a multidisciplinary use for decades of performances of theatre, dance, concerts, galas, sports and public meetings.
      </p>
      <p>
       Renovated in 2003, it now bears the name of Cirque Jules Verne. After hosting the performances of
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Cirque_Rancy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Cirque Rancy (page does not exist)">
        Cirque Rancy
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cirque_Rancy" title="fr:Cirque Rancy">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , it hosts resident
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Cirque_Arlette_Gruss&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Cirque Arlette Gruss (page does not exist)">
        Cirque Arlette Gruss
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cirque_Arlette_Gruss" title="fr:Cirque Arlette Gruss">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Since 1 January 2011, the circus has been labelled "national hub circus and street arts", managed by an
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%89tablissement_public_de_coop%C3%A9ration_culturelle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Établissement public de coopération culturelle (page does not exist)">
        EPCC
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89tablissement_public_de_coop%C3%A9ration_culturelle" title="fr:Établissement public de coopération culturelle">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       . It is one of seven in France and is still in use today.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">
        <a href="#cite_note-93">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="The_house_of_Jules-Verne">
        The house of Jules-Verne
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=66" title="Edit section: The house of Jules-Verne">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article: [[:
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Maison_de_Jules_Verne&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Maison de Jules Verne (page does not exist)">
        Maison de Jules Verne
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maison_de_Jules_Verne" title="fr:Maison de Jules Verne">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ]]
      </div>
      <p>
       In 1882, Jules Verne and his wife, Honorine, rented the house at the corner of
       <i>
        Rue Charles-Dubois
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        Boulevard Longueville
       </i>
       until 1900. Acquired in 1980 by the city, the house is labeled
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Maisons_des_Illustres&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Maisons des Illustres (page does not exist)">
        Maisons des Illustres
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maisons_des_Illustres" title="fr:Maisons des Illustres">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       by the
       <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Culture_(France)" title="Ministry of Culture (France)">
        Ministry of Culture
       </a>
       . Restored in 2006, thanks to the work of the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Centre_international_Jules-Verne&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Centre international Jules-Verne (page does not exist)">
        Centre international Jules-Verne
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centre_international_Jules-Verne" title="fr:Centre international Jules-Verne">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , this 19th-century mansion, listed in the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Supplementary_inventory_of_historic_monuments&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Supplementary inventory of historic monuments (page does not exist)">
        supplementary inventory of historic monuments
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inventaire_suppl%C3%A9mentaire_des_monuments_historiques" title="fr:Inventaire supplémentaire des monuments historiques">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , traces through the exhibition of more than 700 objects, the personality, the sources of inspiration and memories of Jules Verne.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Tour_Perret">
        Tour Perret
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=67" title="Edit section: Tour Perret">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Tour_Perret_(Amiens)" title="Tour Perret (Amiens)">
        Tour Perret (Amiens)
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Opposite the
       <a href="/wiki/Gare_d%27Amiens" title="Gare d'Amiens">
        Gare d'Amiens
       </a>
       , the neighborhood was rebuilt after having been razed by bombing in 1944, is located the
       <a href="/wiki/Tour_Perret_(Amiens)" title="Tour Perret (Amiens)">
        Tour Perret
       </a>
       (from the name of its architect
       <a href="/wiki/Auguste_Perret" title="Auguste Perret">
        Auguste Perret
       </a>
       ). Over 100 metres (330 ft) high, it was one of the first
       <a href="/wiki/Skyscraper" title="Skyscraper">
        skyscrapers
       </a>
       built in Europe, and the highest for a long time.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94">
        <a href="#cite_note-94">
         [80]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="The_Church_of_Saint-Leu">
        The Church of Saint-Leu
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=68" title="Edit section: The Church of Saint-Leu">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article: [[:
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%89glise_Saint-Leu_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Église Saint-Leu d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
        Église Saint-Leu d'Amiens
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89glise_Saint-Leu_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Église Saint-Leu d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ]]
      </div>
      <p>
       This church was built at the end of the 15th century, on the model of the hall-churches. It is dedicated, as its district, to Saint Leu, referring to the 7th century bishop who was exiled to the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Vimeu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Vimeu (page does not exist)">
        Vimeu
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vimeu" title="fr:Vimeu">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       . It has three naves. A flamboyant portal adorns the base of the steeple. The latter, struck by lightning, had to be rebuilt at the beginning of the 16th century. The ends of beams are carved. Stone and wood statues date from the 17th century. The choir houses the
       <a href="/wiki/Glory_(religion)" title="Glory (religion)">
        glory
       </a>
       of the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Aim%C3%A9_and_Louis_Duthoit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Aimé and Louis Duthoit (page does not exist)">
        Duthoit brothers
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aim%C3%A9_et_Louis_Duthoit" title="fr:Aimé et Louis Duthoit">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Other_notable_buildings_or_monuments">
        Other notable buildings or monuments
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=69" title="Edit section: Other notable buildings or monuments">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <h5>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture_from_antiquity">
        Architecture from antiquity
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=70" title="Edit section: Architecture from antiquity">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h5>
      <ul>
       <li>
        Numerous archaeological excavations have uncovered remains from proto-historic times to the Roman era. Two skylights cut in the last development of
        <i>
         Place Gambetta
        </i>
        allow observation of a few remains of the
        <a href="/wiki/Forum_(Roman)" title="Forum (Roman)">
         forum
        </a>
        while important remnants of a large Gallo-Roman theatre uncovered in early 2007 have been dismantled and stored in accordance with the rules of archaeological conservation, during the redevelopment of the Gare quarter (March 2007).
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95">
         <a href="#cite_note-95">
          [81]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        The archaeological garden of Saint-Acheul testifies to the presence of Paleolithic man in the Somme Valley some 450,000 years ago. A stratigraphic cut, classified as an historic monument since 1947, allows visualisation of successive strata of the Somme Valley.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also: [[:
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Archaeological_garden_of_Saint-Acheul&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Archaeological garden of Saint-Acheul (page does not exist)">
        Archaeological garden of Saint-Acheul
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jardin_arch%C3%A9ologique_de_Saint-Acheul" title="fr:Jardin archéologique de Saint-Acheul">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ]]
      </div>
      <h5>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture_from_the_Middle_Ages">
        Architecture from the Middle Ages
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=71" title="Edit section: Architecture from the Middle Ages">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h5>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The Church of Saint-Germain, disused but where exhibitions are regularly held on the colourisation of the cathedral and the St-Germain quarter, historical competitor of the Saint-Leu quarter. The animosity, between the populations of the two districts, has marked the history of Amiens. This church has a high and oddly leaning tower. Affected by the bombing of 1940, it was returned temporarily for worship in October 1965, after a thorough restoration.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article: [[:
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%89glise_Saint-Germain-l%27%C3%89cossais_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Église Saint-Germain-l'Écossais d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
        Église Saint-Germain-l'Écossais d'Amiens
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89glise_Saint-Germain-l%27%C3%89cossais_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Église Saint-Germain-l'Écossais d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ]]
      </div>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The remains of the Hôtel-Dieu (Saint-Leu district, between the
        <abbr title="Centre de Recherche et de Développement Pédagogique (Centre of research and pedagogical development)">
         CRDP
        </abbr>
        and the Faculty of Sciences),
       </li>
       <li>
        The mills
        <i>
         Passe avant
        </i>
        and
        <i>
         Passe arrière
        </i>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96">
         <a href="#cite_note-96">
          [82]
         </a>
        </sup>
        (at Saint-Leu).
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h5>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture_from_the_Renaissance">
        Architecture from the Renaissance
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=72" title="Edit section: Architecture from the Renaissance">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h5>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The renaissance façade of the Maison du Sagittaire (moved to adjoin the Logis du Roy).
       </li>
       <li>
        The Logis du Roy (Faculty of Arts until 2003).
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97">
         <a href="#cite_note-97">
          [83]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        The House of the Bailiwick or Malmaison.
       </li>
       <li>
        The Citadelle: First
        <a href="/wiki/Ravelin" title="Ravelin">
         ravelin
        </a>
        , erected north of the Montrescu gate, the fortress was located in 1531 by F. di Giorgio on the order of
        <a href="/wiki/Francis_I_of_France" title="Francis I of France">
         Francis I
        </a>
        (Francis I gate, with sculpted salamanders). After the capture by the Spaniards and its takeover by Henry IV (1597),
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Jean_Errard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Jean Errard (page does not exist)">
         Jean Errard
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean_Errard" title="fr:Jean Errard">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        received the charge to rebuild the defences of the city.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182px">
        <div style="width: 182px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 180px;">
          <div style="margin:0px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:611_-_Logis_du_Roi_et_maison_du_Sagittaire_-_Amiens.jpg">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3456" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/611_-_Logis_du_Roi_et_maison_du_Sagittaire_-_Amiens.jpg/270px-611_-_Logis_du_Roi_et_maison_du_Sagittaire_-_Amiens.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/611_-_Logis_du_Roi_et_maison_du_Sagittaire_-_Amiens.jpg/405px-611_-_Logis_du_Roi_et_maison_du_Sagittaire_-_Amiens.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/611_-_Logis_du_Roi_et_maison_du_Sagittaire_-_Amiens.jpg/540px-611_-_Logis_du_Roi_et_maison_du_Sagittaire_-_Amiens.jpg 2x" width="180"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           The
           <i>
            Logis du Roy
           </i>
           and the
           <i>
            Maison du Sagittaire
           </i>
           .
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px">
        <div style="width: 162px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;">
          <div style="margin:0px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Amiens_-_Maison_du_Bailliage_(1).jpg">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="2976" data-file-width="3968" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Amiens_-_Maison_du_Bailliage_%281%29.jpg/240px-Amiens_-_Maison_du_Bailliage_%281%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Amiens_-_Maison_du_Bailliage_%281%29.jpg/360px-Amiens_-_Maison_du_Bailliage_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Amiens_-_Maison_du_Bailliage_%281%29.jpg/480px-Amiens_-_Maison_du_Bailliage_%281%29.jpg 2x" width="160"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           The
           <i>
            Maison du bailliage ou Malmaison
           </i>
           , former residence of the
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bailli" title="Bailli">
            bailli
           </a>
           of Amiens, constructed in 1541.
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 161.33333333333px">
        <div style="width: 161.33333333333px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 159.33333333333px;">
          <div style="margin:0px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Amiens_-_Citadelle_(6).jpg">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="1232" data-file-width="1632" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Amiens_-_Citadelle_%286%29.jpg/239px-Amiens_-_Citadelle_%286%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Amiens_-_Citadelle_%286%29.jpg/358px-Amiens_-_Citadelle_%286%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Amiens_-_Citadelle_%286%29.jpg/477px-Amiens_-_Citadelle_%286%29.jpg 2x" width="160"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           Gate of the Ravelin of Montrescu constructed from 1524 to 1531.
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h5>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture_from_the_17th_and_18th_centuries">
        Architecture from the 17th and 18th centuries
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=73" title="Edit section: Architecture from the 17th and 18th centuries">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h5>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Abbaye_Saint-Jean-des-Pr%C3%A9montr%C3%A9s_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Abbaye Saint-Jean-des-Prémontrés d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
         Abbey of Saint-Jean-des-Prémontrés of Amiens
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abbaye_Saint-Jean-des-Pr%C3%A9montr%C3%A9s_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Abbaye Saint-Jean-des-Prémontrés d'Amiens">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        (cloister Dewailly)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abbaye_de_Saint-Acheul" title="Abbaye de Saint-Acheul">
         Abbey of Saint-Acheul
        </a>
        (17th and 18th centuries) and the Church (built in 1760 on the vault of
        <a href="/wiki/Fermin" title="Fermin">
         Fermin
        </a>
        of Amiens)
       </li>
       <li>
        The water tower and fountains of Amiens (1753)
       </li>
       <li>
        The façade of the former theatre (now a bank). It was moved 4 metres (13 ft) to the line of the
        <i>
         Rue des Trois-Cailloux
        </i>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        The façade of the
        <a href="/wiki/Henri_Christian_Michel_de_Stengel" title="Henri Christian Michel de Stengel">
         Stengel barracks
        </a>
        (currently an apartment building)
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Palais_de_l%27%C3%A9v%C3%AAch%C3%A9_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Palais de l'évêché d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
         Palace of the Bishop
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palais_de_l%27%C3%A9v%C3%AAch%C3%A9_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Palais de l'évêché d'Amiens">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        of the 17th and 18th centuries.
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Seminary" title="Seminary">
         Seminary
        </a>
        of the
        <a href="/wiki/Congregation_of_the_Mission" title="Congregation of the Mission">
         Lazarists
        </a>
        : located on
        <i>
         Rue Jules-Barni
        </i>
        , it was built between 1736 and 1741 and benefitted from several extensions of which the last was built under the aegis of
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Fran%C3%A7ois-Auguste_Cheussey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="François-Auguste Cheussey (page does not exist)">
         François-Auguste Cheussey
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois-Auguste_Cheussey" title="fr:François-Auguste Cheussey">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        in 1828. Seized by the
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=State_in_France&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="State in France (page does not exist)">
         State
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89tat_en_France" title="fr:État en France">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        , following the
        <a href="/wiki/1905_French_law_on_the_Separation_of_the_Churches_and_the_State" title="1905 French law on the Separation of the Churches and the State">
         Act of 1905
        </a>
        , the seminary was the
        <a href="/wiki/Barracks" title="Barracks">
         barracks
        </a>
        office (named after the general assigned to the Committee of fortifications,
        <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Charles_Dejean" title="Pierre Charles Dejean">
         Pierre Charles Dejean
        </a>
        ) from 1909 to 1993. During this period, it housed the headquarters of the
        <a href="/wiki/8th_Infantry_Division_(France)" title="8th Infantry Division (France)">
         8th infantry division
        </a>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        The city hall (partly 18th century and partly 19th century). Regional style of stone and brick, with bedrock of sandstone, and stone pavilions. On the pediment is found the statues of King
        <a href="/wiki/Louis_VI_of_France" title="Louis VI of France">
         Louis VI
        </a>
        and Bishop Geoffroi, which granted freedom to Amiens in 1115.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
         <a href="#cite_note-98">
          [84]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ul>

           </a>
          </div>
         </div>

          <p>
           The former Stengel barracks converted into apartments (18th century, historic monuments, 1992).
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px">
        <div style="width: 162px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;">
          <div style="margin:0px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Amiens,_fa%C3%A7ade_de_l%27ancien_th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_(3).JPG">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="2976" data-file-width="3968" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Amiens%2C_fa%C3%A7ade_de_l%27ancien_th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_%283%29.JPG/240px-Amiens%2C_fa%C3%A7ade_de_l%27ancien_th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_%283%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Amiens%2C_fa%C3%A7ade_de_l%27ancien_th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_%283%29.JPG/360px-Amiens%2C_fa%C3%A7ade_de_l%27ancien_th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_%283%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Amiens%2C_fa%C3%A7ade_de_l%27ancien_th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_%283%29.JPG/480px-Amiens%2C_fa%C3%A7ade_de_l%27ancien_th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_%283%29.JPG 2x" width="160"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">

           </i>
           .
          </p>

        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 92px">
        <div style="width: 92px">

           </a>
           <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">

            <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abbaye_Saint-Jean-des-Pr%C3%A9montr%C3%A9s_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Abbaye Saint-Jean-des-Prémontrés d'Amiens">

            </a>
            )
           </span>
           (18th century, historic monuments, 1992).
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>

         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h5>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture_from_the_19th_century">
        Architecture from the 19th century
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=74" title="Edit section: Architecture from the 19th century">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h5>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The Palace of Justice was built from 1865 to 1880
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
         <a href="#cite_note-99">
          [85]
         </a>
        </sup>
        on the site of the Abbey of Saint-Martin-les-Jumeaux (1073 to 1634) established at the supposed place of the sharing of the cloak of Saint Martin and the convent of Célestins (1634 to 1781). Les Célestins, whose order was abolished in 1778, left the premises in 1881.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100">
         <a href="#cite_note-100">
          [86]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Henriville quarter, including the hotel Acloque (neo-Louis XIII style) and the Saint-Martin Church (
        <a href="/wiki/Gothic_Revival_architecture" title="Gothic Revival architecture">
         neo-Gothic
        </a>
        , built by
        <a href="/wiki/Louis_Antoine" title="Louis Antoine">
         Louis Antoine
        </a>
        in 1874).
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=House_of_Jules_Verne&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="House of Jules Verne (page does not exist)">
         home of Jules Verne
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maison_de_Jules_Verne" title="fr:Maison de Jules Verne">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        ,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101">
         <a href="#cite_note-101">
          [87]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102">
         <a href="#cite_note-102">
          [88]
         </a>
        </sup>
        which was reopened after renovation, in 2006, including the present neo-Gothic dining room and antique desk. The tower was covered with an armillary sphere commissioned from artist
        <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Schuiten" title="François Schuiten">
         François Schuiten
        </a>
        , who also signed the mural extending the imaginary garden of yesteryear.
       </li>
       <li>
        The Madeleine Cemetery (Cimetière de la Madeleine)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103">
         <a href="#cite_note-103">
          [89]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104">
         <a href="#cite_note-104">
          [90]
         </a>
        </sup>
        contains a number of listed monuments including the sculpture on the grave of Jules Verne. His tomb is decorated with a sculpture by
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Albert_Roze&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Albert Roze (page does not exist)">
         Albert Roze
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_Roze" title="fr:Albert Roze">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        symbolising the resurrection: Jules Verne lifting the slab to glimpse the modern world.
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Cimeti%C3%A8re_Saint-Acheul&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Cimetière Saint-Acheul (page does not exist)">
         Saint-Acheul cemetery
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cimeti%C3%A8re_Saint-Acheul" title="fr:Cimetière Saint-Acheul">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        where various Amiens personalities are buried and where there is a domed tomb with a sculpture by
        <a href="/wiki/Auguste_Rodin" title="Auguste Rodin">
         Auguste Rodin
        </a>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        The Dewailly clock, by
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Emile_Ricquier&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Emile Ricquier (page does not exist)">
         Emile Ricquier
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emile_Ricquier" title="fr:Emile Ricquier">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        (completely redone in 1999), supplemented by the statue of
        <i>
         Marie-sans chemise
        </i>
        of Albert Roze, originally in the
        <i>
         Place Gambetta
        </i>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        The former insurance house,
        <i>
         Rue Marotte
        </i>
        , built by E. Ricquier in 1893 (now a bar).
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Biblioth%C3%A8ques_d%27Amiens_M%C3%A9tropole&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Bibliothèques d'Amiens Métropole (page does not exist)">
         Louis Aragon library
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biblioth%C3%A8ques_d%27Amiens_M%C3%A9tropole" title="fr:Bibliothèques d'Amiens Métropole">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        ,
        <i>
         Rue de la République
        </i>
        , built by
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Fran%C3%A7ois-Auguste_Cheussey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="François-Auguste Cheussey (page does not exist)">
         François-Auguste Cheussey
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois-Auguste_Cheussey" title="fr:François-Auguste Cheussey">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        in 1823, neoclassical style with a peristyle with columns in
        <a href="/wiki/Tuscan_order" title="Tuscan order">
         Tuscan
        </a>
        drums.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105">
         <a href="#cite_note-105">
          [91]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        The monastery of the visitation, built between 1839 and 1841 by Herbault.
       </li>
       <li>
        The Palace of Justice, new buildings constructed by Cheussey in 1834 and 1846.
       </li>
       <li>
        The renovations by Cheussey (1816-1848) of the cathedral.
       </li>
       <li>
        Place Saint-Denis (now place René Goblet) is designed in 1839 by the architect François Auguste Cheussey.
       </li>
       <li>
        The parish church Saint-Firmin-le-Martyr by Cheussey in 1843.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106">
         <a href="#cite_note-106">
          [92]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%89glise_Sainte-Anne_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Église Sainte-Anne d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
         Church of Sainte-Anne
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89glise_Sainte-Anne_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Église Sainte-Anne d'Amiens">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        of the architect
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Victor_Delefortrie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Victor Delefortrie (page does not exist)">
         Victor Delefortrie
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victor_Delefortrie" title="fr:Victor Delefortrie">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%89glise_Saint-R%C3%A9mi_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Église Saint-Rémi d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
         Church St-Rémi
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89glise_Saint-R%C3%A9mi_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Église Saint-Rémi d'Amiens">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        of architect
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Victor_Delefortrie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Victor Delefortrie (page does not exist)">
         Paul Delefortrie
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victor_Delefortrie" title="fr:Victor Delefortrie">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        .
       </li>
      </ul>
      <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 186px">
        <div style="width: 186px">

          </p>

           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           Hôtel Acloque (19th century, historic monuments, 1999).
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px">
        <div style="width: 162px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;">
          <div style="margin:0px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Amiens_Couvent-Visitation_Facade-ouest_2010.JPG">

           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           The convent of the Visitation-Sainte-Marie (19th century, historic monuments).
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h5>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture_from_the_20th_century">
        Architecture from the 20th century
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=75" title="Edit section: Architecture from the 20th century">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h5>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The hotel Bouctot-Vagniez (seat of the Regional Chamber of commerce and industry), built by Louis Duthoit in 1909, a rare
        <a href="/wiki/Art_Nouveau" title="Art Nouveau">
         Art Nouveau
        </a>
        building in Amiens.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107">
         <a href="#cite_note-107">
          [93]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        The English quarter, located on the road from Longueau, including a British phone box. An island of London in the heart of Amiens.
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/ESIEE_Amiens" title="ESIEE Amiens">
         ESIEE Amiens
        </a>
        , designed by the architects Jean Dubus and Jean-Pierre Lott. A modern building identified by its saucer.
       </li>
       <li>
        Complex of
        <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">
         Art Deco
        </a>
        buildings on
        <i>
         Rue Cauvin
        </i>
        , as well as the
        <a href="/wiki/Gueudet" title="Gueudet">
         Gueudet
        </a>
        garages
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108">
         <a href="#cite_note-108">
          [94]
         </a>
        </sup>
        (
        <i>
         Rue des Otages
        </i>
        ).
       </li>
       <li>
        Église Saint-Honoré, rebuilt between 1957 and 1961, by
        <a href="/wiki/Paul_Tournon" title="Paul Tournon">
         Paul Tournon
        </a>
        , on the plans of the pontifical pavilion of the
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Universal_exhibition_of_Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Universal exhibition of Paris (page does not exist)">
         universal exhibition in Paris
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expositions_universelles_de_Paris" title="fr:Expositions universelles de Paris">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        in 1937.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
         <a href="#cite_note-109">
          [95]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110">
         <a href="#cite_note-110">
          [96]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        The hotel Vagniez-Renon (current headquarters of the administrative tribunal): A former residence of Henriville, it houses a Moorish-style hydrotherapy room, designed by
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%89mile_Ricquier&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Émile Ricquier (page does not exist)">
         Émile Ricquier
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89mile_Ricquier" title="fr:Émile Ricquier">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        The Saint-Pierre church, destroyed in 1940 and rebuilt in 1949 by Evrard, in glass and concrete, with a brick bell tower.
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Le_Courrier_Picard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Le Courrier Picard (page does not exist)">
         <i>
          Le Courrier Picard
         </i>
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Le_Courrier_Picard" title="fr:Le Courrier Picard">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        : The headquarters of the daily life of Amiens, first
        <i>
         Progrès de la Somme
        </i>
        , belongs to a set of
        <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">
         Art Deco
        </a>
        buildings.
       </li>
       <li>
        The monument of
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Philippe_Leclerc_de_Hautecloque" title="Philippe Leclerc de Hautecloque">
         Philippe Leclerc de Hautecloque
        </a>
        by
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jan_and_Jo%C3%ABl_Martel" title="Jan and Joël Martel">
         Jan and Joël Martel
        </a>
        in 1950.
       </li>
       <li>
        The Carmel of the Holy Spirit, on the Montjoie Hill, built in 1965 by architect
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Pierre_Pinsard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Pierre Pinsard (page does not exist)">
         Pierre Pinsard
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierre_Pinsard" title="fr:Pierre Pinsard">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Maison_de_la_culture_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Maison de la culture d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
         House of culture of Amiens
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maison_de_la_culture_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Maison de la culture d'Amiens">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        , inaugurated on 19 March 1966 by
        <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_Malraux" title="André Malraux">
         André Malraux
        </a>
        , built by
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Jean_Duthilleul&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Jean Duthilleul (page does not exist)">
         Jean Duthilleul
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean_Duthilleul" title="fr:Jean Duthilleul">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
         <a href="#cite_note-111">
          [97]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Colis%C3%A9um" title="Coliséum">
         Coliséum
        </a>
        , inaugurated on 5 January 1996, built by the architect
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=ANPAR&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="ANPAR (page does not exist)">
         Pierre Parat
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/ANPAR" title="fr:ANPAR">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        (designer of the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bercy_Arena" title="Bercy Arena">
         Palais omnisports de Paris-Bercy
        </a>
        ).
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Stade_de_la_Licorne" title="Stade de la Licorne">
         Stade de la Licorne
        </a>
        , built in 1999 by architects
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Atelier_d%27architecture_Chaix_%26_Morel_et_associ%C3%A9s&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Atelier d'architecture Chaix &amp; Morel et associés (page does not exist)">
         Philippe Chaix
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atelier_d%27architecture_Chaix_%26_Morel_et_associ%C3%A9s" title="fr:Atelier d'architecture Chaix &amp; Morel et associés">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        and Jean-Paul Morel.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h5>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture_from_the_21st_century">
        Architecture from the 21st century
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=76" title="Edit section: Architecture from the 21st century">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h5>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The
        <i>
         Cinema
         <a href="/wiki/Gaumont_Film_Company" title="Gaumont Film Company">
          Gaumont
         </a>
         Amiens
        </i>
        opened in 2005. It is the work of architects
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Atelier_d%27architecture_Chaix_%26_Morel_et_associ%C3%A9s&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Atelier d'architecture Chaix &amp; Morel et associés (page does not exist)">
         Philippe Chaix and Jean-Paul Morel
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atelier_d%27architecture_Chaix_%26_Morel_et_associ%C3%A9s" title="fr:Atelier d'architecture Chaix &amp; Morel et associés">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        . The interior decoration is the work of
        <a href="/wiki/Christian_Lacroix" title="Christian Lacroix">
         Christian Lacroix
        </a>
        and artists Alain Balzac and François Michel.
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <i>
         Verrière de la place de la
         <a href="/wiki/Gare_d%27Amiens" title="Gare d'Amiens">
          gare d'Amiens
         </a>
        </i>
        , also called the
        <a href="/wiki/Canopy_(biology)" title="Canopy (biology)">
         Canopy
        </a>
        . It is the work of architect
        <a href="/wiki/Claude_Vasconi" title="Claude Vasconi">
         Claude Vasconi
        </a>
        , known especially for the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Forum_des_Halles" title="Forum des Halles">
         Forum des Halles
        </a>
        in
        <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">
         Paris
        </a>
        . Subject of a controversy when it opened in March 2008, the canopy is designed to create a link between the
        <a href="/wiki/Pedestrian_zone" title="Pedestrian zone">
         pedestrian zone
        </a>
        of the city centre and the ZAC Gare la Vallée, to become the business district of Amiens. Criticised
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112">
         <a href="#cite_note-112">
          [98]
         </a>
        </sup>
        for its massive and imposing area of more than 10,000 square metres (110,000 sq ft), the canopy rises to 15 metres (49 ft) in height and is composed of pixellated glass panels created by
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Bernard_Pictet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Bernard Pictet (page does not exist)">
         Bernard Pictet
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernard_Pictet" title="fr:Bernard Pictet">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
         <a href="#cite_note-113">
          [99]
         </a>
        </sup>
        This is one of the largest canopies in
        <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">
         Europe
        </a>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Z%C3%A9nith_d%27Amiens" title="Zénith d'Amiens">
         Zenith of Amiens
        </a>
        by
        <a href="/wiki/Massimiliano_Fuksas" title="Massimiliano Fuksas">
         Massimiliano Fuksas
        </a>
        , in the Renancourt quarter between the Mégacité and the Hippodrome. Construction was completed in 2008.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Environmental_heritage">
        Environmental heritage
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=77" title="Edit section: Environmental heritage">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       With 270 hectares (670 acres) of
       <a href="/wiki/Urban_open_space" title="Urban open space">
        green space
       </a>
       (excluding communal woodland)
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114">
        <a href="#cite_note-114">
         [100]
        </a>
       </sup>
       118,300 hectares (292,000 acres) of
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Hortillonnages_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Hortillonnages d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
        hortillonnages
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hortillonnages_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Hortillonnages d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , 300 hectares (740 acres) of forests, 30 hectares (74 acres) of marshland, its river and its streams, Amiens proves to be green and blue city.
      </p>
      <p>
       Floral City awarded the maximum score of 4 flowers in the
       <a href="/wiki/Concours_des_villes_et_villages_fleuris" title="Concours des villes et villages fleuris">
        floral contest of cities and villages
       </a>
       of France,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115">
        <a href="#cite_note-115">
         [101]
        </a>
       </sup>
       it offers a particularly rich wooded heritage. 38,650 trees (excluding woodland),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116">
        <a href="#cite_note-116">
         [102]
        </a>
       </sup>
       of which 17,000 are situated on highways,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
        <a href="#cite_note-117">
         [103]
        </a>
       </sup>
       allowed it to win the
       <a href="/wiki/Concours_des_villes_et_villages_fleuris" title="Concours des villes et villages fleuris">
        national tree award
       </a>
       . In 2014, the city ranked in the top 10 greenest cities of France.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118">
        <a href="#cite_note-118">
         [104]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Presenting itself as a city concerned with the environment, Amiens has made the link between the city and nature a central axis of its metropolitan development project called
       <i>
        Amiens 2030
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
        <a href="#cite_note-119">
         [105]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="The_Hortillonages">
        The Hortillonages
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=78" title="Edit section: The Hortillonages">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Amiens is also known for the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Hortillonnages&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Hortillonnages (page does not exist)">
        hortillonnages
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hortillonnages_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Hortillonnages d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , gardens on small islands in over 300 hectares (740 acres) of marshland between the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/River_Somme" title="River Somme">
        River Somme
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Avre_(Somme)" title="Avre (Somme)">
        River Avre
       </a>
       , surrounded by a grid network of man-made canals (locally known as "rieux"). They are also known as the "floating gardens of Amiens".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120">
        <a href="#cite_note-120">
         [106]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The hortillonnages are sometimes called "Little Venice of the North", because of the canals.
      </p>
      <p>
       Hortillon means
       <a href="/wiki/Market_garden" title="Market garden">
        market garden
       </a>
       in Picard, and derives from the Latin
       <i>
        hortillus
       </i>
       , small garden. It is circulated in flat bottom boats, formerly called
       <i>
        barque à cornet
       </i>
       [Cornet boat], due to the very raised front, which allows the boats to easily dock on the fragile shores of the cultivated fields. It is the port of upstream, located at the foot of the cathedral where a weekly market is held on the water, although the arrival by boat of the growers can be accomplished only once a year, in summer.
      </p>
      <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 183.33333333333px">

           </a>

          </p>
         </div>
        </div>

      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Amiens_Metropolitan_Zoo">
        Amiens Metropolitan Zoo
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=79" title="Edit section: Amiens Metropolitan Zoo">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Prior to its opening in May 1952, the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Zoo_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Zoo d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
        Amiens Zoo
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zoo_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Zoo d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       is a green space bordering the basin of the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Parc_de_la_Hotoie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Parc de la Hotoie (page does not exist)">
        Park of the Hotoie
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parc_de_la_Hotoie" title="fr:Parc de la Hotoie">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       . It was the mayor of the time,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Maurice_Vast&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Maurice Vast (page does not exist)">
        Maurice Vast
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurice_Vast" title="fr:Maurice Vast">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , who decided to develop the site in 1949. Originally for entertainment venue, the zoo began its mission of conservation, education and research between 1970 and 1980. Between 1990 and 2000, the zoo was completely renovated and became a permanent member of the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Association_of_Zoos_and_Aquaria" title="European Association of Zoos and Aquaria">
        European Association of Zoos and Aquaria
       </a>
       (EAZA) in 2001 and the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Association_nationale_des_parcs_zoologiques&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Association nationale des parcs zoologiques (page does not exist)">
        National Association of Zoological Parks
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_nationale_des_parcs_zoologiques" title="fr:Association nationale des parcs zoologiques">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       (ANPZ) in 2002. Today, there are 300 animals, representing approximately 75 species from all continents, cohabiting on 6.5 hectares (16 acres).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121">
        <a href="#cite_note-121">
         [107]
        </a>
       </sup>
       They live in environments, which are close to their natural environment, favouring their well-being. In 2014, the zoo received 161,128 visitors.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122">
        <a href="#cite_note-122">
         [108]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Traditionally, entry is free on July 14,
       <a href="/wiki/Bastille_Day" title="Bastille Day">
        Bastille Day
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 112px">
        <div style="width: 112px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 110px;">

           </a>
          </div>

           <i>

            <a href="/wiki/South_American_coati" title="South American coati">
             Nasua nasua
            </a>
            )
           </i>
           .
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
