        <div style="width: 162px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;">
          <div style="margin:0px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%C3%89l%C3%A9phants_d%27Asie_au_zoo_d%27Amiens.jpg">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/%C3%89l%C3%A9phants_d%27Asie_au_zoo_d%27Amiens.jpg/240px-%C3%89l%C3%A9phants_d%27Asie_au_zoo_d%27Amiens.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/%C3%89l%C3%A9phants_d%27Asie_au_zoo_d%27Amiens.jpg/360px-%C3%89l%C3%A9phants_d%27Asie_au_zoo_d%27Amiens.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/%C3%89l%C3%A9phants_d%27Asie_au_zoo_d%27Amiens.jpg/480px-%C3%89l%C3%A9phants_d%27Asie_au_zoo_d%27Amiens.jpg 2x" width="160"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           Jena and Praya, the two Asian elephants
           <i>
            (
            <a href="/wiki/Asian_elephant" title="Asian elephant">
             Elephas maximus
            </a>
            )
           </i>
           .
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 87.333333333333px">
        <div style="width: 87.333333333333px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 85.333333333333px;">
          <div style="margin:0px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Otarie_du_zoo_d%27Amiens.jpg">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="1583" data-file-width="1128" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Otarie_du_zoo_d%27Amiens.jpg/128px-Otarie_du_zoo_d%27Amiens.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Otarie_du_zoo_d%27Amiens.jpg/192px-Otarie_du_zoo_d%27Amiens.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Otarie_du_zoo_d%27Amiens.jpg/256px-Otarie_du_zoo_d%27Amiens.jpg 2x" width="86"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           California sea lion
           <i>
            (
            <a href="/wiki/California_sea_lion" title="California sea lion">
             Zalophus californianus
            </a>
            )
           </i>
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 92.666666666667px">
        <div style="width: 92.666666666667px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 90.666666666667px;">
          <div style="margin:0px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Manchots_Amiens_02.jpg">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="2112" data-file-width="1602" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Manchots_Amiens_02.jpg/136px-Manchots_Amiens_02.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Manchots_Amiens_02.jpg/205px-Manchots_Amiens_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Manchots_Amiens_02.jpg/273px-Manchots_Amiens_02.jpg 2x" width="91"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           Humboldt penguins
           <i>
            (
            <a href="/wiki/Humboldt_penguin" title="Humboldt penguin">
             Spheniscus humboldti
            </a>
            )
           </i>
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="The_main_parks_and_gardens">
        The main parks and gardens
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=80" title="Edit section: The main parks and gardens">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Les_principaux_parcs_d%27Amiens.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="793" data-file-width="1041" height="168" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Les_principaux_parcs_d%27Amiens.jpg/220px-Les_principaux_parcs_d%27Amiens.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Les_principaux_parcs_d%27Amiens.jpg/330px-Les_principaux_parcs_d%27Amiens.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Les_principaux_parcs_d%27Amiens.jpg/440px-Les_principaux_parcs_d%27Amiens.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Les_principaux_parcs_d%27Amiens.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The principal parks and gardens in the city.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="div-col columns column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em;">
       <ol>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Parc_Saint-Pierre_(Amiens)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Parc Saint-Pierre (Amiens) (page does not exist)">
          Parc Saint-Pierre
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parc_Saint-Pierre_(Amiens)" title="fr:Parc Saint-Pierre (Amiens)">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         , between the quarter of Saint-Leu and the
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Hortillonnages_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Hortillonnages d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
          Hortillonnages
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hortillonnages_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Hortillonnages d'Amiens">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         , poumon vert de 22 hectares (54 acres) in the heart of the city, which was awarded the
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Prix_du_Paysage&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Prix du Paysage (page does not exist)">
          Prix du Paysage
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prix_du_Paysage" title="fr:Prix du Paysage">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         in 2005.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123">
          <a href="#cite_note-123">
           [109]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Parc_du_Grand_Marais_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Parc du Grand Marais d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
          Parc du Grand Marais
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parc_du_Grand_Marais_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Parc du Grand Marais d'Amiens">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         , along the Somme Canal, to the west of the city. Covering over 25 hectares (62 acres), this park has many sports facilities: American football stadium, skate
         <a href="/wiki/Skatepark" title="Skatepark">
          bowl
         </a>
         , football field, play structures.
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Jardin_des_plantes_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Jardin des plantes d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
          Jardin des plantes
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jardin_des_plantes_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Jardin des plantes d'Amiens">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         originally called the
         <i>
          Jardin du Roy
         </i>
         . Created in 1751, it is the oldest garden of Amiens on the
         <i>
          Boulevard du jardin des plantes
         </i>
        </li>
        <li>
         Square Pierre Marie Saquez on
         <i>
          Rue des Cordeliers
         </i>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Parc_de_l%27Ev%C3%A9ch%C3%A9_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Parc de l'Evéché d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
          Parc de l'Evéché d'Amiens
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parc_de_l%27Ev%C3%A9ch%C3%A9_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Parc de l'Evéché d'Amiens">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         , at the foot of the cathedral on
         <i>
          Place Saint-Michel
         </i>
        </li>
        <li>
         Jardin médiéval on
         <i>
          Impasse Joron
         </i>
        </li>
        <li>
         Square Beauregard on
         <i>
          Rue Louis Thuillier
         </i>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Parc_Jean_Rostand&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Parc Jean Rostand (page does not exist)">
          Parc Jean Rostand
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parc_Jean_Rostand" title="fr:Parc Jean Rostand">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         on
         <i>
          Rue Vulfran Warmé
         </i>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Ch%C3%A2teau_de_Monti%C3%A8res&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Château de Montières (page does not exist)">
          Parc du Château de Montières
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_de_Monti%C3%A8res" title="fr:Château de Montières">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         on
         <i>
          Rue Baudoin d'Ailly
         </i>
        </li>
        <li>
         Parc du Petit Marais on the
         <i>
          Avenue des cygnes
         </i>
        </li>
        <li>
         Square Paul Gauguin on the
         <i>
          Avenue de la paix
         </i>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Parc_de_la_Hotoie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Parc de la Hotoie (page does not exist)">
          Parc de la Hotoie
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parc_de_la_Hotoie" title="fr:Parc de la Hotoie">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         Marais des trois vaches
        </li>
        <li>
         Parc du Château blanc, on the
         <i>
          Route de Rouen
         </i>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Bois_Bonvallet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Bois Bonvallet (page does not exist)">
          Bois Bonvallet
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bois_Bonvallet" title="fr:Bois Bonvallet">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         Square de la rose des vents on
         <i>
          Rue du Docteur Fafet
         </i>
        </li>
        <li>
         Plaine Saint Ladre
        </li>
        <li>
         Parc Léon Pille on
         <i>
          Rue de l'Agrappin
         </i>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Zoo_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Zoo d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
          Zoo d'Amiens
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zoo_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Zoo d'Amiens">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         on the
         <i>
          Esplanade de la Hotoie
         </i>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Cimeti%C3%A8re_de_La_Madeleine_(Amiens)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Cimetière de La Madeleine (Amiens) (page does not exist)">
          Cimetière de la Madeleine
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cimeti%C3%A8re_de_La_Madeleine_(Amiens)" title="fr:Cimetière de La Madeleine (Amiens)">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         , on
         <i>
          Rue Saint Maurice
         </i>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Square_Saint-Denis_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Square Saint-Denis d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
          Le Square Saint-Denis
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Square_Saint-Denis_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Square Saint-Denis d'Amiens">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         Square Montplaisir, on
         <i>
          Place Joffre
         </i>
        </li>
        <li>
         Square Aimé Césaire, on
         <i>
          Boulevard de Belfort
         </i>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Clos_Alexandre_(Amiens)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Clos Alexandre (Amiens) (page does not exist)">
          Clos Alexandre
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clos_Alexandre_(Amiens)" title="fr:Clos Alexandre (Amiens)">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         , jardin floral et paysager privé
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Cimeti%C3%A8re_Saint-Acheul&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Cimetière Saint-Acheul (page does not exist)">
          Cimetière Saint-Acheul
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cimeti%C3%A8re_Saint-Acheul" title="fr:Cimetière Saint-Acheul">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         , on
         <i>
          Rue de Cagny
         </i>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Jardin_arch%C3%A9ologique_de_Saint-Acheul&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Jardin archéologique de Saint-Acheul (page does not exist)">
          Jardin archéologique de Saint-Acheul
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jardin_arch%C3%A9ologique_de_Saint-Acheul" title="fr:Jardin archéologique de Saint-Acheul">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         , on
         <i>
          Rue de Boutillerie
         </i>
        </li>
       </ol>
      </div>
      <p>
       Floral city: 4 flowers attributed since 2013 by the National Council of Cities and Villages of France for the
       <a href="/wiki/Concours_des_villes_et_villages_fleuris" title="Concours des villes et villages fleuris">
        competition of floral cities and villages
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124">
        <a href="#cite_note-124">
         [110]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The national Council of Cities and Villages awarded the
       <a href="/wiki/Concours_des_villes_et_villages_fleuris" title="Concours des villes et villages fleuris">
        2012 National Tree Prize
       </a>
       to the city for "its exceptional and innovative management of its wooded heritage" (37,000 trees, some more than a century old).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125">
        <a href="#cite_note-125">
         [111]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cultural_heritage">
        Cultural heritage
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=81" title="Edit section: Cultural heritage">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Museums">
        Museums
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=82" title="Edit section: Museums">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mus%C3%A9e_de_Picardie_Amiens.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="533" data-file-width="830" height="141" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Mus%C3%A9e_de_Picardie_Amiens.jpg/220px-Mus%C3%A9e_de_Picardie_Amiens.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Mus%C3%A9e_de_Picardie_Amiens.jpg/330px-Mus%C3%A9e_de_Picardie_Amiens.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Mus%C3%A9e_de_Picardie_Amiens.jpg/440px-Mus%C3%A9e_de_Picardie_Amiens.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mus%C3%A9e_de_Picardie_Amiens.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_de_Picardie" title="Musée de Picardie">
          Musée de Picardie
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_de_Picardie" title="Musée de Picardie">
         Musée de Picardie
        </a>
        is a key site in the history of the National Museum since it is the first building to have been built in France to serve as a museum as such.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126">
         <a href="#cite_note-126">
          [112]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Built under the Second Empire on the model of the new
        <a href="/wiki/Louvre_Palace" title="Louvre Palace">
         Louvre of Napoleon III
        </a>
        , it opened its doors to the public in 1867 after the visit of the emperor. Considered the French model of a 19th-century museum, it was nicknamed the "Little Louvre of the Province".
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127">
         <a href="#cite_note-127">
          [113]
         </a>
        </sup>
        It hosted very early rich collections which are now divided into four departments:
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128">
         <a href="#cite_note-128">
          [114]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <a href="/wiki/Archaeology" title="Archaeology">
         Archaeology
        </a>
        in the basement, the
        <a href="/wiki/Medieval_art" title="Medieval art">
         Medieval art
        </a>
        on the ground floor,
        <a href="/wiki/Fine_art" title="Fine art">
         fine arts
        </a>
        on the ground floor and the first floor, and
        <a href="/wiki/Modern_art" title="Modern art">
         modern
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Contemporary_art" title="Contemporary art">
         contemporary art
        </a>
        on the first floor. Rooms are also devoted to temporary exhibitions. The department of fine arts brings together paintings by
        <a href="/wiki/Anthony_van_Dyck" title="Anthony van Dyck">
         Van Dyck
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Jacob_Jordaens" title="Jacob Jordaens">
         Jordaens
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Salomon_van_Ruysdael" title="Salomon van Ruysdael">
         Ruysdael
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/El_Greco" title="El Greco">
         El Greco
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Jusepe_de_Ribera" title="Jusepe de Ribera">
         Ribera
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Battista_Tiepolo" title="Giovanni Battista Tiepolo">
         Tiepolo
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Francesco_Guardi" title="Francesco Guardi">
         Guardi
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Jean-Honor%C3%A9_Fragonard" title="Jean-Honoré Fragonard">
         Fragonard
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Jean-Baptiste-Sim%C3%A9on_Chardin" title="Jean-Baptiste-Siméon Chardin">
         Chardin
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Boucher" title="François Boucher">
         Boucher
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Maurice_Quentin_de_La_Tour" title="Maurice Quentin de La Tour">
         Quentin de La Tour
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Simon_Vouet" title="Simon Vouet">
         Vouet
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Jean-Baptiste-Camille_Corot" title="Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot">
         Corot
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Gustave_Courbet" title="Gustave Courbet">
         Courbet
        </a>
        . The modern and contemporary collection is represented by
        <a href="/wiki/Pablo_Picasso" title="Pablo Picasso">
         Picasso
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Francis_Picabia" title="Francis Picabia">
         Picabia
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Balthus" title="Balthus">
         Balthus
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Jean_Dubuffet" title="Jean Dubuffet">
         Dubuffet
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Jean_H%C3%A9lion" title="Jean Hélion">
         Hélion
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Francis_Bacon_(artist)" title="Francis Bacon (artist)">
         Bacon
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Joan_Mir%C3%B3" title="Joan Miró">
         Miró
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Manessier" title="Alfred Manessier">
         Manessier
        </a>
        . Access to the picture galleries of the first floor is by a mounumental staircase in a setting dedicated to the famous wall compositions of
        <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Puvis_de_Chavannes" title="Pierre Puvis de Chavannes">
         Pierre Puvis de Chavannes
        </a>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129">
         <a href="#cite_note-129">
          [115]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Amiens_-_Hotel_de_Berny.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3072" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Amiens_-_Hotel_de_Berny.JPG/220px-Amiens_-_Hotel_de_Berny.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Amiens_-_Hotel_de_Berny.JPG/330px-Amiens_-_Hotel_de_Berny.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Amiens_-_Hotel_de_Berny.JPG/440px-Amiens_-_Hotel_de_Berny.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Amiens_-_Hotel_de_Berny.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Mus%C3%A9e_de_l%27H%C3%B4tel_de_Berny&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Musée de l'Hôtel de Berny (page does not exist)">
          Musée de l'Hôtel de Berny
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_de_l%27H%C3%B4tel_de_Berny" title="fr:Musée de l'Hôtel de Berny">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Hotel_de_Berny_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Hotel de Berny Museum (page does not exist)">
         Hotel de Berny Museum
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_de_l%27H%C3%B4tel_de_Berny" title="fr:Musée de l'Hôtel de Berny">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        is a regional museum of local art and history. This building, typical of the
        <a href="/wiki/Louis_XIII_style" title="Louis XIII style">
         Louis XIII architecture
        </a>
        , was built in 1634 as a mansion of the treasurers of France. Property of
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=G%C3%A9rard_de_Berny&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Gérard de Berny (page does not exist)">
         Gérard de Berny
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/G%C3%A9rard_de_Berny" title="fr:Gérard de Berny">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        , Senator of the Somme, in the first half of the 20th century, the latter restored the façades and settled its collections. Located a few metres from the Cathedral, this
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Museum_of_France&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Museum of France (page does not exist)">
         Museum of France
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_de_France" title="fr:Musée de France">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        retains an exceptional collection of woodwork, furniture and objets d'art (tapestries, ceramics, ironworks) and memories (objects and arrays) of Amiens personalities:
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130">
         <a href="#cite_note-130">
          [116]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <a href="/wiki/Jules_Verne" title="Jules Verne">
         Jules Verne
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Choderlos_de_Laclos" title="Pierre Choderlos de Laclos">
         Choderlos de Laclos
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/%C3%89douard_Branly" title="Édouard Branly">
         Édouard Branly
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Jean-Baptiste-Louis_Gresset" title="Jean-Baptiste-Louis Gresset">
         Jean-Baptiste Gresset
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Vincent_Voiture" title="Vincent Voiture">
         Vincent Voiture
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Pinchon" title="Joseph Pinchon">
         Joseph Pinchon
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Philippe_Leclerc_de_Hauteclocque" title="Philippe Leclerc de Hauteclocque">
         Maréchal Leclerc
        </a>
        . The museum is currently undergoing a complete renovation of its buildings and an overhaul of the installation of its museum collections.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Amiens_Tour_Jules_Verne_(depuis_boulevard)_1a.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1394" data-file-width="1704" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Amiens_Tour_Jules_Verne_%28depuis_boulevard%29_1a.jpg/220px-Amiens_Tour_Jules_Verne_%28depuis_boulevard%29_1a.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Amiens_Tour_Jules_Verne_%28depuis_boulevard%29_1a.jpg/330px-Amiens_Tour_Jules_Verne_%28depuis_boulevard%29_1a.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Amiens_Tour_Jules_Verne_%28depuis_boulevard%29_1a.jpg/440px-Amiens_Tour_Jules_Verne_%28depuis_boulevard%29_1a.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Amiens_Tour_Jules_Verne_(depuis_boulevard)_1a.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=House_of_Jules_Verne&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="House of Jules Verne (page does not exist)">
          House of Jules Verne
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/maison_de_Jules_Verne" title="fr:maison de Jules Verne">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         from the
         <i>
          Mail Albert 1st
         </i>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=House_of_Jules_Verne&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="House of Jules Verne (page does not exist)">
         House of Jules Verne
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maison_de_Jules_Verne" title="fr:Maison de Jules Verne">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        , labeled
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Maisons_des_Illustres&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Maisons des Illustres (page does not exist)">
         Maisons des Illustres
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maisons_des_Illustres" title="fr:Maisons des Illustres">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        , is the home of the most translated writer in the world after Agatha Christie:
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131">
         <a href="#cite_note-131">
          [117]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <a href="/wiki/Jules_Verne" title="Jules Verne">
         Jules Verne
        </a>
        . He lived here from 1882 to 1900 with his wife Honorine, and wrote part of his work in this mansion of the 19th century. Its visit proposes to enter into the intimate and creative universe of the author. The building largely retains its original decor and opens almost all of its rooms, from the ground floor to the attic. The permanent collections are presented on two floors, in the attic, the tower and the belvedere of the house: Approximately 700 collected objects evoke the personality, sources of inspiration and memories of Jules Verne.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132">
         <a href="#cite_note-132">
          [118]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Costumed tours, performances, parties and literary encounters of thematic conferences are also regularly organised.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133">
         <a href="#cite_note-133">
          [119]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Gallery of
        <a href="/wiki/Stained_glass" title="Stained glass">
         stained glass
        </a>
        is located in the workshop of master glassmaker Claude Barre, in a house of the 16th century near to the cathedral. It presents a large collection to the public of religious stained-glass windows and interior from the 11th to the 19th century. The gallery also offers demonstrations on the techniques of stained glass.
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=House_of_culture_of_Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="House of culture of Amiens (page does not exist)">
         House of culture of Amiens
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maison_de_la_culture_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Maison de la culture d'Amiens">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        (also known by the acronym MCA or MACU) was inaugurated on 19 March 1966 by
        <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_Malraux" title="André Malraux">
         André Malraux
        </a>
        . Major
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%89tablissement_public_de_coop%C3%A9ration_culturelle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Établissement public de coopération culturelle (page does not exist)">
         cultural institution
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89tablissement_public_de_coop%C3%A9ration_culturelle" title="fr:Établissement public de coopération culturelle">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        in the region, it has two exhibition halls for
        <a href="/wiki/Contemporary_art" title="Contemporary art">
         contemporary art
        </a>
        , the Matisse Hall and the Giacometti Room, which regularly host exhibitions of sculptures, photographs and plastic arts.
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Fonds_r%C3%A9gional_d%27art_contemporain" title="Fonds régional d'art contemporain">
         Fonds régional d'art contemporain
        </a>
        of Picardie (FRAC Picardie), created in 1983, aims the promotion of contemporary art in partiular through dissemination actions. As early as 1985, FRAC Picardie had specialised its action in the field of the design and its contemporary dimensions. It is also interested in the media, on and off paper, since artists are now working through the video medium. This allowed it to acquire a good reputation in France and abroad.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134">
         <a href="#cite_note-134">
          [120]
         </a>
        </sup>
        In 30 years, the FRAC has brought together a unique collection of a thousand drawings which include major names of contemporary art, such as
        <a href="/wiki/Jean-Michel_Basquiat" title="Jean-Michel Basquiat">
         Basquiat
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Jean_Dubuffet" title="Jean Dubuffet">
         Dubuffet
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Dennis_Oppenheim" title="Dennis Oppenheim">
         Oppenheim
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Cy_Twombly" title="Cy Twombly">
         Twombly
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Roberto_Matta" title="Roberto Matta">
         Matta
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Manessier" title="Alfred Manessier">
         Manessier
        </a>
        , etc.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135">
         <a href="#cite_note-135">
          [121]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Since 2001, discussions are underway to construct a new building to accommodate the
        <a href="/wiki/Fonds" title="Fonds">
         fonds
        </a>
        and its collections.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136">
         <a href="#cite_note-136">
          [122]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       Amiens was strongly tipped to host the
       <a href="/wiki/Louvre-Lens" title="Louvre-Lens">
        Louvre II
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137">
        <a href="#cite_note-137">
         [123]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Concert_halls">
        Concert halls
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=83" title="Edit section: Concert halls">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       The city has a number of concert spaces, mostly small venues, and pubs also host numerous concerts throughout the year.
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Z%C3%A9nith_d%27Amiens" title="Zénith d'Amiens">
         Zenith of Amiens
        </a>
        was inaugurated in September 2008. With a capacity of 6,000 seats, it is the work of the Italian architect
        <a href="/wiki/Massimiliano_Fuksas" title="Massimiliano Fuksas">
         Massimiliano Fuksas
        </a>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138">
         <a href="#cite_note-138">
          [124]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Holder of the required
        <a href="/wiki/Le_Z%C3%A9nith" title="Le Zénith">
         Zénith
        </a>
        label, this facility allows the hosting of national and international headline acts and ensures a high level of services and organisation. The accessibility of the place by motorway (A16, A29, A1), and the possibilities of free parking, radiates to Belgium and to the Paris region.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139">
         <a href="#cite_note-139">
          [125]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=M%C3%A9gacit%C3%A9_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Mégacité d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
         megacity
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/M%C3%A9gacit%C3%A9_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Mégacité d'Amiens">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        is the Park of the Congress and Exhibitions of Amiens. Located in immediate proximity of the Zenith of Amiens and the
        <a href="/wiki/Stade_de_la_Licorne" title="Stade de la Licorne">
         Stade de la Licorne
        </a>
        , there are two auditoriums of 350 and 1,000 places
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140">
         <a href="#cite_note-140">
          [126]
         </a>
        </sup>
        where concerts and
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Spectacle_comique&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Spectacle comique (page does not exist)">
         comedy shows
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectacle_comique" title="fr:Spectacle comique">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        are programmed.
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Cirque_Jules-Verne&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Cirque Jules-Verne (page does not exist)">
         Cirque Jules-Verne
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cirque_Jules-Verne" title="fr:Cirque Jules-Verne">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        , the biggest grand circus of France, has about 1,700 seating spaces since its renovation in 2003. It welcomes, among other shows, concerts.
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Maison_de_la_culture_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Maison de la culture d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
         House of culture of Amiens
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maison_de_la_culture_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Maison de la culture d'Amiens">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        offers many live shows and concerts. It manages also New Dreams, a room for 120 seated or 300 standing, which also hosts concerts.
       </li>
       <li>
        The Auditorium Henri Dutilleux is the auditorium of the
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Conservatoire_%C3%A0_rayonnement_r%C3%A9gional_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Conservatoire à rayonnement régional d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
         Conservatoire à rayonnement régional d'Amiens
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservatoire_%C3%A0_rayonnement_r%C3%A9gional_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Conservatoire à rayonnement régional d'Amiens">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        . With high acoustic quality, it offers 370 seats on three levels. It offers mainly classical concerts.
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=La_Lune_des_Pirates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="La Lune des Pirates (page does not exist)">
         La Lune des Pirates
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_Lune_des_Pirates" title="fr:La Lune des Pirates">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        is the
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Musiques_actuelles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Musiques actuelles (page does not exist)">
         stage of contemporary music
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Musiques_actuelles" title="fr:Musiques actuelles">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        (SMAC) of the city. Created in
        <a href="/wiki/1987_in_music" title="1987 in music">
         1987
        </a>
        in a former banana warehouse of the Belu Wharf, La Lune has a capacity of 250 seats.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Theatres">
        Theatres
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=84" title="Edit section: Theatres">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Amiens_France_Maison-de-la-Culture-01.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2334" data-file-width="4000" height="128" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Amiens_France_Maison-de-la-Culture-01.jpg/220px-Amiens_France_Maison-de-la-Culture-01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Amiens_France_Maison-de-la-Culture-01.jpg/330px-Amiens_France_Maison-de-la-Culture-01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Amiens_France_Maison-de-la-Culture-01.jpg/440px-Amiens_France_Maison-de-la-Culture-01.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Amiens_France_Maison-de-la-Culture-01.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Maison_de_la_culture_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Maison de la culture d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
          House of Culture of Amiens
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maison_de_la_culture_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Maison de la culture d'Amiens">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Maison_de_la_culture_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Maison de la culture d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
         House of Culture of Amiens
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maison_de_la_culture_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Maison de la culture d'Amiens">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        has the
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Sc%C3%A8ne_nationale&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Scène nationale (page does not exist)">
         Scène nationale
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sc%C3%A8ne_nationale" title="fr:Scène nationale">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        accreditation from the
        <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Culture_(France)" title="Ministry of Culture (France)">
         Ministry of Culture
        </a>
        . Cultural place of the city, its mission is broad and covers many disciplines: theatre, music, dance, cinema and visual arts. It brings together two theatres: the
        <i>
         Grand Théâtre
        </i>
        (1,070 seats) and the
        <i>
         Petit Théâtre
        </i>
        (300 seats).
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Com%C3%A9die_de_Picardie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Comédie de Picardie (page does not exist)">
         Comédie de Picardie
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Com%C3%A9die_de_Picardie" title="fr:Comédie de Picardie">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        (ComDePic) is one of the city's main theatres. This
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Sc%C3%A8ne_conventionn%C3%A9e&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Scène conventionnée (page does not exist)">
         Scène conventionnée
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sc%C3%A8ne_conventionn%C3%A9e" title="fr:Scène conventionnée">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        was founded in 1989 by the
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Conseil_r%C3%A9gional_de_Picardie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Conseil régional de Picardie (page does not exist)">
         Regional Council of Picardie
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conseil_r%C3%A9gional_de_Picardie" title="fr:Conseil régional de Picardie">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        and offers fifteen plays every year. The theatre has a room of 400 places and houses its own company.
       </li>
       <li>
        The Maison du Théâtre was established in April 1988 in the historic quarter of
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Saint-Leu_(Amiens)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Saint-Leu (Amiens) (page does not exist)">
         Saint-Leu
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saint-Leu_(Amiens)" title="fr:Saint-Leu (Amiens)">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        . Its activities range from creation to dissemination, training and theatrical information. Focused on contemporary theatre, the
        <i>
         Maison du Théâtre
        </i>
        also hosts local theatrical companies and their creations.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141">
         <a href="#cite_note-141">
          [127]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        The puppet theatre "Chés cabotants of Amiens", founded in 1933, is the heir of some eighty cabotan theatres which were created in Amiens, in the 19th century, the French capital of the puppet son.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142">
         <a href="#cite_note-142">
          [128]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Since 1997, a theatre is dedicated to
        <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A9s_Cabotans" title="Chés Cabotans">
         Chés Cabotans of Amiens
        </a>
        and his popular hero
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Lafleur_(marionnette)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Lafleur (marionnette) (page does not exist)">
         Lafleur
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lafleur_(marionnette)" title="fr:Lafleur (marionnette)">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        . It is located in the heart of the Saint-Leu quarter.
       </li>
       <li>
        The Boîte à Rire is a
        <a href="/wiki/Caf%C3%A9-th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre" title="Café-théâtre">
         café-théâtre
        </a>
        , created in September 2012.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143">
         <a href="#cite_note-143">
          [129]
         </a>
        </sup>
        This 48-seat hall is located near to
        <a href="/wiki/Amiens_Cathedral" title="Amiens Cathedral">
         Amiens Cathedral
        </a>
        , and proudly displays a
        <a href="/wiki/One-person_show" title="One-person show">
         one-man show
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Boulevard_theatre_(aesthetic)" title="Boulevard theatre (aesthetic)">
         Boulevard theatre
        </a>
        .
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cultural_centres">
        Cultural centres
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=85" title="Edit section: Cultural centres">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Amiens Métropole has nine cultural centres which cover much of the metropolitan area: Six in various districts of Amiens, and three in the neighbouring communes of
       <a href="/wiki/Longueau" title="Longueau">
        Longueau
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Camon,_Somme" title="Camon, Somme">
        Camon
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Glisy" title="Glisy">
        Glisy
       </a>
       . These outreach facilities working in the field of art and creation are openly oriented "venues". Open to all, they offer an eclectic programme: Parts of theatre and concerts, shows for young people and dance, projections of films, exhibitions, meetings and debates, etc. In 2013, they accommodated 48,000 people.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144">
        <a href="#cite_note-144">
         [130]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The
        <i>
         Briqueterie
        </i>
        is installed, since 2001, on the site of the former Friant military barracks in the Elbeuf quarter.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145">
         <a href="#cite_note-145">
          [131]
         </a>
        </sup>
        As part of its programming, it hosts concerts, as well as exhibitions, public theatre and shows for youths. To this end, it has a room that can accommodate 120 people.
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <i>
         Jacques Tati cultural centre
        </i>
        is located in the heart of the Pierre Rollin.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146">
         <a href="#cite_note-146">
          [132]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Opened in January 2008, the Jacques Tati theatre has 198 seats
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147">
         <a href="#cite_note-147">
          [133]
         </a>
        </sup>
        and hosts plays, public youth performances, concerts, etc.
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <i>
         Léo-Lagrange cultural centre
        </i>
        is located in Saint Germain district.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148">
         <a href="#cite_note-148">
          [134]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Venue of exhibitions, meetings and performances (music, theatre, dance, circus), it has a room of 85 seats named the chapel.
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <i>
         CSC
        </i>
        is installed in the heart of the Etouvie quarter.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149">
         <a href="#cite_note-149">
          [135]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Its missions include the dissemination of exhibitions and performances. To this end, it has a room of 150 seats.
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <i>
         Étoile du sud
        </i>
        is located in the neighbourhood Victorine-Autier. This cultural centre is specialised in urban cultures and has the peculiarity of having a computer (
        <abbr title="Musique assistée par ordinateur (Computer music)">
         MAO
        </abbr>
        ) recording studio.
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <i>
         Safran
        </i>
        is located in the north quarter of Amiens. This 'multidisciplinary and experimental'
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Sc%C3%A8ne_Conventionn%C3%A9e&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Scène Conventionnée (page does not exist)">
         Scène Conventionnée
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sc%C3%A8ne_Conventionn%C3%A9e" title="fr:Scène Conventionnée">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        offers diverse programming:
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150">
         <a href="#cite_note-150">
          [136]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Drama, public youth shows, dance and exhibitions. Its theatre hall, known as
        <i>
         Gérard-Philipe
        </i>
        has 220 spaces.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151">
         <a href="#cite_note-151">
          [137]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Saffron also hosts a music complex, the
        <i>
         Cité Carter
        </i>
        , which offers rehearsal studios, recording sessions and organises concerts of contemporary music in its 250-seat hall.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152">
         <a href="#cite_note-152">
          [138]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Libraries">
        Libraries
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=86" title="Edit section: Libraries">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article: [[:
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Biblioth%C3%A8ques_d%27Amiens_M%C3%A9tropole&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Bibliothèques d'Amiens Métropole (page does not exist)">
        Bibliothèques d'Amiens Métropole
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biblioth%C3%A8ques_d%27Amiens_M%C3%A9tropole" title="fr:Bibliothèques d'Amiens Métropole">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ]]
      </div>
      <p>
       Libraries currently constitute a network of 28 facilities spread over the whole territory of the metropolis. The heart of this network is the Louis Aragon library, located on
       <i>
        Rue de la République
       </i>
       . Built between 1823 and 1826, it is one of the oldest municipal libraries in France.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153">
        <a href="#cite_note-153">
         [139]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It experienced several improvements, including campaigns of work between 1982 and 1993, which have endowed it with new spaces: Two auditoriums, a youth space, a library and an art library.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154">
        <a href="#cite_note-154">
         [140]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Registration and borrowing is free for all of the people of Amiens in all libraries. Two libraries also provide service to quarters and the communes of the agglomeration, as well as the home delivery of documents for people with reduced mobility.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cinemas">
        Cinemas
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=87" title="Edit section: Cinemas">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       There are three cinemas:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The
        <i>
         Cinema Gaumont Amiens
        </i>
        (12 rooms, 2,700 seats) was inaugurated in September 2005. Located just steps from the
        <a href="/wiki/Gare_d%27Amiens" title="Gare d'Amiens">
         Amiens railway station
        </a>
        , it has a large lobby and a 600-seat room. A 500-space car park is located under the cinema. It is the work of the architects
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Atelier_d%27architecture_Chaix_%26_Morel_et_associ%C3%A9s&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Atelier d'architecture Chaix &amp; Morel et associés (page does not exist)">
         Philippe Chaix and Jean-Paul Morel
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atelier_d%27architecture_Chaix_%26_Morel_et_associ%C3%A9s" title="fr:Atelier d'architecture Chaix &amp; Morel et associés">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        and its interior decoration was entrusted to
        <a href="/wiki/Christian_Lacroix" title="Christian Lacroix">
         Christian Lacroix
        </a>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155">
         <a href="#cite_note-155">
          [141]
         </a>
        </sup>
        In
        <a href="/wiki/2011_in_film" title="2011 in film">
         2011
        </a>
        , this multiplex received 887,000 cinemagoers.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156">
         <a href="#cite_note-156">
          [142]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <i>
         Cine-Saint-Leu
        </i>
        (one room with 250 seats) was inaugurated in October 2000,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157">
         <a href="#cite_note-157">
          [143]
         </a>
        </sup>
        after the closure of the Regent Cinema located near the railway station. An
        <a href="/wiki/Art_film" title="Art film">
         arthouse
        </a>
        cinema, it is part of the major cultural facilities of the Cathedral Centre. Its eclectic and cinephile programming offers the possibility to see the
        <a href="/wiki/Dubbing_(filmmaking)#France" title="Dubbing (filmmaking)">
         original version
        </a>
        of contemporary films.
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <i>
         Studio Orson Welles
        </i>
        (one room with 180 seats in the
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Maison_de_la_culture_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Maison de la culture d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
         Maison de la culture d'Amiens
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maison_de_la_culture_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Maison de la culture d'Amiens">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        ). An arthouse cinema operated by the
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Maison_de_la_culture_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Maison de la culture d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
         Maison de la culture d'Amiens
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maison_de_la_culture_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Maison de la culture d'Amiens">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        , it offers arthouse films as well as retrospectives of great names of the seventh art, old or contemporary.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158">
         <a href="#cite_note-158">
          [144]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cultural_events_and_festivals">
        Cultural events and festivals
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=88" title="Edit section: Cultural events and festivals">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Throughout the year, Amiens is the seat of many cultural, traditional or economic events.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Royal_de_luxe_%C3%A0_Amiens_en_2005.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="750" data-file-width="1000" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Royal_de_luxe_%C3%A0_Amiens_en_2005.jpg/220px-Royal_de_luxe_%C3%A0_Amiens_en_2005.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Royal_de_luxe_%C3%A0_Amiens_en_2005.jpg/330px-Royal_de_luxe_%C3%A0_Amiens_en_2005.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Royal_de_luxe_%C3%A0_Amiens_en_2005.jpg/440px-Royal_de_luxe_%C3%A0_Amiens_en_2005.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Royal_de_luxe_%C3%A0_Amiens_en_2005.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_de_luxe" title="Royal de luxe">
          Royal de luxe
         </a>
         company during the 28th
         <i>
          Fête dans la ville
         </i>
         in 2005.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>

       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">

        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hortillonnagesdamiens2010.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <i>
          Festival Art
         </i>
         , city and landscape in the Hortillonnages
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Amiens_Cath%C3%A9drale_Spectacle_190908_05.jpg">

        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
