         )
        </span>
        , film of
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Am%C3%A9lie_Van_Elmbt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Amélie Van Elmbt (page does not exist)">
         Amélie Van Elmbt
        </a>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Amiens_and_comics">
        Amiens and comics
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=92" title="Edit section: Amiens and comics">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Amiens is a stronghold of
       <a href="/wiki/Comics" title="Comics">
        comics
       </a>
       in France. A whole generation of designers and Amiens writers make the city an important creative centre of the
       <a href="/wiki/Classificatory_disputes_about_art" title="Classificatory disputes about art">
        9th art
       </a>
       . The main actors in this generation, include
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=R%C3%A9gis_Hauti%C3%A8re&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Régis Hautière (page does not exist)">
        Régis Hautière
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/R%C3%A9gis_Hauti%C3%A8re" title="fr:Régis Hautière">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Nor%C3%A9dine_Allam&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Norédine Allam (page does not exist)">
        Norédine Allam
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nor%C3%A9dine_Allam" title="fr:Norédine Allam">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       who notably led the recolouring of the 33
       <a href="/wiki/Asterix" title="Asterix">
        Asterix
       </a>
       albums in the framework of the project "The great collection" and also
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Antoine_Dod%C3%A9&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Antoine Dodé (page does not exist)">
        Antoine Dodé
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antoine_Dod%C3%A9" title="fr:Antoine Dodé">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=David_Fran%C3%A7ois_(comic_artist)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="David François (comic artist) (page does not exist)">
        David François
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Fran%C3%A7ois_(dessinateur)" title="fr:David François (dessinateur)">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , Fraco,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Hardoc&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Hardoc (page does not exist)">
        Hardoc
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hardoc" title="fr:Hardoc">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , Greg Blondin, Nicolas Hitori De, etc.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177">
        <a href="#cite_note-177">
         [163]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The city was also the birthplace or home of big names in the comic strip universe, such as the Amiens native
       <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Pinchon" title="Joseph Pinchon">
        Joseph Pinchon
       </a>
       , creator of the character of
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/B%C3%A9cassine" title="Bécassine">
         Bécassine
        </a>
       </i>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Paul_Gillon" title="Paul Gillon">
        Paul Gillon
       </a>
       , winner of the
       <a href="/wiki/Grand_Prix_de_la_ville_d%27Angoul%C3%AAme" title="Grand Prix de la ville d'Angoulême">
        Grand Prix de la ville d'Angoulême
       </a>
       and also
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Philippe_Thirault&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Philippe Thirault (page does not exist)">
        Philippe Thirault
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philippe_Thirault" title="fr:Philippe Thirault">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Actor of this dynamic around the
       <abbr title="Bande dessinée (comic strip)">
        BD
       </abbr>
       , the association
       <i>
        On a marché sur la bulle
       </i>
       [Explorers on the bubble] organises the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Rendez-vous_de_la_bande_dessin%C3%A9e_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Rendez-vous de la bande dessinée d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
        Rendez-vous de la bande dessinée d'Amiens
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rendez-vous_de_la_bande_dessin%C3%A9e_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Rendez-vous de la bande dessinée d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , one of the greatest French
       <a href="/wiki/Comic_book_convention" title="Comic book convention">
        comic book festivals
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178">
        <a href="#cite_note-178">
         [164]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Active throughout the territory, the structure also manages a resource centre and has an editorial department with the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%89ditions_de_la_Goutti%C3%A8re&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Éditions de la Gouttière (page does not exist)">
        Éditions de la Gouttière
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89ditions_de_la_Goutti%C3%A8re" title="fr:Éditions de la Gouttière">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Regional_culture">
        Regional culture
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=93" title="Edit section: Regional culture">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Picard_language" title="Picard language">
        Picard language
       </a>
       and [[:
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Literature_in_Picard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Literature in Picard (page does not exist)">
        Literature in Picard
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Litt%C3%A9rature_en_picard" title="fr:Littérature en picard">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ]]
      </div>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A9s_Cabotans" title="Chés Cabotans">
          Chés Cabotans
         </a>
         d'Anmien
        </i>
        or the
        <i>
         Cabotins of Amiens
        </i>
        is a small Picardy traditional puppet theatre founded in 1933.
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Lafleur_(marionnette)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Lafleur (marionnette) (page does not exist)">
         Lafleur
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lafleur_(marionnette)" title="fr:Lafleur (marionnette)">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        , the hero, was created around 1811 at
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Saint-Leu_(Amiens)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Saint-Leu (Amiens) (page does not exist)">
         Saint-Leu
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saint-Leu_(Amiens)" title="fr:Saint-Leu (Amiens)">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        . He talks in
        <a href="/wiki/Picard_language" title="Picard language">
         Picard
        </a>
        , exclusively. Traditionally a lackey costume (wearing a red velvet
        <a href="/wiki/Tricorne" title="Tricorne">
         tricorne
        </a>
        hat) dressed, Lafleur is cheerful, dynamic, independent and resourceful; its motto is:
        <i>
         "bin mier, bin boere, pis did rin foere!"
        </i>
        (Drink well, eat well and then do nothing).
       </li>
       <li>
        The Picard language is recognised
        <a href="/wiki/Regional_language" title="Regional language">
         regional language
        </a>
        . It is spoken in France in the
        <a href="/wiki/Picardy" title="Picardy">
         Picardy
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Nord-Pas-de-Calais" title="Nord-Pas-de-Calais">
         Nord-Pas-de-Calais
        </a>
        regions, and in Belgium in the Province of
        <a href="/wiki/Hainaut_(province)" title="Hainaut (province)">
         Hainaut
        </a>
        . Various associations work for the promotion and development of Picardy culture expressed in theatre, song, in spoken tales but also in writing: Novels, journals, poetry, etc. Since 1993, the
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Conseil_r%C3%A9gional_de_Picardie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Conseil régional de Picardie (page does not exist)">
         Conseil régional de Picardie
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conseil_r%C3%A9gional_de_Picardie" title="fr:Conseil régional de Picardie">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        has developed within the "Office Culturel Régional de Picardie" a cultural policy for the language and the Picardy culture. "The Agency for Picard", created in 2008, is headquartered in Amiens.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179">
         <a href="#cite_note-179">
          [165]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <a href="/wiki/Picard_language" title="Picard language">
         Picard
        </a>
        is taught at the
        <a href="/wiki/University_of_Picardie_Jules_Verne" title="University of Picardie Jules Verne">
         University of Amiens
        </a>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <i>
         blasons populaires
        </i>
        are surnames or the nicknames given to the inhabitants of cities and the Picardy villages. These
        <i>
         surpitchets
        </i>
        sometimes come from the history of the city, sometimes a verbal game, sometimes through a mockery of people. The nickname of the inhabitants of Amiens is:
        <i>
         Chés Maqueus d'gueugues d'Anmien
        </i>
        [Amiens nut eaters] in reference to an episode of the Spanish invasion. On 11 March 1597, the Spanish armies developed a ploy to seize the city: The soldiers of Hernán Tello de Portocarrero, Governor of
        <a href="/wiki/Doullens" title="Doullens">
         Doullens
        </a>
        , disguised as peasants, came to the gates of the walls with nuts. The Amiens hungry then opened the doors and the Spaniards took the city.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Gastronomic_specialities">
        Gastronomic specialities
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=94" title="Edit section: Gastronomic specialities">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       During December, the town hosts the largest
       <a href="/wiki/Christmas_market" title="Christmas market">
        Christmas market
       </a>
       in northern France.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-waterways_180-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-waterways-180">
         [166]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Amiens, in the image of the Picardy region, has a rich gastronomic heritage.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181">
        <a href="#cite_note-181">
         [167]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Here are some of the specialities:
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182">
        <a href="#cite_note-182">
         [168]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Amiens is known for a few local foods, including "
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Macarons_d%27Amiens" title="Macarons d'Amiens">
        macarons d'Amiens
       </a>
       ", small, round-shaped biscuit-type macaroons made from
       <a href="/wiki/Almond_paste" title="Almond paste">
        almond paste
       </a>
       , fruit and honey, which were first recorded in 1855;
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183">
        <a href="#cite_note-183">
         [169]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Tuile_d%27Amiens_au_chocolat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Tuile d'Amiens au chocolat (page does not exist)">
        "tuiles amienoises"
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tuile_d%27Amiens_au_chocolat" title="fr:Tuile d'Amiens au chocolat">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , chocolate and orange curved "
       <a href="/wiki/Tuile" title="Tuile">
        tuiles
       </a>
       " or biscuits;
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=P%C3%A2t%C3%A9_de_canard_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Pâté de canard d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
        Pâté de canard d'Amiens
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/P%C3%A2t%C3%A9_de_canard_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Pâté de canard d'Amiens">
         fr
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       - duck pate in pastry, made since the 17th century;
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184">
        <a href="#cite_note-184">
         [170]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and "la
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Ficelle_Picarde&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Ficelle Picarde (page does not exist)">
        ficelle Picarde
       </a>
       ", an oven-baked cheese-topped
       <a href="/wiki/Cr%C3%AApe" title="Crêpe">
        crêpe
       </a>
       with ham and mushroom filling,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-waterways_180-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-waterways-180">
         [166]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185">
        <a href="#cite_note-185">
         [171]
        </a>
       </sup>
       then topped with fresh cream flavoured with nutmeg, white pepper, and sprinkled with grated cheese before being browned in the oven. The region is also known for "
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flamiche_aux_poireaux" title="Flamiche aux poireaux">
        flamiche aux poireaux
       </a>
       ", a puff pastry tart made with leeks and cream.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186">
        <a href="#cite_note-186">
         [172]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Other dishes include:
      </p>
      <div class="div-col columns column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em;">
       <ul>
        <li>
         The soup des hortillons: A spring soup which, as its name suggests, originated in the
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Hortillonnages_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Hortillonnages d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
          hortillonnages
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hortillonnages_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Hortillonnages d'Amiens">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         and their vegetable wealth.
        </li>
        <li>
         The bisteu or bigalan: Potatoes, onions and bacon pie.
        </li>
        <li>
         The
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Andouillette_ami%C3%A9noise&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Andouillette amiénoise (page does not exist)">
          Andouillette amiénoise
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andouillette_ami%C3%A9noise" title="fr:Andouillette amiénoise">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         : Pork dumpling mixed with a panade and onions.
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Beignet_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Beignet d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
          Beignet d'Amiens
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beignet_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Beignet d'Amiens">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         so-called
         <i>
          pets d'âne
         </i>
         [donkey pets]: Small round doughnuts and fried fresh goat's cheese and beef marrow.
        </li>
        <li>
         The
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=G%C3%A2teau_battu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Gâteau battu (page does not exist)">
          Gâteau battu
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/G%C3%A2teau_battu" title="fr:Gâteau battu">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         : Golden yellow brioche crumbs and with an aerated texture, it is rich in eggs and butter.
        </li>
        <li>
         The galopin: A
         <a href="/wiki/French_toast" title="French toast">
          French toast
         </a>
         made from brioche bread cooked like a big pancake.
        </li>
        <li>
         The Picardy rabotte: Apple wrapped and baked in a puff pastry.
        </li>
        <li>
         The Dariole of Amiens: A popular pastry from the 18th century, topped with a cream with almonds.
        </li>
        <li>
         Amiens barley sugar.
        </li>
       </ul>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Rambo_apple#Summer_Rambo" title="Rambo apple">
        Summer Rambo
       </a>
       apple cultivar originated near Amiens in the 16th century.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Personalities_and_athletes_linked_to_the_commune">
        Personalities and athletes linked to the commune
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=95" title="Edit section: Personalities and athletes linked to the commune">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Personalities_linked_to_the_commune">
        Personalities linked to the commune
       </span>

         [
        </span>

         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>

      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Portrait_Najat_Vallaud-Belkacem-crop.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="599" data-file-width="462" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Portrait_Najat_Vallaud-Belkacem-crop.jpg/170px-Portrait_Najat_Vallaud-Belkacem-crop.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Portrait_Najat_Vallaud-Belkacem-crop.jpg/255px-Portrait_Najat_Vallaud-Belkacem-crop.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Portrait_Najat_Vallaud-Belkacem-crop.jpg/340px-Portrait_Najat_Vallaud-Belkacem-crop.jpg 2x" width="170"/>

          </a>
         </div>
         The minister
         <a href="/wiki/Najat_Vallaud-Belkacem" title="Najat Vallaud-Belkacem">
          Najat Vallaud-Belkacem
         </a>
         in June 2012
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="div-col columns column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em;">
       <ul>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Magnentius" title="Magnentius">
          Magnentius
         </a>
         (303-11 August 353), usurper of the imperial title 18 January 350 to 11 August 353
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saint_Anschar" title="Saint Anschar">
          Ansgar
         </a>
         (8 September 801-3 February 865 at
         <a href="/wiki/Bremen" title="Bremen">
          Bremen
         </a>
         ), known as Oscar or
         <a href="/wiki/Ansgar" title="Ansgar">
          Ansgar
         </a>
         , evangeliser of
         <a href="/wiki/Scandinavia" title="Scandinavia">
          Scandinavia
         </a>
         , Ansgar is the patron saint of
         <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">
          Denmark
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Peter_the_Hermit" title="Peter the Hermit">
          Peter the Hermit
         </a>
         (?-1115), preacher of the
         <a href="/wiki/First_Crusade" title="First Crusade">
          First Crusade
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Andr%C3%A9_d%27Ypres&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="André d'Ypres (page does not exist)">
          André d'Ypres
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_d%27Ypres" title="fr:André d'Ypres">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         , (before 1428-1450), painter and
         <a href="/wiki/Illuminated_manuscript" title="Illuminated manuscript">
          illuminator
         </a>
         ;
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=La_Crucifixion_du_Parlement_de_Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="La Crucifixion du Parlement de Paris (page does not exist)">
          <i>
           La Crucifixion du Parlement de Paris
          </i>
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_Crucifixion_du_Parlement_de_Paris" title="fr:La Crucifixion du Parlement de Paris">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         is attributed to him
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Simon_Marmion" title="Simon Marmion">
          Simon Marmion
         </a>
         (1425-1489), painter and
         <a href="/wiki/Illuminated_manuscript" title="Illuminated manuscript">
          illuminator
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Michel_de_Vascosan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Michel de Vascosan (page does not exist)">
          Michel de Vascosan
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michel_de_Vascosan" title="fr:Michel de Vascosan">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         (1500-1576),
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Imprimer_du_roi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Imprimer du roi (page does not exist)">
          king's printer
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/imprimeur_du_roi" title="fr:imprimeur du roi">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         and the
         <a href="/wiki/University_of_Paris" title="University of Paris">
          University of Paris
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Bookselling" title="Bookselling">
          bookseller
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Jean_Bullant" title="Jean Bullant">
          Jean Bullant
         </a>
         (1515-1578), architect notably of the
         <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_d%27%C3%89couen" title="Château d'Écouen">
          Château d'Écouen
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Dubois" title="François Dubois">
          François Dubois
         </a>
         (1529-1584),

         </a>
         (1828-1905), city councillor from 1888 to his death, and before all a writer known to all; he rests in the
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Cimeti%C3%A8re_de_La_Madeleine_(Amiens)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Cimetière de La Madeleine (Amiens) (page does not exist)">
          Cemetery of La Madeleine
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cimeti%C3%A8re_de_La_Madeleine_(Amiens)" title="fr:Cimetière de La Madeleine (Amiens)">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>

          <a href="#cite_note-189">
           [note 5]
          </a>
         </sup>

         </a>

         </span>

      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Sportspeople_linked_to_the_commune">

        </span>

        </a>

        </span>

       <ul>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Pierre_Baruzy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Pierre Baruzy (page does not exist)">
          Pierre Baruzy
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierre_Baruzy" title="fr:Pierre Baruzy">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         , (1897-1994), boxer and
         <a href="/wiki/Savate" title="Savate">
          Savate
         </a>
         coach; between 1922 and 1935, he was crowned 11 times as middleweight champion of France
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Urbain_Wallet" title="Urbain Wallet">
          Urbain Wallet
         </a>
         , (1899-1973), footballer, played in team of France
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Robert_Marchand_(cyclist)" title="Robert Marchand (cyclist)">
          Robert Marchand
         </a>
         , (1911-), world record holder of the fastest centenarian cycling 100 km
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Letourneur" title="Alfred Letourneur">
          Alfred Letourneur
         </a>
         , (1907-1975),
         <a href="/wiki/Cycle_sport" title="Cycle sport">
          racing cyclist
         </a>
         ,
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cycling_records" title="Cycling records">
          world speed record holder of bicycle on flat ground and behind shelter
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Georges_Vallerey" title="Georges Vallerey">
          Georges Vallerey
         </a>
         , (1927-1954), swimmer of backstroke events, freestyle; 3×100m triple medley world record holder in 1946, bronze medal in 100m backstroke at the
         <a href="/wiki/1948_Summer_Olympics" title="1948 Summer Olympics">
          1948 Summer Olympics
         </a>
         in London
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Jack_Braun&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Jack Braun (page does not exist)">

        </li>

         , (1983-), footballer
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Yannick_Salem" title="Yannick Salem">
          Yannick Salem
         </a>
         , (1983-), footballer
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/K%C3%A9vin_Hecquefeuille" title="Kévin Hecquefeuille">
          Kévin Hecquefeuille
         </a>
         , (1984-), hockey player, played in team of France
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Lucie_Louette&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Lucie Louette (page does not exist)">
          Lucie Louette
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucie_Louette" title="fr:Lucie Louette">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         , (1985-), judoka,
         <a href="/wiki/2013_European_Judo_Championships" title="2013 European Judo Championships">
          2013 champion of Europe
         </a>
         in the under 78 kg (172 lb) category
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Roussel" title="Thomas Roussel">
          Thomas Roussel
         </a>
         , (1985-), hockey player, played in team of France
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Brian_Henderson_(ice_hockey)" title="Brian Henderson (ice hockey)">
          Brian Henderson
         </a>
         , (1986-), hockey player, played in team of France
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Morgane_Ribout&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Morgane Ribout (page does not exist)">
          Morgane Ribout
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morgane_Ribout" title="fr:Morgane Ribout">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>

         <a href="/wiki/2009_World_Judo_Championships" title="2009 World Judo Championships">
          2009 champion of the world
         </a>
         in the under 57 kg (126 lb) category, trained in part at the "pôle Espoirs" of Amiens
        </li>
        <li>

         </a>
         , (1988-),

          canoeist
         </a>
         , double champion of Europe's canoe single-seater, bronze medallist at the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_ICF_Canoe_Slalom_World_Championships_medalists_in_women%27s_Canadian" title="List of ICF Canoe Slalom World Championships medalists in women's Canadian">
          World Championships
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Pierre_Soudry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Pierre Soudry (page does not exist)">
          Pierre Soudry
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">

          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierre_Soudry" title="fr:Pierre Soudry">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         , (1988-),
         <a href="/wiki/Handball" title="Handball">
          handball
         </a>
         player
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Lo%C3%AFc_Korval" title="Loïc Korval">

         </a>
         , (1988-), judoka,
         <a href="/wiki/2014_European_Judo_Championships" title="2014 European Judo Championships">
          2014 champion of Europe
         </a>
         , the World Championships bronze medallist in the category of less than 66 kg (146 lb), trained in part at the "pôle Espoirs" of Amiens
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=P%C3%A9n%C3%A9lope_Bonna&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Pénélope Bonna (page does not exist)">
          Pénélope Bonna
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">

      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Other_personalities_linked_to_the_city">
        Other personalities linked to the city
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=98" title="Edit section: Other personalities linked to the city">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="div-col columns column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em;">
       <ul>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Martin_of_Tours" title="Martin of Tours">
          Saint Martin
         </a>
         , Roman soldier, shared his coat with a beggar in Amiens in a gesture which has been remembered
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Honoratus_of_Amiens" title="Honoratus of Amiens">
          Saint Honoré
         </a>
         , Bishop of
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bishopric_of_Amiens" title="Bishopric of Amiens">
          Amiens
         </a>
         and Patron Saint of
         <a href="/wiki/Baker" title="Baker">
          bakers
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A9s_Cabotans" title="Chés Cabotans">
          Lafleur
         </a>
         , hero and main character of puppet Amiens "Chés cabotans".
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Jean-Marie_Roland,_vicomte_de_la_Plati%C3%A8re" title="Jean-Marie Roland, vicomte de la Platière">
          Jean-Marie Roland de La Platière
         </a>
         (1734-1793), Economist and statesman, lived in Amiens and was Inspector of factories in the city
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Antoine-Augustin_Parmentier" title="Antoine-Augustin Parmentier">
          Antoine Parmentier
         </a>
         , (1737-1813), military
         <a href="/wiki/Pharmacist" title="Pharmacist">
          pharmacist
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Agricultural_engineering" title="Agricultural engineering">
          agronomist
         </a>
         , nutritionist and hygienist. Member of the Academy of sciences of Amiens,
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194">
          <a href="#cite_note-194">
           [179]
          </a>
         </sup>
         he popularized the consumption of
         <a href="/wiki/Potato" title="Potato">
          potatoes
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Delille" title="Jacques Delille">
          Jacques Delille
         </a>
         or Abbé Delille, (1738-1813), poet and translator, a member of the French Academy, was a professor at the college of Amiens
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Lamarck" title="Jean-Baptiste Lamarck">
          Jean-Baptiste Lamarck
         </a>
         (1744-1829),
         <a href="/wiki/Natural_history" title="Natural history">
          naturalist
         </a>
         who laid the foundations of the
         <a href="/wiki/Objections_to_evolution" title="Objections to evolution">
          theory of the evolution of species
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Cousin_de_Grainville" title="Jean-Baptiste Cousin de Grainville">
          Jean-Baptiste Cousin de Grainville
         </a>
         , (1746-1805), philosopher, poet, priest in Amiens and pioneer of fantasy literature
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Madame_Roland" title="Madame Roland">
          Madame Roland
         </a>
         (1754-1793), figure of the
         <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">
          French Revolution
         </a>
         , face of the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Girondist" title="Girondist">
          Girondist
         </a>
         party, lived in Amiens
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Marguerite_Georges" title="Marguerite Georges">
          Marguerite Georges
         </a>
         , (1787-1867), famous actress, lived at Amiens and began her career there
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Jean-Baptiste_Jacquenet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Jean-Baptiste Jacquenet (page does not exist)">
          Bishop Jacquenet
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Jacquenet" title="fr:Jean-Baptiste Jacquenet">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         , (1816-1892), Bishop of Amiens
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Antoine_Louis_de_Romance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Antoine Louis de Romance (page does not exist)">
          Antoine Louis de Romance
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antoine_Louis_de_Romance" title="fr:Antoine Louis de Romance">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         , (1819-1881), Counsellor at the
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Cour_d%27appel_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Cour d'appel d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
          Court of Appeal of Amiens
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cour_d%27appel_d%27Amiens" title="fr:Cour d'appel d'Amiens">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Camille_L%C3%A9on_de_Chassepot_de_Beaumont&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Camille Léon de Chassepot de Beaumont (page does not exist)">
          Camille Léon de Chassepot de Beaumont
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camille_L%C3%A9on_de_Chassepot_de_Beaumont" title="fr:Camille Léon de Chassepot de Beaumont">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         , (1808-1893),
         <a href="/wiki/Colonel" title="Colonel">
          colonel
         </a>
         in the
         <a href="/wiki/National_Guard_(France)#National_Guard_following_1831" title="National Guard (France)">
          National Guard
         </a>
         who, under his command, distinguished himself on 17 November 1870
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195">
          <a href="#cite_note-195">
           [180]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Jules_Joseph_Lefebvre" title="Jules Joseph Lefebvre">
          Jules Lefebvre
         </a>
         , (1836-1911),
         <a href="/wiki/Painting" title="Painting">
          painter
         </a>
         , student of the
         <a href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_nationale_sup%C3%A9rieure_des_Beaux-Arts" title="École nationale supérieure des Beaux-Arts">
          École nationale supérieure des Beaux-Arts
         </a>
         of Amiens
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196">
          <a href="#cite_note-196">
           [181]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Athanase_Foss%C3%A9&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Athanase Fossé (page does not exist)">
          Athanase Fossé
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athanase_Foss%C3%A9" title="fr:Athanase Fossé">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         , (1851-1923),
         <a href="/wiki/Sculpture" title="Sculpture">
          sculptor
         </a>
         , student of the
         <a href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_nationale_sup%C3%A9rieure_des_Beaux-Arts" title="École nationale supérieure des Beaux-Arts">
          École des beaux-arts
         </a>
         of Amiens
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B3n_Sveinsson" title="Jón Sveinsson">
          Jón Sveinsson
         </a>
         (nicknamed "Nonni"), (1857-1944), Icelandic priest and author of popular children's books, studied and did his
         <a href="/wiki/Novitiate" title="Novitiate">
          novitiate
         </a>
         in Amiens
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Auguste_Perret" title="Auguste Perret">
          Auguste Perret
         </a>
         , (1874-1954), architect, creator of the
         <a href="/wiki/Tour_Perret_(Amiens)" title="Tour Perret (Amiens)">
          Tour Perret
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Jean_Moulin" title="Jean Moulin">
          Jean Moulin
         </a>
         (1899-1943),
         <a href="/wiki/Prefect_(France)" title="Prefect (France)">
          prefect
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/French_Resistance" title="French Resistance">
          resistant
         </a>
         , was Secretary general of the prefecture of Somme
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Philippe_Leclerc_de_Hauteclocque" title="Philippe Leclerc de Hauteclocque">
          Philippe Leclerc de Hauteclocque
         </a>
         (1902-1947),
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marshal_of_France" title="Marshal of France">
          Marshal of France
         </a>
         , began his studies at the college of the
         <i>
          Providence
         </i>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197">
          <a href="#cite_note-197">
           [182]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Manessier" title="Alfred Manessier">
          Alfred Manessier
         </a>
         , (1911-1993),
         <a href="/wiki/Painting" title="Painting">
          painter
         </a>
         , pupil of the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_nationale_sup%C3%A9rieure_des_beaux-arts" title="École nationale supérieure des beaux-arts">
          École des beaux-arts
         </a>
         of Amiens
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Mallet_(writer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Robert Mallet (writer) (page does not exist)">
          Robert Mallet
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Mallet_(%C3%A9crivain)" title="fr:Robert Mallet (écrivain)">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         , (1915-2002), civil servant, writer and man of French radio, founder and Rector of the
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Acad%C3%A9mie_d%27Amiens_(education)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Académie d'Amiens (education) (page does not exist)">
          Academy of Amiens
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acad%C3%A9mie_d%27Amiens_(%C3%A9ducation)" title="fr:Académie d'Amiens (éducation)">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Le_Goff" title="Jacques Le Goff">
          Jacques Le Goff
         </a>
         , (1924-2014), medievalist historian, he taught at the
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Lyc%C3%A9e_Louis-Thuillier&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Lycée Louis-Thuillier (page does not exist)">
          Lycée Louis-Thuillier
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyc%C3%A9e_Louis-Thuillier" title="fr:Lycée Louis-Thuillier">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Alain_Bombard" title="Alain Bombard">
          Alain Bombard
         </a>
         , (1924-2005), medical biologist and navigator, lived in Amiens for twenty years
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_Cr%C3%A9pin" title="André Crépin">
          André Crépin
         </a>
         (1928-2013), essayist, linguist and medievalist, Member of the
         <a href="/wiki/Acad%C3%A9mie_des_Inscriptions_et_Belles-Lettres" title="Académie des Inscriptions et Belles-Lettres">
          Académie des Inscriptions et Belles-Lettres
         </a>
         , lived in Amiens
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Gilbert_Richard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Gilbert Richard (page does not exist)">
          Gilbert Richard
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gilbert_Richard" title="fr:Gilbert Richard">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         , (1928-), television producer and host on the first television channel (1960-1992)
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Volkoff" title="Vladimir Volkoff">
          Vladimir Volkoff
         </a>
         , (1932-2005), writer, lived in Amiens
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/St%C3%A9phane_Le_Foll" title="Stéphane Le Foll">
          Stéphane Le Foll
         </a>
         , (1960-),
         <a href="/wiki/Politician" title="Politician">
          politician
         </a>
         , Minister of agriculture in
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ayrault_Government" title="Ayrault Government">
          Jean-Marc Ayrault I and II
         </a>
         ,
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_Valls_Government" title="First Valls Government">
          Manuel Valls I
         </a>
         and
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_Valls_Government" title="Second Valls Government">
          II
         </a>
         Governments, graduated from the agricultural college of Amiens Le Paraclet
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Catherine_Matausch&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Catherine Matausch (page does not exist)">
          Catherine Matausch
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catherine_Matausch" title="fr:Catherine Matausch">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         , (1960-), journalist, presented the regional journal on
         <a href="/wiki/France_3_Picardie" title="France 3 Picardie">
          France 3 Picardie
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Gr%C3%A9goire_Delacourt" title="Grégoire Delacourt">
          Grégoire Delacourt
         </a>
         , (1960-), writer, had part of his studies at the school of Providence in Amiens
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Thierry_Adam&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Thierry Adam (page does not exist)">
          Thierry Adam
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thierry_Adam" title="fr:Thierry Adam">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         , (1967-), sports journalist, resides in Amiens
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Fr%C3%A9d%C3%A9ric_Cuvillier" title="Frédéric Cuvillier">
          Frédéric Cuvillier
         </a>
         , (1968-),
         <a href="/wiki/Politician" title="Politician">
          politician
         </a>
         , Deputy
         <a href="/wiki/Minister_of_Transport_(France)" title="Minister of Transport (France)">
          Minister of transport and maritime economy
         </a>
         in
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ayrault_Government" title="Ayrault Government">
          Jean-Marc Ayrault I and II
         </a>
         ,
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_Valls_Government" title="First Valls Government">
          Manuel Valls I
         </a>
         Governments, graduated in law at the
         <a href="/wiki/University_of_Picardie_Jules_Verne" title="University of Picardie Jules Verne">
          University of Picardy
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Pascale_Boistard" title="Pascale Boistard">
          Pascale Boistard
         </a>
         , (1971-),
         <a href="/wiki/Politician" title="Politician">
          politician
         </a>
         ,
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Women%27s_Affairs_(France)" title="Ministry of Women's Affairs (France)">
          Secretary of State for the rights of women
         </a>
         in the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_Valls_Government" title="Second Valls Government">
          Second Valls Government
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_(France)" title="National Assembly (France)">
          Member of Parliament
         </a>
         for the
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Premi%C3%A8re_circonscription_de_la_Somme&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Première circonscription de la Somme (page does not exist)">
          1st electoral district of the Somme
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Premi%C3%A8re_circonscription_de_la_Somme" title="fr:Première circonscription de la Somme">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         (Northern Amiens)
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Biolay" title="Benjamin Biolay">
          Benjamin Biolay
         </a>
         , (1973-),
         <a href="/wiki/Singer-songwriter" title="Singer-songwriter">
          singer-songwriter
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Singing" title="Singing">
          singer
         </a>
         , lived in Amiens
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198">
          <a href="#cite_note-198">
           [183]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Miss_Kittin" title="Miss Kittin">
          Miss Kittin
         </a>
         (Caroline Hervé), (1973-),
         <a href="/wiki/Disc_jockey" title="Disc jockey">
          DJ
         </a>
         star of the
         <a href="/wiki/Electro_(music)" title="Electro (music)">
          electro
         </a>
         scene, studied at the
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%89cole_sup%C3%A9rieure_d%27art_et_de_design_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="École supérieure d'art et de design d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
          school of art and design of Amiens
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89cole_sup%C3%A9rieure_d%27art_et_de_design_d%27Amiens" title="fr:École supérieure d'art et de design d'Amiens">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Fabrice_%C3%89bou%C3%A9&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Fabrice Éboué (page does not exist)">
          Fabrice Éboué
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fabrice_%C3%89bou%C3%A9" title="fr:Fabrice Éboué">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         , (1977-),
         <a href="/wiki/Comedian" title="Comedian">
          comedian
         </a>
         and actor, has made part of his studies at the school of Providence in Amiens
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/%C3%89lodie_Gossuin" title="Élodie Gossuin">
          Élodie Gossuin-Lacherie
         </a>
         , (1980-),
         <a href="/wiki/Television_presenter" title="Television presenter">
          television presenter
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Radio_personality" title="Radio personality">
          radio host
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Miss_France" title="Miss France">
          Miss France
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Miss_Europe" title="Miss Europe">
          Miss Europe
         </a>
         2001, registered at the
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Conseil_r%C3%A9gional_de_Picardie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Conseil régional de Picardie (page does not exist)">
          Picardy regional Council
         </a>
         <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
          (
          <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conseil_r%C3%A9gional_de_Picardie" title="fr:Conseil régional de Picardie">
           fr
          </a>
          )
         </span>
         since 2004.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199">
          <a href="#cite_note-199">
           [184]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Nicolas_Duvauchelle" title="Nicolas Duvauchelle">
          Nicolas Duvauchelle
         </a>
         , (1980-),
         <a href="/wiki/Actor" title="Actor">
          actor
         </a>
         and model, has lived in Amiens.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blondeau_2011_200-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-Blondeau_2011-200">
           [185]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/%C3%89douard_Louis" title="Édouard Louis">
          Édouard Louis
         </a>
         , (1992-), writer and academic, studied at the Lycée Madeleine Michelis and the
         <a href="/wiki/University_of_Picardie_Jules_Verne" title="University of Picardie Jules Verne">
          University of Picardy
         </a>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span id="Heraldry.2C_logo_and_motto">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Heraldry,_logo_and_motto">
        Heraldry, logo and motto
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=99" title="Edit section: Heraldry, logo and motto">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <table class="wikitable">
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:center;padding:5px 8px;width:120px;">
         <div class="center">
          <div class="floatnone">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Blason_fr_ville_Amiens.svg" title="Arms of Amiens">
            <img alt="Arms of Amiens" data-file-height="660" data-file-width="600" height="132" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Blason_fr_ville_Amiens.svg/120px-Blason_fr_ville_Amiens.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Blason_fr_ville_Amiens.svg/180px-Blason_fr_ville_Amiens.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Blason_fr_ville_Amiens.svg/240px-Blason_fr_ville_Amiens.svg.png 2x" width="120"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </td>
        <td style="vertical-align:top;">
         The arms of Amiens are
         <a href="/wiki/Blazon" title="Blazon">
          blazoned
         </a>
         :
         <br/>
         <i>
          "Of
          <a href="/wiki/Gules" title="Gules">
           gules
          </a>
          to ivy of argent, the chief
          <a href="/wiki/Azure_(heraldry)" title="Azure (heraldry)">
           azure
          </a>
          sown of fleurs-de-lis
          <a href="/wiki/Or_(heraldry)" title="Or (heraldry)">
           Or
          </a>
          ."
         </i>
         <br/>
         <br/>
         Motto: "Liliis tenaci vimine jungor",
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201">
          <a href="#cite_note-201">
           [186]
          </a>
         </sup>
         which means 'a strong bond unites the lilies'.
         <br/>
         <br/>
         Amiens, a fortress city, suffered attacks and resisted, staying French. Its coat of arms symbolise this attachment to France, commitment symbolised by ivy, the France being symbolised by the seedlings of fleurs-de-lis authorised by the Kings of France.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202">
          <a href="#cite_note-202">
           [187]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <p>
          <br/>
         </p>
         <p>
          <br/>
         </p>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <table class="wikitable">
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:center;padding:5px 8px;width:120px;">
         <div class="center">
          <div class="floatnone">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Armoirie_ville_fr_Amiens.svg">
            <img alt="Armoirie ville fr Amiens.svg" data-file-height="1684" data-file-width="1729" height="117" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Armoirie_ville_fr_Amiens.svg/120px-Armoirie_ville_fr_Amiens.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Armoirie_ville_fr_Amiens.svg/180px-Armoirie_ville_fr_Amiens.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Armoirie_ville_fr_Amiens.svg/240px-Armoirie_ville_fr_Amiens.svg.png 2x" width="120"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </td>
        <td style="vertical-align:top;">
         In the full arms of the city, holding and support are two unicorns, support is of acanthus leaves, while the
         <a href="/wiki/Crest_(heraldry)" title="Crest (heraldry)">
          crest
         </a>
         is a castle keep of five parts. The two figures emblazoned in the arms of Amiens are lily and ivy, which today still decorate the city logo. The unicorn is a symbol of the knightly virtues of purity and attraction to beauty and delicacy. Even today, the unicorn makes a number of references in the city: The
         <a href="/wiki/Stade_de_la_Licorne" title="Stade de la Licorne">
          eponymous stadium
         </a>
         , the coat of arms of the
         <a href="/wiki/Amiens_SC" title="Amiens SC">
          Amiens football team
         </a>
         as well as the award of the
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Festival_international_du_film_d%27Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Festival international du film d'Amiens (page does not exist)">
          Amiens International Film Festival
         </a>
         .
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203">
          <a href="#cite_note-203">
           [188]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <p>
          <br/>
         </p>
         <p>
          <br/>
         </p>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Logo of the city of Amiens
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       In 1991, the municipality formed around
       <a href="/wiki/Gilles_de_Robien" title="Gilles de Robien">
        Gilles de Robien
       </a>
       designed a new logo, incorporating the Fleur-de-lis and the Ivy leaf present on the coat of arms, placed side by side in red with a background of grey or white, depending on usage.
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        A
        <a href="/wiki/Postage_stamp" title="Postage stamp">
         stamp
        </a>
        representing the arms of the city was issued in 1962, this issue fitted into one of the
        <i>
         Arms of cities
        </i>
        . Its power of postage was five cents. It was issued on 23 January 1962 and withdrawn from sale on 23 January 1977. A
        <i>
         first day
        </i>
        was arranged in Amiens on 21 July 1962. It was designed by
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Louis_(architect)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Robert Louis (architect) (page does not exist)">
         Robert Louis
        </a>
        <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
         (
         <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Louis" title="fr:Robert Louis">
          fr
         </a>
         )
        </span>
        . Artist
        <a href="/wiki/Arman" title="Arman">
         Arman
        </a>
        made a board collage of this stamp.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204">
         <a href="#cite_note-204">
          [189]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ul>

         <p>
          <b>
           Education
          </b>
         </p>
         <ul>
          <li>
           <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Acad%C3%A9mie_d%27Amiens_(%C3%A9ducation)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Académie d'Amiens (éducation) (page does not exist)">
            Académie d'Amiens
           </a>
           <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
            (
            <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acad%C3%A9mie_d%27Amiens_(%C3%A9ducation)" title="fr:Académie d'Amiens (éducation)">
             fr
            </a>
            )
           </span>

            (
            <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/H%C3%B4tel_particulier_Bouct%C3%B4t_Vagniez" title="fr:Hôtel particulier Bouctôt Vagniez">

            </a>

      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">
        Notes
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amiens&amp;action=edit&amp;section=101" title="Edit section: Notes">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em; list-style-type: decimal;">
       <ol class="references">
        <li id="cite_note-17">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-17">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Work had also been delayed, because some people wanted to "preserve the cathedral", the situation was exceptional.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-43">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-43">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          At the beginning of the 21st century, the terms of census have been amended by
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/affichTexte.do?cidTexte=JORFTEXT000000593100&amp;fastPos=1&amp;fastReqId=2036940488&amp;categorieLien=cid&amp;oldAction=rechTexte" rel="nofollow">
           Act No. 2002-276 of 27 February 2002
          </a>
          , called "grassroots democracy law" on the democracy of proximity and in particular Title V "of census operations", in order, after a power transition period from 2004 to 2008, the annual publication of the legal population of the different French administrative districts. For municipalities with populations greater than 10,000 inhabitants, a sample survey is carried out annually, the entire territory of these municipalities is included at the end of the same period of five years. The first post-legal population from 1999, and fitting in the new system which came into force on 1 January 2009, is the census of 2006.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-44">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-44">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          In the census table, by Wikipedia convention, the principle was retained for subsequent legal populations since 1999 not to display the census populations in the table corresponding to the year 2006, the first published legal population calculated according to the concepts defined in Decree No. 2003-485 of 5 June 2003, and the years corresponding to an exhaustive census survey for municipalities with less than 10,000 inhabitants, and the years 2006, 2011, 2016, etc. For municipalities with more than 10,000, the latest legal population is published by INSEE for all municipalities.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-76">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-76">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          The concentration of employment indicator equals the number of jobs in the area per 100 people in active employment residing in the area, according to the
          <a href="/wiki/Institut_national_de_la_statistique_et_des_%C3%A9tudes_%C3%A9conomiques" title="Institut national de la statistique et des études économiques">
           Insee
          </a>
          definition.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-189">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-189">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          He lived for 18 years in a mansion located in Henriville, which includes an observatory atop a tower. His house, now classified as an Historical Monument, was acquired by the city of Amiens in 1980. Reopened on 24 March 2006 after a year of work, the Jules Verne House is a museum. The University of Picardie is called "Jules Verne". A viaduct east of the city and a lecture hall of ESIEE also bear his name.
         </span>
        </li>
       </ol>
      </div>

           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=courrier-picard.fr&amp;rft.atitle=AMIENS+Le+bus+%C3%A0+haut+niveau+de+service+avance&amp;rft.date=2014-12-19&amp;rft.aulast=Thi%C3%A9bault&amp;rft.aufirst=Estelle&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.courrier-picard.fr%2Fregion%2Famiens-le-bus-a-haut-niveau-de-service-avance-ia167b0n488910&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAmiens">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-bedel-14">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-bedel_14-0">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-bedel_14-1">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               b
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           Benoit Delespierre,
           <i>
            Longueau, l'autre gare d'Amiens
           </i>
           ,
           <i>
            <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Le_Courrier_picard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Le Courrier picard (page does not exist)">
             Courrier picard
            </a>
           </i>
           , 11 avril 2013.
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-15">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-15">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           This expression, which dates from before 2004, is due to a Socialist politician from the
           <a href="/wiki/Haute-Vienne" title="Haute-Vienne">
            Haute-Vienne
           </a>
           ,
           <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Jacques_Santrot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Jacques Santrot (page does not exist)">
            Jacques Santrot
           </a>
           <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
            (
            <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacques_Santrot" title="fr:Jacques Santrot">
             fr
            </a>
            )
           </span>
           , the expression which was then adopted by a geographer, Jean-François Troin, which also cited the TGV stations of
           <a href="/wiki/Vend%C3%B4me" title="Vendôme">
            Vendôme
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A2con" title="Mâcon">
            Mâcon
           </a>
           , and
           <a href="/wiki/Le_Creusot" title="Le Creusot">
            Le Creusot
           </a>
           .
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.lorraine.developpement-durable.gouv.fr/IMG/pdf/Rapport_Adielor_Phase_2_cle817d73.pdf" rel="nofollow">
             "Analyse de l'impact du TGV-Est sur les agglomérations de Metz, Nancy, Épinal et Thionville"
            </a>
            <span style="font-size:85%;">
             (PDF)
            </span>
            . 16 November 2004. p. 33. rapport de phase 2, I.S.I.S. Ingénierie.
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Analyse+de+l%E2%80%99impact+du+TGV-Est+sur+les+agglom%C3%A9rations+de+Metz%2C+Nancy%2C+%C3%89pinal+et+Thionville&amp;rft.pages=33&amp;rft.date=2004-11-16&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.lorraine.developpement-durable.gouv.fr%2FIMG%2Fpdf%2FRapport_Adielor_Phase_2_cle817d73.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAmiens">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-16">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-16">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150923232144/http://www.courrier-picard.fr/region/tgv-picardie-roissy-le-ministre-des-transports-valide-le-projet-ia0b0n69766" rel="nofollow">
             "TGV Picardie-Roissy: le ministre des Transports valide le projet"
            </a>
            .
            <i>
             Le Courrier picard
            </i>
            . 1 May 2013. Archived from
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.courrier-picard.fr/region/tgv-picardie-roissy-le-ministre-des-transports-valide-le-projet-ia0b0n69766" rel="nofollow">
             the original
            </a>
            on 23 September 2015.
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Le+Courrier+picard&amp;rft.atitle=TGV+Picardie-Roissy%3A+le+ministre+des+Transports+valide+le+projet&amp;rft.date=2013-05-01&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.courrier-picard.fr%2Fregion%2Ftgv-picardie-roissy-le-ministre-des-transports-valide-le-projet-ia0b0n69766&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAmiens">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-18">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-18">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation journal">
            "Amiens, Un écoquartier en projet à Montières".

           </a>
           <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
            (
            <a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Code_de_la_s%C3%A9curit%C3%A9_sociale_(France)" title="fr:Code de la sécurité sociale (France)">

            <a class="external text" href="https://www.webcitation.org/5lctsW5KG?url=http://www.twins2010.com/fileadmin/user_upload/pic/Dokumente/List_of_Twin_Towns_01.pdf?PHPSESSID=2edd34819db21e450d3bb625549ce4fd" rel="nofollow">

          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">

            </a>

          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           Unlike most cathedrals in France, Notre Dame Amiens has substantially retained all of its original statues and ornaments, which even today allows one to admire some of the colours used in Middle Ages.

           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=DRAVIE.net&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.languepicarde.fr%2Fpages%2Frubrique-91%2Flangue_et_culture_de_picardie.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAmiens">

         <li id="cite_note-waterways-180">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-waterways_180-0">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-waterways_180-1">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               b
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Hugh McKnight (1 Sep 2005).
